explanation: Digoxin is appropriate for rate control in HFrEF patients with AFib when beta-blockers alone are insufficient or limited by hypotension. It provides rate control without negative inotropy or hypotension. Non-dihydropyridine calcium channel blockers (A, B) are contraindicated in HFrEF due to negative inotropic effects. Amiodarone (D) is for rhythm control, not rate control. Ivabradine (E) is ineffective in AFib because it works on the SA node, which is overridden by atrial fibrillation.

stem:
A 62-year-old man with CAD and prior MI requires high-intensity statin therapy. He develops severe bilateral thigh myalgias 3 weeks after starting atorvastatin 80 mg. CK is mildly elevated at 380 U/L (normal <200). The statin is stopped and symptoms resolve after 2 weeks. He previously had similar myalgias on rosuvastatin 20 mg.

What is the most appropriate next step?
options: [{"text":"Rechallenge with atorvastatin 80 mg","label":"A"},{"text":"Trial of rosuvastatin 5 mg every other day","label":"B"},{"text":"Start ezetimibe monotherapy","label":"C"},{"text":"No lipid-lowering therapy needed given intolerance","label":"D"},{"text":"Start fenofibrate","label":"E"}]
explanation: For patients with statin intolerance, a trial of an alternative statin at lower dose or with alternate-day dosing is the first step. Rosuvastatin has a long half-life making every-other-day dosing feasible. If this fails, ezetimibe (C) or PCSK9 inhibitors can be added or substituted. Rechallenging with the same high dose (A) will likely reproduce symptoms. Abandoning lipid therapy (D) is inappropriate given his high ASCVD risk. Fenofibrate (E) does not have the same cardiovascular benefit as statins.

stem:
A 24-year-old college athlete is diagnosed with hypertrophic cardiomyopathy after a pre-participation screening echocardiogram showed asymmetric septal hypertrophy of 18 mm. He is asymptomatic with no syncope or family history of sudden cardiac death. He asks about continuing to play competitive basketball.

Which of the following recommendations is most appropriate?
options: [{"text":"Continue competitive sports if stress test is normal","label":"A"},{"text":"Disqualification from competitive sports is recommended","label":"B"},{"text":"Sports participation allowed with prophylactic ICD","label":"C"},{"text":"Competitive sports allowed if on beta-blocker therapy","label":"D"},{"text":"Restriction only applies to contact sports","label":"E"}]
explanation: HCM is the leading cause of sudden cardiac death in young athletes. Current guidelines recommend disqualification from competitive sports regardless of symptoms, risk stratification, or treatment. Exercise causes dynamic obstruction, arrhythmias, and ischemia in HCM. Low-intensity recreational activity may be considered after shared decision-making, but competitive athletics are contraindicated. An ICD (C) prevents death but does not make competitive sports safe. Beta- blockers (D) do not eliminate the risk.

stem:
A 58-year-old man with ischemic cardiomyopathy had a STEMI 3 weeks ago treated with PCI. Current EF is 28%. He is now on optimal GDMT including sacubitril/valsartan, carvedilol, spironolactone, and empagliflozin with good blood pressure and symptom control.

What is the most appropriate recommendation regarding ICD placement?
options: [{"text":"Implant ICD now given EF <30%","label":"A"},{"text":"Reassess EF in 3 months; ICD if EF remains ≤35%","label":"B"},{"text":"ICD only if he has documented ventricular arrhythmia","label":"C"},{"text":"ICD contraindicated in ischemic cardiomyopathy","label":"D"},{"text":"Implant ICD only if EF <20%","label":"E"}]
explanation: Primary prevention ICD is indicated if EF remains ≤35% despite at least 3 months of optimal GDMT. However, ICD should NOT be implanted within 40 days of MI or within 90 days of revascularization, as EF may improve with GDMT and revascularization. This patient is only 3 weeks post-MI. Reassessment at 3 months will determine if he still meets criteria. Waiting for documented arrhythmia (C) describes secondary prevention, not primary prevention.

stem:
A 68-year-old woman with a mechanical mitral valve on warfarin (INR goal 2.5-3.5) requires elective hip replacement surgery. Her INR is 3.0. The surgeon plans to hold warfarin 5 days preoperatively.

What is the appropriate anticoagulation management perioperatively?
options: [{"text":"Hold warfarin only; no bridging needed","label":"A"},{"text":"Bridge with therapeutic enoxaparin, stop 24h before surgery","label":"B"},{"text":"Bridge with therapeutic unfractionated heparin, stop 4-6h before surgery","label":"C"},{"text":"Continue warfarin through surgery with close INR monitoring","label":"D"},{"text":"Switch to apixaban for the perioperative period","label":"E"}]
explanation: Patients with mechanical heart valves (especially mitral position) have high thromboembolic risk and require bridging anticoagulation when warfarin is held. Therapeutic-dose LMWH or UFH should be used. LMWH is stopped 24 hours before surgery; UFH is stopped 4-6 hours before. No bridging (A) is inappropriate for mechanical valves. Continuing warfarin (D) creates unacceptable surgical bleeding risk. DOACs (E) are contraindicated with mechanical valves.

stem:
A 54-year-old man has blood pressure of 158/96 mmHg despite amlodipine 10 mg, lisinopril 40 mg, and chlorthalidone 25 mg daily. He reports taking his medications consistently. His BMI is 32 kg/m². Basic metabolic panel shows potassium 3.2 mEq/L and creatinine 1.0 mg/dL. Urinalysis is negative for protein.

Which secondary cause should be evaluated first based on his presentation?
options: [{"text":"Pheochromocytoma","label":"A"},{"text":"Primary hyperaldosteronism","label":"B"},{"text":"Renal artery stenosis","label":"C"},{"text":"Cushing syndrome","label":"D"},{"text":"Coarctation of the aorta","label":"E"}]
explanation: This patient has resistant hypertension (BP uncontrolled on 3 drugs including a diuretic). The hypokalemia (K 3.2) despite not being on a potassium-wasting diuretic at high dose strongly suggests primary hyperaldosteronism, which is present in 10-20% of resistant hypertension. Screening is with aldosterone-to-renin ratio. Renal artery stenosis (C) would be suggested by rising creatinine on ACE inhibitor, which is not present. Pheochromocytoma (A) typically presents with episodic symptoms.

stem:
A 66-year-old man with COPD (FEV1 55% predicted) has been on fluticasone/salmeterol for 3 years. He has had no exacerbations in the past 2 years. Recent CBC shows blood eosinophils of 80 cells/μL. He asks about simplifying his regimen due to concern about pneumonia risk from ICS.

What is the most appropriate recommendation?
options: [{"text":"Continue current ICS/LABA regimen indefinitely","label":"A"},{"text":"Withdraw ICS; continue LABA monotherapy","label":"B"},{"text":"Withdraw ICS; switch to LAMA/LABA combination","label":"C"},{"text":"Add LAMA to current ICS/LABA regimen","label":"D"},{"text":"ICS withdrawal is never safe in COPD","label":"E"}]
explanation: ICS withdrawal is safe and appropriate in COPD patients with low eosinophil counts (<300 cells/μL) and infrequent exacerbations (<2/year). This patient meets both criteria (eosinophils 80, no exacerbations in 2 years). ICS increases pneumonia risk in COPD without providing benefit in this population. Withdrawing to LAMA/LABA maintains bronchodilation while eliminating ICS risks. LABA monotherapy (B) is less effective than dual bronchodilation. ICS withdrawal is evidence-based when appropriate (E is incorrect).

stem:
A 58-year-old woman with a 25-pack-year smoking history has an incidental 7 mm solid pulmonary nodule found on CT chest performed for rib pain after a fall. She has no respiratory symptoms. The nodule has smooth margins. She has no prior imaging for comparison.

What is the most appropriate next step?
options: [{"text":"PET-CT for metabolic characterization","label":"A"},{"text":"CT-guided biopsy","label":"B"},{"text":"Repeat CT in 6-12 months per Fleischner criteria","label":"C"},{"text":"Surgical resection given smoking history","label":"D"},{"text":"No follow-up needed for nodules <8 mm","label":"E"}]
explanation: Per Fleischner Society guidelines for solid pulmonary nodules, a 6-8 mm nodule in a high-risk patient (>25 pack-year smoking) warrants CT surveillance at 6-12 months, then consider additional imaging at 18-24 months. PET-CT (A) has limited utility for nodules <8-10 mm due to poor sensitivity. Biopsy (B) and surgery (D) are premature without evidence of growth. Nodules <6 mm in high-risk patients may be followed; this nodule requires surveillance (E is incorrect).

stem:
A 52-year-old woman with non-CF bronchiectasis has chronic productive cough with 30-50 mL of purulent sputum daily. She has had 3 exacerbations requiring antibiotics in the past year. Sputum cultures persistently grow Pseudomonas aeruginosa. She is currently on inhaled hypertonic saline.

Which additional therapy is most likely to reduce exacerbation frequency?
options: [{"text":"Long-term oral azithromycin","label":"A"},{"text":"Inhaled corticosteroids","label":"B"},{"text":"Daily oral fluoroquinolone","label":"C"},{"text":"Continuous oral amoxicillin","label":"D"},{"text":"Systemic corticosteroids","label":"E"}]
explanation: In bronchiectasis with frequent exacerbations (≥3/year), long-term macrolide therapy (azithromycin) reduces exacerbation frequency through anti-inflammatory and immunomodulatory effects, not just antimicrobial action. Airway clearance techniques and mucolytics are foundational. ICS (B) is not standard for bronchiectasis. Continuous fluoroquinolones (C) or amoxicillin (D) promote resistance without proven exacerbation reduction. Inhaled antibiotics (tobramycin) may be considered for Pseudomonas but weren't listed.

stem:
A 68-year-old man with idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis (IPF) diagnosed by HRCT showing UIP pattern has progressive dyspnea. His FVC is 72% predicted, down from 80% one year ago. He asks about treatment options to slow disease progression.

What is the most appropriate pharmacotherapy?
options: [{"text":"Prednisone 40 mg daily","label":"A"},{"text":"Azathioprine plus prednisone","label":"B"},{"text":"Pirfenidone or nintedanib","label":"C"},{"text":"Mycophenolate mofetil","label":"D"},{"text":"N-acetylcysteine monotherapy","label":"E"}]
explanation: Antifibrotic agents (pirfenidone or nintedanib) are the only pharmacotherapies proven to slow FVC decline in IPF. Importantly, systemic corticosteroids (A) and immunosuppression (B, D) are NOT beneficial and may increase mortality in IPF (PANTHER-IPF trial showed harm with prednisone/azathioprine/NAC). N-acetylcysteine monotherapy (E) showed no benefit. These patients should be referred for lung transplant evaluation.

stem:
A 71-year-old man with severe COPD presents with acute hypercapnic respiratory failure (pH 7.28, pCO2 68 mmHg). He is drowsy but arousable and follows commands. He is hemodynamically stable. The team considers non-invasive positive pressure ventilation (NIPPV).

Which of the following would be a contraindication to NIPPV in this patient?
options: [{"text":"Drowsiness with ability to follow commands","label":"A"},{"text":"pH < 7.30","label":"B"},{"text":"Copious respiratory secretions with inability to clear","label":"C"},{"text":"pCO2 > 60 mmHg","label":"D"},{"text":"Respiratory rate of 28/min","label":"E"}]
explanation: NIPPV is contraindicated when the patient cannot protect their airway, including those with copious secretions they cannot clear. This creates aspiration risk and prevents effective ventilation. Drowsiness alone (A) is not a contraindication if the patient can cooperate and protect their airway. Acidosis (B) and hypercapnia (D) are indications for, not against, NIPPV. Other contraindications include: facial trauma/surgery, hemodynamic instability, cardiac arrest, and GI bleeding with emesis risk.

stem:
A 45-year-old woman with progressive dyspnea undergoes right heart catheterization showing mPAP 42 mmHg, PCWP 10 mmHg, and PVR 6 Wood units. Echocardiogram shows normal LV function. V/Q scan and workup for connective tissue disease are negative. She is diagnosed with idiopathic pulmonary arterial hypertension.

Which therapy class is appropriate for this patient?
options: [{"text":"Calcium channel blockers as first-line for all PAH","label":"A"},{"text":"Endothelin receptor antagonist (bosentan)","label":"B"},{"text":"Loop diuretics as primary therapy","label":"C"},{"text":"Beta-blockers for rate control","label":"D"},{"text":"Sildenafil is contraindicated in PAH","label":"E"}]
explanation: This patient has Group 1 PAH (precapillary PH with normal PCWP). Specific PAH therapies include endothelin receptor antagonists (bosentan, ambrisentan), PDE5 inhibitors (sildenafil, tadalafil), and prostacyclins. These are NOT indicated for Group 2 PH (left heart disease). Calcium channel blockers (A) are only for the minority with positive vasoreactivity testing. Diuretics (C) are supportive, not primary therapy. Beta-blockers (D) are generally avoided. Sildenafil (E) IS indicated for PAH.

stem:
A 56-year-old man with chronic GERD undergoes EGD showing 4 cm of salmon-colored mucosa extending from the GE junction. Biopsies confirm intestinal metaplasia without dysplasia. He is on omeprazole 20 mg daily.

What is the appropriate surveillance interval for repeat EGD?
options: [{"text":"Repeat EGD in 6 months","label":"A"},{"text":"Repeat EGD in 1 year","label":"B"},{"text":"Repeat EGD in 3-5 years","label":"C"},{"text":"No further surveillance needed if no dysplasia","label":"D"},{"text":"EGD only if symptoms worsen","label":"E"}]
explanation: Barrett's esophagus without dysplasia requires surveillance EGD every 3-5 years to detect progression to dysplasia or adenocarcinoma. More frequent surveillance (6-12 months) is reserved for low-grade dysplasia. High-grade dysplasia requires intervention (ablation or resection). Surveillance should not be abandoned (D) given malignancy risk. The patient should also be on optimized PPI therapy (consider increasing to 40 mg or BID dosing).

stem:
A 72-year-old woman has been on omeprazole 40 mg daily for 8 years for GERD symptoms. She now presents with fatigue. Labs show hemoglobin 10.2 g/dL with MCV 108 fL, vitamin B12 level of 180 pg/mL (normal >200), and magnesium 1.4 mEq/L (normal 1.7-2.2).

Which findings are most likely related to her long-term PPI use?
options: [{"text":"Vitamin B12 deficiency only","label":"A"},{"text":"Hypomagnesemia only","label":"B"},{"text":"Both vitamin B12 deficiency and hypomagnesemia","label":"C"},{"text":"Neither finding is PPI-related","label":"D"},{"text":"These findings indicate PPI overdose toxicity","label":"E"}]
explanation: Long-term PPI use is associated with vitamin B12 deficiency (reduced acid impairs B12 absorption from food) and hypomagnesemia (mechanism unclear, may involve intestinal TRPM6 channels). Other risks include C. difficile infection, community-acquired pneumonia, and hip fractures. The appropriate response is to use the lowest effective PPI dose, supplement B12 and magnesium as needed, and reassess ongoing PPI necessity. These are not "toxicity" but rather chronic effects.

stem:
A 52-year-old woman with obesity (BMI 34) and type 2 diabetes has elevated ALT of 68 U/L. Ultrasound shows hepatic steatosis. FibroScan reveals liver stiffness of 9.8 kPa, suggesting significant fibrosis (F2-F3). Hepatitis B and C serologies are negative.

Which intervention has the strongest evidence for improving liver histology?
options: [{"text":"Ursodeoxycholic acid","label":"A"},{"text":"Vitamin E 800 IU daily","label":"B"},{"text":"Weight loss of 7-10% of body weight","label":"C"},{"text":"Metformin intensification","label":"D"},{"text":"Milk thistle supplementation","label":"E"}]
explanation: Weight loss of 7-10% body weight is the most effective intervention for improving NASH histology, including steatosis, inflammation, and fibrosis. This patient with significant fibrosis (F2-F3) is at high risk for progression to cirrhosis. Vitamin E (B) may help inflammation in non-diabetic NASH but has less effect on fibrosis. Metformin (D) does not improve liver histology despite glucose benefits. GLP-1 agonists and SGLT2 inhibitors show promise. Ursodeoxycholic acid (A) and milk thistle (E) lack evidence.

stem:
A 32-year-old woman with anorexia nervosa (BMI 14.5) is admitted after syncopal episode. She reports minimal oral intake for 3 weeks. Labs show phosphorus 2.8 mg/dL (normal 2.5-4.5), potassium 3.4 mEq/L, and magnesium 1.8 mEq/L. The team plans to initiate nutritional support.

What is the most appropriate initial approach to nutrition?
options: [{"text":"Start full caloric requirements immediately to reverse malnutrition","label":"A"},{"text":"Start at 10-15 kcal/kg/day with phosphorus, potassium, and thiamine supplementation","label":"B"},{"text":"TPN is required for severe malnutrition","label":"C"},{"text":"High-protein diet to rebuild muscle mass","label":"D"},{"text":"Wait for electrolytes to normalize before feeding","label":"E"}]
explanation: Refeeding syndrome is a life-threatening complication of rapid nutritional repletion in malnourished patients. It causes profound hypophosphatemia, hypokalemia, and hypomagnesemia as insulin surge drives electrolytes intracellularly. Prevention requires starting low-calorie feeds (10-15 kcal/kg/day), advancing slowly, supplementing phosphorus/potassium/magnesium prophylactically, and giving thiamine before glucose. Full caloric feeding (A) precipitates the syndrome. Waiting (E) delays necessary nutrition.

stem:
A 63-year-old man with cirrhosis and prior hepatic encephalopathy episodes is on lactulose 30 mL three times daily. He presents confused with asterixis. His wife reports he has had 6 loose bowel movements daily for the past week and reduced oral intake due to nausea.

What is the most appropriate adjustment to his lactulose regimen?
options: [{"text":"Increase lactulose to 45 mL three times daily","label":"A"},{"text":"Decrease lactulose and reassess fluid/electrolyte status","label":"B"},{"text":"Stop lactulose; it is ineffective if he is still encephalopathic","label":"C"},{"text":"Continue same dose; 6 bowel movements is appropriate","label":"D"},{"text":"Switch to rifaximin monotherapy","label":"E"}]
explanation: Lactulose should be titrated to 2-3 soft bowel movements per day. Excessive lactulose causing >4-5 BMs leads to dehydration and electrolyte disturbances that can paradoxically worsen or precipitate encephalopathy. This patient's 6 BMs daily with reduced intake suggests lactulose-induced dehydration as a precipitant of his current encephalopathy. The appropriate response is to reduce lactulose, correct volume/electrolytes, and reassess. Rifaximin (E) is adjunctive, not replacement, therapy.

stem:
A 58-year-old man with decompensated cirrhosis and ascites was diagnosed with spontaneous bacterial peritonitis (PMN 850/mm³, monomicrobial E. coli) 72 hours ago and started on ceftriaxone. Repeat paracentesis shows PMN 920/mm³. He has new diffuse abdominal tenderness and rebound.

What is the most appropriate next step?
options: [{"text":"Continue ceftriaxone for full 5-day course","label":"A"},{"text":"Add metronidazole for anaerobic coverage","label":"B"},{"text":"Obtain CT abdomen to evaluate for secondary peritonitis","label":"C"},{"text":"Switch to meropenem for resistant organisms","label":"D"},{"text":"Repeat paracentesis in 48 hours","label":"E"}]
explanation: Failure to improve on appropriate SBP therapy (defined as <25% decrease in PMN count at 48-72 hours) should raise concern for secondary peritonitis from a surgical source (bowel perforation, abscess, cholecystitis). The development of new peritoneal signs (rebound tenderness) further supports this. CT abdomen is essential to identify a surgically treatable source. Polymicrobial cultures or high protein ascites also suggest secondary peritonitis. Simply changing antibiotics (B, D) without imaging misses potentially life-threatening pathology.

stem:
A 74-year-old woman on chronic furosemide therapy for HFrEF presents with creatinine rise from 1.2 to 2.4 mg/dL. She has orthostatic hypotension and poor skin turgor. Urinalysis shows bland sediment. FENa is calculated at 2.8%.

How should this FENa result be interpreted?
options: [{"text":"FENa >2% confirms intrinsic renal injury (ATN)","label":"A"},{"text":"FENa is unreliable; calculate FEUrea instead","label":"B"},{"text":"FENa >1% rules out prerenal azotemia","label":"C"},{"text":"The elevated FENa indicates post-renal obstruction","label":"D"},{"text":"Diuretics do not affect FENa calculation","label":"E"}]
explanation: FENa is unreliable in patients on diuretics because diuretics cause obligate sodium wasting, elevating FENa even in prerenal states. This patient has clinical signs of volume depletion (orthostasis, poor turgor) suggesting prerenal AKI, but her FENa is falsely elevated by furosemide. FEUrea (fractional excretion of urea) is unaffected by diuretics; FEUrea <35% suggests prerenal azotemia. Using FENa alone here would lead to misdiagnosis and inappropriate withholding of volume resuscitation.

stem:
A 68-year-old man with hypertension on lisinopril 20 mg and hydrochlorothiazide 25 mg daily presents for knee pain. He is considering taking ibuprofen 600 mg three times daily for osteoarthritis. His baseline creatinine is 1.4 mg/dL.

What is the most appropriate advice regarding NSAID use?
options: [{"text":"Ibuprofen is safe at this dose for short-term use","label":"A"},{"text":"Avoid NSAIDs; high risk for acute kidney injury","label":"B"},{"text":"NSAIDs are safe if taken with food","label":"C"},{"text":"Switch hydrochlorothiazide to furosemide before starting NSAID","label":"D"},{"text":"NSAIDs are nephrotoxic only in patients with CKD stage 4-5","label":"E"}]
explanation: The combination of NSAID + ACE inhibitor/ARB + diuretic is called the "triple whammy" and carries significantly elevated risk of AKI. NSAIDs block prostaglandin-mediated afferent arteriolar vasodilation, ACEi/ARBs block efferent arteriolar constriction, and diuretics reduce intravascular volume. Together, they can precipitate severe prerenal AKI. This patient should avoid NSAIDs; alternatives include acetaminophen, topical NSAIDs, or considering temporary NSAID use with holding ACEi during that period (with close monitoring).

stem:
A 72-year-old man with BPH presents with urinary retention and creatinine of 6.8 mg/dL. Foley catheter is placed with immediate drainage of 1400 mL of urine. Over the next 6 hours, he produces 2800 mL of urine. His blood pressure is 108/68 mmHg, down from 142/86 mmHg on admission.

What is the most appropriate fluid management?
options: [{"text":"Strict fluid restriction to reduce urine output","label":"A"},{"text":"Replace urine output 1:1 with IV normal saline","label":"B"},{"text":"Replace approximately 50% of urine output with IV fluids","label":"C"},{"text":"No IV fluids needed; this diuresis is physiologic","label":"D"},{"text":"Furosemide to control excessive urine output","label":"E"}]
explanation: Post-obstructive diuresis is common after relief of urinary obstruction and results from accumulated urea acting as an osmotic diuretic plus impaired tubular concentrating ability. While some diuresis is physiologic (clearing retained solutes), excessive replacement (1:1) perpetuates the diuresis. Replacing approximately 50% of urine output prevents hypovolemia while allowing the diuresis to naturally resolve. This patient's hypotension indicates he needs volume replacement. Strict restriction (A) risks hypovolemia and hemodynamic collapse.

stem:
A 64-year-old man with type 2 diabetes on metformin 1000 mg twice daily and CKD stage 3b (eGFR 38 mL/min) requires CT angiography with IV contrast to evaluate peripheral vascular disease. His creatinine is 1.8 mg/dL.

What is the appropriate management of metformin?
options: [{"text":"Continue metformin without interruption","label":"A"},{"text":"Hold metformin for 24 hours before and 48 hours after contrast","label":"B"},{"text":"Hold metformin starting the day of the procedure and for 48 hours after, then check creatinine","label":"C"},{"text":"Metformin is contraindicated in patients receiving IV contrast","label":"D"},{"text":"Switch to insulin permanently before contrast studies","label":"E"}]
explanation: Metformin itself is not nephrotoxic, but if contrast causes AKI, metformin accumulation can cause lactic acidosis. Current guidelines recommend holding metformin starting the day of the procedure in patients with eGFR <45 (or <60 if receiving intra-arterial contrast). Metformin should be held for 48 hours post-contrast, and renal function should be checked before resuming. Pre-procedure hydration should also be provided. Permanent discontinuation (E) is unnecessary if renal function remains stable.

stem:
A 58-year-old woman with ESKD from diabetic nephropathy requires dialysis initiation. She works full-time as a teacher, values independence, and wants to minimize time at medical facilities. She has no significant cardiac disease. Her partner is willing to assist with treatments.

Which dialysis modality best fits her preferences?
options: [{"text":"In-center hemodialysis 3 times per week","label":"A"},{"text":"Peritoneal dialysis","label":"B"},{"text":"Hemodialysis is medically superior and should be chosen","label":"C"},{"text":"Dialysis modality should be chosen by nephrologist, not patient","label":"D"},{"text":"She should defer dialysis as long as possible","label":"E"}]
explanation: Peritoneal dialysis (PD) offers advantages for patients who prioritize independence, flexible scheduling, and minimizing facility visits. PD is performed at home (often overnight), allows continued employment, and preserves residual renal function better than HD initially. This patient's preferences, home support, and lack of contraindications (severe cardiac disease, abdominal surgery) make her an excellent PD candidate. Modality selection should be shared decision-making, not physician-imposed (D). Neither modality has clear survival advantage for most patients.

stem:
A 54-year-old woman with polymyalgia rheumatica has been on prednisone 20 mg daily for 4 months with good symptom control. Her rheumatologist wants to discontinue steroids. She asks about the safest way to stop the medication.

What is the most appropriate approach to discontinuation?
options: [{"text":"Stop prednisone abruptly; adrenal suppression is rare","label":"A"},{"text":"Taper prednisone gradually over weeks to months","label":"B"},{"text":"Switch to hydrocortisone for one week then stop","label":"C"},{"text":"Taper only needed if dose was >40 mg daily","label":"D"},{"text":"Check morning cortisol; if normal, stop immediately","label":"E"}]
explanation: Corticosteroid use for >3 weeks suppresses the hypothalamic-pituitary-adrenal (HPA) axis and adrenal cortisol production. Abrupt discontinuation can cause adrenal crisis (hypotension, shock, death). Gradual tapering allows HPA axis recovery. Typical approach: reduce by 5-10 mg every 1-2 weeks until reaching physiologic dose (5-7.5 mg prednisone), then slower taper. Patients should also receive stress-dose steroids if surgery or serious illness occurs during and shortly after the taper.

stem:
A 62-year-old man is in the ICU with septic shock from pneumonia. Thyroid function tests show: TSH 0.8 mIU/L (normal 0.5-4.5), free T4 0.9 ng/dL (normal 0.8-1.8), and total T3 42 ng/dL (low; normal 80-180). He has no history of thyroid disease.

What is the most appropriate management of these thyroid abnormalities?
options: [{"text":"Start levothyroxine for low T3","label":"A"},{"text":"Start liothyronine (T3) replacement","label":"B"},{"text":"No treatment; recheck thyroid function after recovery","label":"C"},{"text":"Order thyroid ultrasound to evaluate for thyroiditis","label":"D"},{"text":"Start combination T4/T3 therapy","label":"E"}]
explanation: This is sick euthyroid syndrome (nonthyroidal illness syndrome), characterized by low T3 with normal or low-normal TSH and T4 in critically ill patients. It represents an adaptive response to illness, not true thyroid dysfunction. T3 is reduced due to decreased peripheral conversion from T4. Treatment with thyroid hormone has not shown benefit and may be harmful. Thyroid function typically normalizes with recovery from the underlying illness. Retesting after recovery confirms resolution.

stem:
A 45-year-old woman with type 1 diabetes on basal-bolus insulin calls because she has gastroenteritis with vomiting and has not been able to eat for 24 hours. Her blood glucose is 186 mg/dL. She asks if she should skip her insulin doses.

What is the most appropriate advice?
options: [{"text":"Hold all insulin until able to eat normally","label":"A"},{"text":"Continue basal insulin; hold bolus insulin; monitor glucose frequently","label":"B"},{"text":"Take only 50% of usual basal insulin","label":"C"},{"text":"Continue all usual insulin doses regardless of intake","label":"D"},{"text":"Stop insulin and present to ED immediately","label":"E"}]
explanation: Sick day rules for type 1 diabetes: continue basal insulin even when not eating, as basal insulin prevents DKA (the body still needs insulin to prevent ketogenesis). Bolus/mealtime insulin can be held or reduced if not eating. Blood glucose should be monitored every 2-4 hours, ketones should be checked, and hydration maintained. Stopping all insulin (A) risks DKA. Counter-regulatory hormones during illness often raise glucose despite reduced intake. She should seek care if unable to keep down fluids or if ketones are elevated.

stem:
A 28-year-old woman at 8 weeks gestation has Graves' disease diagnosed before pregnancy. She is currently on methimazole 10 mg daily with controlled thyroid function (TSH 0.8 mIU/L, free T4 1.2 ng/dL). She asks about continuing her medication during pregnancy.

What is the most appropriate antithyroid drug management?
options: [{"text":"Continue methimazole throughout pregnancy","label":"A"},{"text":"Switch to propylthiouracil (PTU) now; consider switching back to methimazole after first trimester","label":"B"},{"text":"Stop all antithyroid drugs; use beta-blockers only","label":"C"},{"text":"Proceed with thyroidectomy during pregnancy","label":"D"},{"text":"Radioactive iodine ablation is safe in early pregnancy","label":"E"}]
explanation: Methimazole is associated with teratogenicity in the first trimester (aplasia cutis, choanal atresia, esophageal atresia). PTU is preferred during the first trimester despite its hepatotoxicity risk. After the first trimester (when organogenesis is complete), switching back to methimazole is recommended due to PTU's hepatotoxicity risk. Stopping antithyroid drugs (C) risks uncontrolled hyperthyroidism, which is harmful to fetus (growth restriction, preterm delivery). Radioactive iodine (E) is absolutely contraindicated in pregnancy.

stem:
A 58-year-old woman with metastatic pancreatic cancer is diagnosed with acute DVT of the left femoral vein. She has normal renal function and no GI bleeding history. She asks about anticoagulation options.

What is the most appropriate anticoagulation choice?
options: [{"text":"Warfarin with INR goal 2-3","label":"A"},{"text":"Low-molecular-weight heparin (enoxaparin) or edoxaban/rivaroxaban","label":"B"},{"text":"Unfractionated heparin indefinitely","label":"C"},{"text":"Fondaparinux as first-line for cancer VTE","label":"D"},{"text":"Inferior vena cava filter instead of anticoagulation","label":"E"}]
explanation: For cancer-associated VTE, LMWH or select DOACs (edoxaban, rivaroxaban) are preferred over warfarin based on lower recurrence rates. The HOKUSAI VTE-Cancer and SELECT-D trials showed DOACs are non-inferior to LMWH. However, DOACs carry higher GI bleeding risk in GI/GU malignancies, so LMWH remains preferred in those patients. Warfarin (A) is less effective in cancer patients due to drug interactions and variable INR. IVC filters (E) are reserved for anticoagulation contraindications, not first-line.

stem:
A 42-year-old woman with heavy menstrual bleeding has iron deficiency anemia (hemoglobin 9.2 g/dL, ferritin 8 ng/mL, iron saturation 10%). She was started on oral ferrous sulfate 325 mg three times daily 8 weeks ago but reports severe constipation and abdominal cramping. Repeat hemoglobin is 9.4 g/dL.

What is the most appropriate next step?
options: [{"text":"Continue oral iron; adequate response takes 3-6 months","label":"A"},{"text":"Switch to a different oral iron formulation","label":"B"},{"text":"Administer intravenous iron infusion","label":"C"},{"text":"Oral iron is the only appropriate treatment for iron deficiency","label":"D"},{"text":"Blood transfusion for anemia","label":"E"}]
explanation: IV iron is indicated when oral iron is not tolerated (as in this patient with severe GI side effects), when oral iron is ineffective (malabsorption, ongoing losses exceeding oral replacement capacity), or when rapid repletion is needed. This patient has documented intolerance and minimal response after 8 weeks. IV iron formulations (iron sucrose, ferric carboxymaltose, ferumoxytol) bypass GI absorption and rapidly replenish stores. Transfusion (E) is reserved for symptomatic anemia or hemodynamic instability, not for this stable patient.

stem:
A 72-year-old man with COPD undergoes elective hip replacement. Post-operatively, his hemoglobin is 7.4 g/dL. He is hemodynamically stable with no chest pain, dyspnea, or signs of active bleeding.

What is the most appropriate transfusion approach?
options: [{"text":"Transfuse to goal hemoglobin >10 g/dL","label":"A"},{"text":"Transfuse one unit of PRBCs; reassess","label":"B"},{"text":"No transfusion needed if asymptomatic","label":"C"},{"text":"Transfuse only if hemoglobin <6 g/dL","label":"D"},{"text":"Liberal transfusion strategy improves surgical outcomes","label":"E"}]
explanation: Restrictive transfusion strategy (transfuse at Hgb <7 g/dL) is appropriate for most stable hospitalized patients and is associated with equivalent or better outcomes compared to liberal strategies. This patient's hemoglobin of 7.4 g/dL is at the threshold; transfusing one unit and reassessing is reasonable given his age and comorbidities (COPD). The TRICC and TRACS trials support restrictive thresholds. Liberal threshold (<9-10 g/dL) is reserved for ACS or symptomatic anemia. Waiting until <6 g/dL (D) is unnecessarily restrictive.

stem:
A 66-year-old man with recent drug-eluting stent placement 3 months ago (on aspirin and clopidogrel) presents with melena. EGD reveals a duodenal ulcer with clean base that is treated with PPI. He is hemodynamically stable with hemoglobin of 10.2 g/dL. The GI team achieves hemostasis.

What is the appropriate management of antiplatelet therapy?
options: [{"text":"Discontinue all antiplatelets for 4 weeks","label":"A"},{"text":"Discontinue clopidogrel; continue aspirin once hemostasis confirmed","label":"B"},{"text":"Resume dual antiplatelet therapy within 24-48 hours if hemostasis achieved","label":"C"},{"text":"Permanently discontinue all antiplatelet therapy given bleeding history","label":"D"},{"text":"Bridge with heparin while antiplatelets are held","label":"E"}]
explanation: In patients with recent coronary stent on DAPT, prolonged antiplatelet interruption carries high risk of stent thrombosis, which has 30-40% mortality. Once endoscopic hemostasis is achieved and the patient is stable, DAPT should be resumed early (within 24-48 hours in high-risk cardiac patients). The ulcer had a clean base (low rebleeding risk). Continued PPI therapy reduces recurrent bleeding. Permanently stopping antiplatelets (D) or prolonged interruption (A) risks catastrophic stent thrombosis, which outweighs bleeding risk.

stem:
A 78-year-old man on warfarin for AFib (INR 4.2) presents after a fall with acute subdural hematoma and declining mental status. His blood pressure is 168/94 mmHg. Emergent reversal of anticoagulation is required.

What is the most appropriate reversal strategy?
options: [{"text":"Fresh frozen plasma 4 units + vitamin K 10 mg IV","label":"A"},{"text":"Vitamin K 10 mg IV alone","label":"B"},{"text":"4-factor prothrombin complex concentrate (PCC) + vitamin K 10 mg IV","label":"C"},{"text":"Activated charcoal to absorb warfarin","label":"D"},{"text":"Hold warfarin and recheck INR in 24 hours","label":"E"}]
explanation: For life-threatening bleeding on warfarin (intracranial hemorrhage), 4-factor PCC is preferred over FFP for reversal. PCC advantages: faster reversal (minutes vs hours), smaller volume (avoids fluid overload), complete factor replacement, no thawing required. Vitamin K should be given concurrently for sustained reversal (PCC effect wanes as factors are consumed). FFP alone (A) is slower and may not fully correct INR. Vitamin K alone (B) takes 12-24 hours for effect, too slow for ICH. This is a medical emergency; observation (E) is inappropriate.

stem:
A 72-year-old woman with type 2 diabetes is admitted for elective knee replacement. Preoperative urinalysis shows >100,000 CFU/mL E. coli. She has no urinary symptoms, fever, or costovertebral angle tenderness. The orthopedic team asks if she needs antibiotic treatment before surgery.

What is the most appropriate management?
options: [{"text":"Treat with ciprofloxacin for 7 days before surgery","label":"A"},{"text":"Treat with nitrofurantoin for 5 days before surgery","label":"B"},{"text":"No antibiotic treatment indicated; proceed with surgery","label":"C"},{"text":"Cancel surgery until urine is sterile","label":"D"},{"text":"Obtain urine culture to guide antibiotic selection","label":"E"}]
explanation: Asymptomatic bacteriuria should NOT be treated except in two specific situations: pregnancy and prior to urologic procedures involving mucosal trauma. Orthopedic surgery does not require treatment of asymptomatic bacteriuria. Treatment does not reduce surgical site infections and promotes antibiotic resistance. The patient has no symptoms of UTI (dysuria, frequency, urgency, fever), so this is true asymptomatic bacteriuria. Diabetic status does not change this recommendation.

stem:
A 58-year-old man presents with pneumonia requiring ICU admission. He was hospitalized 6 weeks ago for a COPD exacerbation. He is not on hemodialysis and has no known MRSA history. Chest X-ray shows multilobar infiltrates. He is hypotensive requiring vasopressors.

Should empiric MRSA coverage (vancomycin) be included in his antibiotic regimen?
options: [{"text":"No; MRSA coverage not needed for community-acquired pneumonia","label":"A"},{"text":"Yes; recent hospitalization is a risk factor for MRSA","label":"B"},{"text":"Only if sputum Gram stain shows gram-positive cocci","label":"C"},{"text":"MRSA coverage is only needed for skin infections","label":"D"},{"text":"Wait for culture results before adding MRSA coverage","label":"E"}]
explanation: Risk factors for MRSA pneumonia that warrant empiric vancomycin/linezolid include: prior MRSA infection or colonization, recent hospitalization (within 90 days), hemodialysis, IV drug use, and severe/necrotizing presentation. This patient's recent hospitalization 6 weeks ago qualifies him for empiric MRSA coverage. Waiting for culture results (E) is inappropriate given his severe presentation. MRSA coverage should be de-escalated if cultures return negative at 48-72 hours.

stem:
A 64-year-old man was started on vancomycin and piperacillin-tazobactam for healthcare-associated pneumonia. Blood cultures grow methicillin-sensitive Staphylococcus aureus (MSSA). He has defervesced and is clinically improving at 72 hours.

What is the most appropriate antibiotic adjustment?
options: [{"text":"Continue vancomycin and piperacillin-tazobactam for full course","label":"A"},{"text":"Stop vancomycin; continue piperacillin-tazobactam","label":"B"},{"text":"Stop both; switch to nafcillin or cefazolin","label":"C"},{"text":"Stop piperacillin-tazobactam; continue vancomycin","label":"D"},{"text":"Add gentamicin for synergy","label":"E"}]
explanation: Antibiotic de-escalation based on culture and sensitivity data is essential stewardship. MSSA bacteremia should be treated with a beta-lactam (nafcillin, oxacillin, or cefazolin), which has superior efficacy compared to vancomycin for MSSA. Continuing vancomycin (D) provides inferior MSSA coverage. Continuing broad-spectrum empiric therapy (A) promotes resistance and adverse effects. The patient is clinically improving, supporting de-escalation. Note: MSSA bacteremia typically requires 4-6 weeks of treatment with evaluation for endocarditis.

stem:
A 34-year-old healthcare worker from the Philippines has a positive interferon-gamma release assay (IGRA) during routine screening. Chest X-ray is normal. She has no symptoms of cough, fever, night sweats, or weight loss. She has no history of TB treatment. She is not immunocompromised.

What is the most appropriate management?
options: [{"text":"No treatment needed if asymptomatic with normal chest X-ray","label":"A"},{"text":"Treat for latent TB infection","label":"B"},{"text":"Repeat IGRA in 3 months to confirm","label":"C"},{"text":"Treat only if she develops active TB symptoms","label":"D"},{"text":"Isoniazid prophylaxis only for immunocompromised patients","label":"E"}]
explanation: This patient has latent TB infection (LTBI): positive IGRA with no symptoms or radiographic evidence of active disease. Healthcare workers have ongoing TB exposure risk, and LTBI treatment reduces her 5-10% lifetime risk of reactivation to <1%. Treatment options include 4 months of rifampin, 3 months of isoniazid-rifapentine, or 6-9 months of isoniazid. Foreign-born individuals from high-prevalence countries and healthcare workers are high-risk groups for whom LTBI treatment is recommended. Waiting for active disease (D) is inappropriate prevention.

stem:
A 28-year-old woman with newly diagnosed focal epilepsy requires anti-seizure medication. She is planning pregnancy within the next year. She has no other medical conditions.

Which anti-seizure medication should be avoided due to teratogenicity concerns?
options: [{"text":"Levetiracetam","label":"A"},{"text":"Lamotrigine","label":"B"},{"text":"Valproate","label":"C"},{"text":"Lacosamide","label":"D"},{"text":"Oxcarbazepine","label":"E"}]
explanation: Valproate is the most teratogenic anti-seizure medication and should be avoided in women of childbearing potential. It causes neural tube defects, craniofacial abnormalities, and neurodevelopmental impairment at rates significantly higher than other ASMs. Levetiracetam (A) and lamotrigine (B) have the best safety data in pregnancy and are preferred for women planning conception. All women on ASMs planning pregnancy should take high-dose folic acid (4 mg daily). Valproate also has significant weight gain and polycystic ovary syndrome associations.

stem:
A 52-year-old man presents with fever, severe headache, and neck stiffness. He is alert and oriented with no focal neurologic deficits. Fundoscopic exam is normal without papilledema. He is immunocompetent with no HIV risk factors.

What is the most appropriate next step before lumbar puncture?
options: [{"text":"CT head is required before LP in all patients with suspected meningitis","label":"A"},{"text":"Proceed directly to LP; CT head not needed","label":"B"},{"text":"MRI brain before LP","label":"C"},{"text":"CT head required because of his age >50","label":"D"},{"text":"Blood cultures and antibiotics; defer LP","label":"E"}]
explanation: CT before LP is only required if the patient has risk factors for herniation or space-occupying lesion: focal neurologic deficits, papilledema, altered mental status, immunocompromised state (HIV, transplant), or history of CNS disease. This patient has none of these features: he is alert, oriented, non-immunocompromised, without focal findings or papilledema. LP can proceed immediately. Age alone (D) is not an indication for pre-LP imaging. Delaying LP for imaging can delay diagnosis and treatment of bacterial meningitis.

stem:
A 38-year-old woman on paroxetine 40 mg daily for 2 years abruptly stops her medication because she "feels better." Five days later, she presents with dizziness, nausea, "electric shock" sensations, irritability, and vivid dreams. Her vital signs are normal.

What is the most likely diagnosis?
options: [{"text":"Recurrence of major depressive disorder","label":"A"},{"text":"Serotonin syndrome","label":"B"},{"text":"SSRI discontinuation syndrome","label":"C"},{"text":"Generalized anxiety disorder","label":"D"},{"text":"Panic disorder","label":"E"}]
explanation: SSRI discontinuation syndrome occurs when SSRIs (especially those with short half-lives like paroxetine and venlafaxine) are abruptly stopped. Symptoms include "FINISH": Flu-like symptoms, Insomnia, Nausea, Imbalance/dizziness, Sensory disturbances (electric shock/"brain zaps"), and Hyperarousal. Symptoms typically begin 2-4 days after stopping and resolve within 1-2 weeks or upon reinstatement. This is not serotonin syndrome (B), which presents with hyperthermia, rigidity, and autonomic instability from serotonin excess. Treatment: restart medication and taper gradually.

stem:
A 45-year-old woman with treatment-resistant depression on fluoxetine 60 mg is transitioning to phenelzine (an MAOI) after failing multiple medication trials. The psychiatrist plans to stop fluoxetine.

What is the minimum required washout period before starting phenelzine?
options: [{"text":"No washout needed; start immediately","label":"A"},{"text":"2 weeks","label":"B"},{"text":"3 weeks","label":"C"},{"text":"5 weeks","label":"D"},{"text":"8 weeks","label":"E"}]
explanation: Switching from an SSRI to an MAOI requires a washout period to prevent serotonin syndrome. For most SSRIs, 2 weeks (5 half-lives) is sufficient. However, fluoxetine has a long half-life (4-6 days) and an active metabolite (norfluoxetine) with a half-life of 4-16 days, requiring at least 5 weeks washout. Similarly, when switching FROM an MAOI TO any serotonergic agent, a 2-week washout is required. This patient cannot start phenelzine for at least 5 weeks after stopping fluoxetine.

stem:
An 82-year-old woman with mild dementia is admitted to the hospital for hip fracture repair. Post-operatively, she is agitated and having difficulty sleeping. Her daughter asks if she can receive "something to help her relax and sleep," mentioning her mother took lorazepam in the past.

Why should benzodiazepines be avoided in this patient?
options: [{"text":"Benzodiazepines are contraindicated after surgery","label":"A"},{"text":"Risk of falls, cognitive impairment, and paradoxical agitation in elderly","label":"B"},{"text":"Benzodiazepines are ineffective for insomnia","label":"C"},{"text":"Lorazepam is only available in IV formulation","label":"D"},{"text":"Benzodiazepines cause serotonin syndrome in elderly","label":"E"}]
explanation: Benzodiazepines are included on the Beers Criteria of potentially inappropriate medications in older adults. In the elderly, they increase risk of: falls and hip fractures, cognitive impairment, confusion and delirium (especially in those with baseline dementia), paradoxical agitation/disinhibition, over-sedation, and respiratory depression. This patient with dementia and recent hip fracture is at particularly high risk. Alternatives for insomnia include sleep hygiene, melatonin, or low-dose trazodone. Non-pharmacologic delirium prevention is preferred.

stem:
A 32-year-old woman has a Pap smear showing atypical squamous cells of undetermined significance (ASC-US) with positive high-risk HPV co-testing. She had a normal Pap with negative HPV 3 years ago. She has no history of abnormal Paps or cervical procedures.

What is the most appropriate next step?
options: [{"text":"Repeat co-testing in 1 year","label":"A"},{"text":"Colposcopy","label":"B"},{"text":"Repeat cytology alone in 6 months","label":"C"},{"text":"HPV genotyping for types 16/18","label":"D"},{"text":"Repeat co-testing in 3 years","label":"E"}]
explanation: Management of abnormal cervical cytology depends on the Pap result AND HPV status: Cytology HPV Status Management ASC-US HPV positive Colposcopy ASC-US HPV negative Repeat co-testing in 3 years ASC-US HPV unknown Reflex HPV testing or repeat cytology in 1 year LSIL Any Colposcopy (regardless of HPV) ASC-H Any Colposcopy HSIL Any Colposcopy (consider immediate LEEP) This patient: • ASC-US + HPV positive = Colposcopy indicated The combination of abnormal cytology and high-risk HPV significantly increases the risk of underlying CIN2+ compared to either finding alone. HPV 16/18 genotyping is used in some algorithms when Pap is normal with positive HPV, not for ASC-US/HPV+. Why other options are wrong: • A: One-year follow-up is for lower-risk scenarios (e.g., ASC-US with HPV unknown) • C: Cytology alone at 6 months was the old algorithm before HPV co-testing • D: Genotyping for 16/18 is used when cytology is negative but HPV is positive (to decide between 1-year repeat vs colposcopy) • E: Three-year repeat is for ASC-US with negative HPV (very low risk) High-Yield Takeaway: ASC-US + HPV positive = colposcopy. ASC-US + HPV negative = repeat co-testing in 3 years. LSIL or higher = colposcopy regardless of HPV status.

stem:
A 68-year-old man with atrial fibrillation (non-adherent with anticoagulation) presents with acute onset of severe left leg pain and numbness 4 hours ago. Exam shows a cold, pale leg with no palpable pulses below the femoral artery. The foot is mottled. He has minimal motor function (cannot wiggle toes) and absent sensation below the ankle.

What is the most appropriate management?
options: [{"text":"Systemic anticoagulation and vascular surgery consultation within 24 hours","label":"A"},{"text":"Immediate thrombolysis via catheter-directed approach","label":"B"},{"text":"Emergent surgical embolectomy","label":"C"},{"text":"CT angiography to localize obstruction before treatment","label":"D"},{"text":"Amputation given the severity of ischemia","label":"E"}]
explanation: Acute limb ischemia (ALI) classification guides management urgency: Rutherford Classification: Class Motor Sensory Doppler Viability Management I Intact Intact Audible Viable Anticoagulation; elective revascularization IIA Intact Mild loss Inaudible Marginally threatened Urgent revascularization (within hours) IIB Mild-moderate loss More than toes Inaudible Immediately threatened Emergent revascularization III Profound paralysis Anesthetic None Irreversible Amputation This patient: • 4-hour duration • Motor loss (cannot wiggle toes) • Sensory loss to ankle • Mottled foot = Rutherford IIB (immediately threatened limb) Treatment for Class IIB: • Emergent revascularization — surgical embolectomy preferred for embolic etiology (AFib source) • Time is muscle — delays lead to irreversible damage and progression to Class III • Heparin anticoagulation should be given immediately while preparing for OR Embolectomy vs thrombolysis: • Embolectomy: Preferred for IIB, embolic source, <14 days duration; faster • Thrombolysis: Better for thrombotic occlusion of native vessel/graft; Class I–IIA; requires 12–24 hours to work Why other options are wrong: • A: Class IIB requires emergent intervention, not next-day consultation • B: Thrombolysis too slow for immediately threatened limb; risk of irreversible damage during infusion • D: Imaging delays revascularization; clinical exam sufficient to diagnose ALI and proceed • E: Limb is still potentially salvageable (motor function present, <6 hours); amputation only for Class III High-Yield Takeaway: Acute limb ischemia with motor deficit (Rutherford IIB) = emergent surgical revascularization. Thrombolysis is too slow for immediately threatened limbs. Class III (profound paralysis, anesthesia, rigor) = amputation. Psychiatry

stem:
A 12-year-old girl is evaluated for scoliosis noted on school screening. She has no back pain. She had menarche 6 months ago. Spine radiograph shows a 28-degree right thoracic curve. Risser sign is 1.

What is the most appropriate management?
options: [{"text":"Observation with repeat imaging in 6–12 months","label":"A"},{"text":"Full-time bracing (23 hours/day)","label":"B"},{"text":"Physical therapy and core strengthening","label":"C"},{"text":"Referral for surgical consultation","label":"D"},{"text":"Nighttime-only bracing","label":"E"}]
explanation: Adolescent idiopathic scoliosis (AIS) management depends on curve magnitude and skeletal maturity: Skeletal maturity indicators: • Risser sign: 0–1 = immature (significant growth remaining); 4–5 = mature • Menarche: Growth typically continues 2 years post-menarche • Triradiate cartilage: Open = immature Management algorithm: Curve Risser 0–2 (Immature) Risser 3+ (Mature) <25° Observe q4-6 months Observe annually 25–40° Brace (18–23 hr/day) Observe >40–50° Surgical evaluation Observe or surgery if progressing This patient: • 28° curve (within bracing range 25–40°) • Risser 1 (immature, significant growth remaining) • 6 months post-menarche (1.5 years of growth remaining) Bracing efficacy (BrAIST trial): • Full-time bracing (average 18+ hours/day) significantly reduces progression to surgical threshold • Number needed to treat = 3 Why other options are wrong: • A: Observation alone inappropriate for skeletally immature patient with curve in bracing range—high progression risk • C: Physical therapy does not prevent curve progression; may improve symptoms but not curvature • D: Surgical threshold typically >45–50°; this curve doesn't meet criteria • E: Nighttime-only bracing less effective; full-time recommended for curves approaching 30° High-Yield Takeaway: AIS + Cobb angle 25–40° + Risser 0–2 (immature) = full-time bracing. Observation for curves <25° or skeletally mature patients. Surgery for curves >45–50°.

stem:
A 62-year-old man underwent low anterior resection for rectal cancer 12 days ago. He was progressing well until today when he developed fever (38.6°C), tachycardia, and diffuse abdominal tenderness with guarding. CT abdomen/pelvis shows extraluminal air and fluid collection adjacent to the colorectal anastomosis with free fluid in the pelvis.

What is the most appropriate management?
options: [{"text":"Broad-spectrum antibiotics and observation","label":"A"},{"text":"CT-guided percutaneous drainage","label":"B"},{"text":"Operative intervention with likely fecal diversion","label":"C"},{"text":"Endoscopic stent placement across the anastomosis","label":"D"},{"text":"Total parenteral nutrition and bowel rest for 2 weeks","label":"E"}]
explanation: Anastomotic leak management depends on timing, patient stability, and leak characteristics: Leak classification: Timing Characteristics Management Early (<7 days) Often technical failure; fresh tissues allow primary repair Reoperation: revision of anastomosis or diversion Timing Characteristics Management Late (7–14 days) Tissues friable; primary repair usually not possible Diversion (stoma) ± drainage; avoid anastomotic revision Contained leak No peritonitis, walled-off collection Percutaneous drainage + antibiotics Uncontained leak Peritonitis, sepsis, free spillage Operative intervention This patient: • Post-operative day 12 (late leak) • Peritonitis (diffuse tenderness, guarding) • Free fluid in pelvis (uncontained) • CT shows extraluminal air at anastomosis Surgical approach for late uncontained leak: 1. Exploratory laparotomy 2. Washout of peritoneal cavity 3. Fecal diversion (end colostomy, Hartmann procedure, or proximal diverting loop ileostomy) 4. ± Drain placement 5. Leave anastomosis alone (tissues too friable for repair) Why other options are wrong: • A: Peritonitis requires source control; antibiotics alone inadequate • B: Percutaneous drainage appropriate for contained collections without peritonitis; this leak is uncontained with peritonitis • D: Endoscopic stenting used for small, contained leaks; cannot address peritonitis • E: NPO and TPN supportive but doesn't address sepsis/peritonitis requiring source control High-Yield Takeaway: Anastomotic leak with peritonitis = operative intervention with fecal diversion. Late leaks (>7 days) preclude primary repair—divert proximally and allow to heal.

stem:
A 29-year-old woman at 8 weeks gestation has a history of severe recurrent major depressive disorder with two prior hospitalizations for suicidal ideation. She has been stable on sertraline 150mg daily for 3 years. She asks whether she should stop her medication to protect her baby.

What is the most appropriate recommendation?
options: [{"text":"Discontinue sertraline; depression can be managed with psychotherapy during pregnancy","label":"A"},{"text":"Continue sertraline at current dose with close monitoring","label":"B"},{"text":"Switch to bupropion, which has the lowest teratogenic risk","label":"C"},{"text":"Taper sertraline and discontinue by second trimester","label":"D"},{"text":"Discontinue sertraline and start fluoxetine, which has more safety data","label":"E"}]
explanation: Antidepressant use in pregnancy requires weighing fetal risks against maternal relapse risk: SSRI risks in pregnancy: • First trimester: Small absolute increase in cardiac defects (paroxetine > others); overall risk remains low (~1%) • Third trimester: Neonatal adaptation syndrome (30%) — jitteriness, respiratory distress; transient, not life- threatening • No increased risk of major malformations with sertraline or fluoxetine Maternal depression risks (untreated): • Relapse rate: 60–70% if antidepressant discontinued during pregnancy • Poor prenatal care, substance use, poor nutrition • Preterm birth, low birth weight • Postpartum depression • Suicide Risk-benefit analysis: Scenario Recommendation Mild depression, single episode Consider taper; psychotherapy Severe/recurrent depression, prior hospitalization Continue antidepressant Currently stable for years Continuation preferred; high relapse risk with discontinuation This patient: • Severe recurrent MDD with hospitalizations • Stable on sertraline (favorable safety profile) • High relapse risk if discontinued The benefit of continued treatment clearly outweighs the small, uncertain fetal risks. Why other options are wrong: • A: Psychotherapy alone inadequate for severe recurrent MDD; high relapse risk • C: No evidence bupropion is safer; switching stable medication introduces unnecessary risk • D: Tapering in stable patient with severe history risks relapse • E: Fluoxetine and sertraline have similar safety data; no benefit to switching stable medication High-Yield Takeaway: Severe/recurrent depression stable on SSRI → continue antidepressant throughout pregnancy. Untreated maternal depression poses greater risk than SSRIs (especially sertraline, fluoxetine). Discontinuation leads to 60–70% relapse.

stem:
A 32-year-old man with schizophrenia has persistent auditory hallucinations and disorganized thinking despite adequate trials of risperidone (6mg x 8 weeks), olanzapine (20mg x 10 weeks), and aripiprazole (30mg x 8 weeks) with confirmed adherence. He has no history of seizures. His symptoms significantly impair his daily functioning.

What is the most appropriate next step in management?
options: [{"text":"Add a second antipsychotic to current regimen","label":"A"},{"text":"Initiate clozapine","label":"B"},{"text":"Trial another atypical antipsychotic (ziprasidone)","label":"C"},{"text":"Add valproate for mood stabilization","label":"D"},{"text":"Initiate long-acting injectable antipsychotic","label":"E"}]
explanation: Treatment-resistant schizophrenia (TRS) is defined as failure of ≥2 adequate antipsychotic trials (including at least one atypical). Clozapine is the ONLY antipsychotic with proven efficacy for TRS: Feature Clozapine Indication Treatment-resistant schizophrenia (failed ≥2 antipsychotics) Efficacy 30–60% response rate in TRS (no other agent approaches this) Unique benefits Reduces suicidality in schizophrenia (FDA indication); may reduce violence Monitoring requirement Weekly → biweekly → monthly ANC due to agranulocytosis risk (1%) Other side effects Metabolic syndrome, seizures (dose-related), myocarditis, constipation/ileus This patient: • Failed 3 adequate antipsychotic trials with documented adherence • Meets definition of TRS • No seizure history (would require extra caution but not contraindication) Key point: There is no evidence that switching between non-clozapine antipsychotics improves outcomes after 2 failures. Clozapine has unique efficacy that other antipsychotics lack. Why other options are wrong: • A: Antipsychotic polypharmacy lacks evidence; adds side effects without proven benefit • C: Fourth trial of non-clozapine antipsychotic delays effective treatment; low likelihood of response • D: Valproate augmentation has minimal evidence in schizophrenia without mood component • E: LAI improves adherence but this patient has confirmed adherence; efficacy still limited by TRS High-Yield Takeaway: Treatment-resistant schizophrenia (failed ≥2 antipsychotic trials) → clozapine is the only evidence-based option. Do not delay with additional non-clozapine trials. Requires ANC monitoring for agranulocytosis.

stem:
A 62-year-old woman has been taking alprazolam 1mg three times daily for generalized anxiety disorder for 8 years, prescribed by her previous physician. She wants to discontinue due to cognitive concerns. She has no history of seizures or complicated withdrawal.

What is the most appropriate tapering approach?
options: [{"text":"Discontinue alprazolam and start buspirone for anxiety coverage","label":"A"},{"text":"Reduce alprazolam dose by 25% every 2 weeks until discontinued","label":"B"},{"text":"Convert to equivalent dose of long-acting benzodiazepine, then taper gradually over months","label":"C"},{"text":"Reduce alprazolam by 50% immediately, then taper the remainder over 4 weeks","label":"D"},{"text":"Refer to inpatient detoxification for medically supervised withdrawal","label":"E"}]
explanation: Benzodiazepine discontinuation requires careful tapering to prevent withdrawal seizures and severe symptoms: Risk factors for complicated withdrawal: • Long duration of use (this patient: 8 years — high risk) • High doses • Short-acting agents (alprazolam — high risk) • History of seizures or complicated withdrawal • Concurrent alcohol use Tapering protocol for long-term, short-acting benzodiazepine: Step Action 1 Convert to long-acting benzodiazepine (diazepam or clonazepam) 2 Gradual taper over weeks to months (longer duration = slower taper) Step Action 3 Typical reduction: 10–25% every 1–2 weeks initially; slower near the end 4 Total taper: 6–12 months for long-term users Why convert to long-acting agent? • Short-acting agents (alprazolam, lorazepam) cause interdose withdrawal and wide plasma fluctuations • Long-acting agents (diazepam, clonazepam) provide stable plasma levels, smoother taper • Conversion: Alprazolam 1mg ≈ Diazepam 10–20mg ≈ Clonazepam 0.5mg Why other options are wrong: • A: Abrupt discontinuation after 8 years risks severe withdrawal including seizures; buspirone doesn't prevent BZD withdrawal • B: Tapering alprazolam directly is difficult due to short half-life and interdose fluctuations • D: 50% immediate reduction too aggressive; risks withdrawal symptoms • E: Outpatient taper is safe for uncomplicated cases; inpatient reserved for high-dose, complicated history, or poor social support High-Yield Takeaway: Long-term benzodiazepine discontinuation: convert short-acting (alprazolam) to long-acting (diazepam/clonazepam), then taper gradually over months. Abrupt discontinuation risks seizures.

stem:
A 38-year-old woman with bipolar I disorder presents with a 3-week depressive episode characterized by hypersomnia, low energy, anhedonia, and passive suicidal ideation. Her last manic episode was 2 years ago on no medications; she has been stable on lithium (level 0.8 mEq/L) since then. She has no history of rapid cycling.

What is the most appropriate pharmacologic addition for her depressive episode?
options: [{"text":"Sertraline","label":"A"},{"text":"Quetiapine","label":"B"},{"text":"Lamotrigine","label":"C"},{"text":"Aripiprazole","label":"D"},{"text":"Bupropion","label":"E"}]
explanation: Bipolar depression treatment differs fundamentally from unipolar depression: FDA-approved for bipolar depression: 1. Quetiapine (monotherapy) 2. Lurasidone (monotherapy or adjunct to lithium/valproate) 3. Olanzapine-fluoxetine combination (Symbyax) 4. Cariprazine (monotherapy) Treatment hierarchy for bipolar depression: Agent Role Notes Quetiapine First-line Strong evidence; sedating (good for insomnia); metabolic effects Lurasidone First-line Strong evidence; less sedating; take with food Lamotrigine Preventive/adjunct Better at preventing than treating acute depression; slow titration required Antidepressants Controversial Risk of switch to mania; avoid monotherapy; may consider with mood stabilizer This patient: • Acute bipolar depressive episode • Already on lithium (mood stabilizer in place) • Needs acute treatment for depression Quetiapine (or lurasidone) added to lithium is evidence-based for acute bipolar depression. Why other options are wrong: • A: SSRIs risk manic switch; controversial even as adjunct; not first-line • C: Lamotrigine requires 6-week titration (risk of SJS with rapid increase); better for maintenance than acute treatment • D: Aripiprazole is FDA-approved for bipolar mania and maintenance, not depression • E: Bupropion has lowest switch risk among antidepressants but is not FDA-approved and lacks strong evidence for bipolar depression High-Yield Takeaway: Acute bipolar depression → quetiapine or lurasidone (FDA-approved). Lamotrigine is for maintenance/prevention. Avoid antidepressant monotherapy due to switch risk.

stem:
A 52-year-old woman has a newly diagnosed 2.5-cm invasive ductal carcinoma in the upper outer quadrant of her right breast. MRI shows a second suspicious 1.5-cm lesion in the lower inner quadrant of the same breast, confirmed as invasive carcinoma on biopsy. The lesions are 7 cm apart. She has C-cup breasts and strongly desires breast conservation if oncologically appropriate.

What is the most appropriate surgical recommendation?
options: [{"text":"Lumpectomy of both lesions with radiation","label":"A"},{"text":"Neoadjuvant chemotherapy followed by reassessment","label":"B"},{"text":"Mastectomy","label":"C"},{"text":"Oncoplastic lumpectomy with bilateral reduction mammoplasty","label":"D"},{"text":"Lumpectomy of larger lesion only","label":"E"}]
explanation: Breast-conserving surgery (BCS) vs mastectomy decision depends on several factors: Contraindications to breast-conserving surgery: Factor Rationale Multicentric disease Tumors in different quadrants (>5 cm apart) Large tumor-to-breast ratio Cannot achieve negative margins with acceptable cosmesis Inability to achieve negative margins After reasonable re-excisions Prior breast radiation Cannot reirradiate Inflammatory breast cancer Requires mastectomy Diffuse suspicious microcalcifications Suggests extensive DCIS Pregnancy (relative) Radiation contraindicated; can delay if late pregnancy This patient: • Two invasive carcinomas in different quadrants (upper outer + lower inner) • 7 cm apart = multicentric disease • Multicentric disease = contraindication to BCS Why multicentric disease requires mastectomy: • BCS requires single surgical field with radiation to tumor bed • Multiple widely separated tumors cannot be encompassed by standard BCS + radiation • Higher local recurrence rates with BCS for multicentric disease Why other options are wrong: • A: Multiple lumpectomies for multicentric disease associated with high local recurrence; not standard of care • B: Neoadjuvant chemotherapy may shrink tumors but doesn't change multicentric anatomy; still requires mastectomy • D: Oncoplastic techniques don't overcome multicentricity; still separate tumor beds • E: Leaving untreated cancer is not appropriate High-Yield Takeaway: Multicentric breast cancer (tumors in different quadrants >5 cm apart) is a contraindication to breast-conserving surgery → mastectomy required. Multifocal (same quadrant) may still permit BCS.

stem:
A 30-year-old G3P0020 at 18 weeks presents for routine ultrasound. Her obstetric history includes two second- trimester losses at 19 and 21 weeks—both presented with painless cervical dilation. Current transvaginal ultrasound shows cervical length of 2.8 cm with closed internal os. She has had no contractions, bleeding, or ROM.

What is the most appropriate management?
options: [{"text":"Immediate cerclage placement based on obstetric history","label":"A"},{"text":"Serial cervical length monitoring; cerclage if length <25mm","label":"B"},{"text":"Vaginal progesterone supplementation only","label":"C"},{"text":"Reassurance; cervical length is normal","label":"D"},{"text":"Cerclage now plus vaginal progesterone","label":"E"}]
explanation: Cerclage indications fall into three categories: Type Criteria Timing History-indicated ≥3 prior second-trimester losses OR prior preterm birth with cervical insufficiency 12–14 weeks (before cervical changes) Ultrasound-indicated Prior spontaneous PTB <34wk + current short cervix (<25mm) before 24wk When cervix shortens Rescue (physical exam– indicated) Dilated cervix with visible membranes Emergency This patient: • 2 prior second-trimester losses (classic cervical insufficiency history) • Does NOT meet history-indicated threshold (requires ≥3 losses or 1 loss with documented insufficiency) • Current cervix is 2.8 cm = normal length Management for patient with 1–2 prior losses suggestive of insufficiency but not meeting history-indicated criteria: • Serial transvaginal cervical length surveillance q2 weeks starting at 16 weeks • Ultrasound-indicated cerclage if cervix shortens to <25mm before 24 weeks • Vaginal progesterone if short cervix develops (can be used with or instead of cerclage) Why other options are wrong: • A: History-indicated cerclage requires ≥3 losses; this patient has 2 • C: Progesterone alone is reasonable for short cervix but cervix is currently normal; surveillance is priority • D: Given her history, she requires serial monitoring even with normal current length • E: No indication for cerclage with current cervical length of 28mm High-Yield Takeaway: History-indicated cerclage: ≥3 prior second-trimester losses. For 1–2 losses: serial cervical length monitoring with ultrasound-indicated cerclage if cervix shortens to <25mm before 24 weeks.

stem:
An 18-month-old boy is evaluated for developmental concerns. He is not yet walking independently (pulls to stand), has no words (babbles), and does not point to request or show objects. He has no dysmorphic features. He was born at term with uncomplicated delivery. Hearing screen at birth was passed. There is no family history of developmental disorders. Physical exam including head circumference is normal.

What is the most appropriate initial diagnostic test?
options: [{"text":"Brain MRI","label":"A"},{"text":"Chromosomal microarray","label":"B"},{"text":"Fragile X testing","label":"C"},{"text":"Metabolic panel including lactate, ammonia, and urine organic acids","label":"D"},{"text":"Electroencephalogram","label":"E"}]
explanation: Global developmental delay (GDD) evaluation follows a tiered approach based on diagnostic yield: Definition of GDD: Significant delay (<2 SD) in ≥2 developmental domains in child <5 years Tiered workup: Tier Test Yield When to Order 1 Chromosomal microarray (CMA) 15–20% First-line for unexplained GDD 1 Fragile X (males) 2–3% First-line for males with GDD 2 Brain MRI 30% abnormal, but rarely changes management if CMA/FX negative Abnormal neuro exam, microcephaly, regression, seizures 2 Metabolic studies <1% in non-syndromic GDD Regression, episodic symptoms, consanguinity, organomegaly 3 Whole exome sequencing Variable After CMA/FX negative This patient: • Global developmental delay (motor, language, social) • No dysmorphic features, normal exam • No regression or episodic symptoms Chromosomal microarray is first-line because: • Highest diagnostic yield (~15–20%) for unexplained GDD • Detects copy number variants (deletions, duplications) missed by karyotype • Non-invasive (blood test) • Results guide prognosis and recurrence risk counseling Why other options are wrong: • A: MRI often abnormal but rarely diagnostic in non-syndromic GDD without focal findings; pursue after genetic testing • C: Fragile X testing appropriate for males but CMA should be sent simultaneously as it has higher overall yield • D: Metabolic workup has very low yield (<1%) without red flags (regression, consanguinity, organomegaly, acidosis) • E: EEG indicated for seizures or regression (Landau-Kleffner); not routine for GDD High-Yield Takeaway: Unexplained global developmental delay → chromosomal microarray first (15–20% yield). Add Fragile X testing for males. MRI and metabolic studies are second-tier for those with additional red flags.

stem:
A 19-year-old woman with anorexia nervosa is brought by her parents for worsening restriction. She reports eating ~400 calories daily for the past month. BMI is 15.2 kg/m². Vitals: HR 42, BP 78/50, temperature 35.6°C. Labs: potassium 2.9 mEq/L, glucose 58 mg/dL, phosphorus 2.2 mg/dL. ECG shows sinus bradycardia with prolonged QTc (480 ms).

What is the most appropriate disposition?
options: [{"text":"Intensive outpatient program with daily monitoring","label":"A"},{"text":"Psychiatric hospitalization for supervised refeeding","label":"B"},{"text":"Medical hospitalization for cardiac and metabolic stabilization","label":"C"},{"text":"Residential eating disorder treatment facility","label":"D"},{"text":"Outpatient follow-up with dietitian within 1 week","label":"E"}]
explanation: Anorexia nervosa hospitalization requires understanding medical vs psychiatric criteria: Medical hospitalization criteria (any ONE): Category Threshold Heart rate <50 bpm (this patient: 42) Blood pressure <80/50 or orthostatic (this patient: 78/50) Potassium <3.0 mEq/L (this patient: 2.9) Glucose <60 mg/dL (this patient: 58) Phosphorus <2.5 mg/dL (this patient: 2.2) QTc >450–460 ms (this patient: 480) Temperature <36°C (this patient: 35.6) BMI <14–15 kg/m² (varies by guideline) This patient has MULTIPLE medical hospitalization criteria: • HR 42 ✓ • BP 78/50 ✓ • K+ 2.9 ✓ • Glucose 58 ✓ • Phos 2.2 ✓ • QTc 480 ms ✓ • Temp 35.6°C ✓ Medical vs psychiatric hospitalization: • Medical floor: Cardiac monitoring, electrolyte repletion, supervised refeeding with refeeding syndrome precautions • Psychiatric unit: After medical stabilization; for patients who are medically stable but refuse treatment or have severe psychiatric comorbidity Why other options are wrong: • A: Intensive outpatient cannot manage medical instability • B: Psychiatric hospitalization is appropriate AFTER medical stabilization; this patient needs cardiac monitoring • D: Residential programs are for stable patients requiring long-term behavioral treatment • E: Medical instability precludes outpatient management High-Yield Takeaway: Anorexia nervosa with bradycardia (<50), hypotension, electrolyte abnormalities, or ECG changes = medical hospitalization first. Psychiatric hospitalization follows medical stabilization. BATCH 3 — QUESTION GENERATION COMPLETE Summary: • Neurology: 8 questions • OB/GYN: 8 questions • Pediatrics: 6 questions • Surgery: 7 questions • Psychiatry: 7 questions Total: 36 questions

stem:
A 29-year-old nulligravid woman presents with 2 years of progressive dysmenorrhea, deep dyspareunia, and dyschezia during menses. She is not currently trying to conceive but hopes to have children within 2–3 years. Pelvic exam reveals a fixed, retroverted uterus with nodularity in the posterior cul-de-sac. Transvaginal ultrasound shows a 3 cm left ovarian endometrioma.

What is the most appropriate management approach?
options: [{"text":"Combined oral contraceptives for symptom suppression","label":"A"},{"text":"GnRH agonist therapy for 6 months","label":"B"},{"text":"Diagnostic laparoscopy with excision of endometriosis","label":"C"},{"text":"Expectant management until she is ready to conceive","label":"D"},{"text":"Refer for in vitro fertilization","label":"E"}]
explanation: Endometriosis management depends on symptom severity, fertility goals, and disease extent: Medical therapy indications: • Suspected endometriosis without endometrioma or deep infiltrating disease • Pain management when fertility not immediately desired • Post-surgical suppression Surgical therapy indications: • Endometrioma >3 cm — May impact ovarian reserve; cystectomy improves fertility and symptoms • Deep infiltrating endometriosis — Nodularity in cul-de-sac, rectovaginal involvement • Failed medical management • Definitive diagnosis needed • Fertility optimization — Surgery improves spontaneous conception rates in mild-moderate disease This patient: • Moderate-severe symptoms • Endometrioma (3 cm) • Deep infiltrating disease (cul-de-sac nodularity, dyschezia) • Desires future fertility Surgical excision is preferred because: 1. Endometrioma and deep disease respond poorly to medical therapy alone 2. Surgery improves fertility outcomes before conception attempts 3. Medical therapy only suppresses, doesn't treat; symptoms recur after stopping Why other options are wrong: • A: COCs may help pain but don't treat endometrioma or deep disease; delay definitive treatment • B: GnRH agonists cause hypoestrogenic side effects, don't shrink endometriomas significantly, and symptoms recur after stopping • D: Disease progression may worsen fertility; proactive treatment indicated • E: IVF is for conception, not treatment of symptomatic endometriosis; she's not trying to conceive yet High-Yield Takeaway: Endometrioma ≥3 cm or deep infiltrating endometriosis (especially with future fertility goals) → surgical excision. Medical therapy is for symptom suppression in mild disease or post-surgical maintenance.

stem:
A 10-month-old boy is evaluated for poor weight gain. His weight has dropped from the 25th percentile at 4 months to the 3rd percentile now, while length and head circumference remain at the 25th percentile. He was breastfed exclusively until 6 months, then started solids. Mother reports he is a "picky eater" and mealtimes are stressful. He has no vomiting, diarrhea, or respiratory symptoms. He reaches appropriately for food and has normal activity level. Physical exam is unremarkable except for decreased subcutaneous fat.

What is the most likely etiology of this patient's failure to thrive?
options: [{"text":"Celiac disease","label":"A"},{"text":"Cystic fibrosis","label":"B"},{"text":"Inadequate caloric intake","label":"C"},{"text":"Growth hormone deficiency","label":"D"},{"text":"Congenital heart disease","label":"E"}]
