explanation: Failure to thrive (FTT) evaluation hinges on distinguishing organic from nonorganic (psychosocial/nutritional) causes: Pattern recognition: Feature Organic FTT Nonorganic FTT Weight, length, HC All affected (or length/HC first) Weight affected first, length/HC preserved Symptoms Vomiting, diarrhea, respiratory, dysmorphism Usually absent Feeding behavior May have oral aversion, dysphagia Chaotic mealtimes, food refusal Activity May be decreased Normal Catch-up with adequate calories May not catch up Rapid catch-up This patient: • Weight declined while length/HC preserved → classic for inadequate intake • No GI symptoms (argues against celiac, CF) • Normal activity and development • Stressful mealtimes, "picky eater" → feeding behavior issues • Transition from breastfeeding to solids at 6 months correlates with weight decline Management of suspected inadequate intake: 1. Detailed feeding history (volume, frequency, preparation of formula, introduction of solids) 2. Observed feeding session 3. Caloric prescription and close follow-up 4. If rapid catch-up with adequate calories → confirms diagnosis Why other options are wrong: • A: Celiac causes diarrhea, abdominal distension; typically presents after gluten introduction with malabsorption symptoms • B: CF causes malabsorption with steatorrhea, respiratory symptoms; this child has neither • D: GH deficiency affects length primarily, with relatively preserved weight; opposite pattern • E: CHD causes poor feeding with diaphoresis, tachypnea, hepatomegaly; exam is unremarkable High-Yield Takeaway: FTT with weight loss but preserved length/head circumference and no organic symptoms = inadequate caloric intake until proven otherwise. Detailed feeding history and observed feeding are diagnostic.

stem:
A 20-month-old girl is brought to the ED after a 2-minute generalized tonic-clonic seizure during a febrile illness (T 39.2°C). She returned to baseline within 20 minutes. This is her second simple febrile seizure—her first occurred at 13 months. Neurologic exam is normal. Family history is notable for the patient's mother having febrile seizures as a child.

What is the most appropriate counseling regarding seizure prophylaxis?
options: [{"text":"Start daily levetiracetam to prevent recurrence","label":"A"},{"text":"Prescribe rectal diazepam for use during future febrile illnesses","label":"B"},{"text":"Reassure that prophylaxis is not indicated for simple febrile seizures","label":"C"},{"text":"Start daily phenobarbital given recurrent seizures","label":"D"},{"text":"Obtain EEG before deciding on prophylaxis","label":"E"}]
explanation: Simple febrile seizures are benign and do NOT require prophylactic antiepileptic medication, even with recurrence. Simple febrile seizure criteria: • Age 6 months to 5 years • Generalized seizure • Duration <15 minutes • Single seizure in 24 hours • Normal neurologic exam afterward • No prior afebrile seizures Key points for counseling: • Recurrence risk: ~30% after first seizure; higher with younger age, lower temperature at seizure, family history, short duration of fever before seizure • Epilepsy risk: NOT increased by simple febrile seizures (~1%, same as general population) • Prophylaxis: NOT recommended—AEDs have significant side effects (sedation, behavioral changes, hepatotoxicity) that outweigh benefit for a benign condition • Antipyretics: Do NOT prevent febrile seizures (fever is a marker, not the cause) Options for high-anxiety families (not standard of care): • Intermittent rectal or nasal diazepam at fever onset—reduces recurrence but has sedation risks; reserved for parental anxiety, not medical necessity Why other options are wrong: • A: Daily AEDs not indicated for simple febrile seizures regardless of recurrence • B: Intermittent diazepam is an option for parental anxiety but NOT standard recommendation; doesn't change long-term outcome • D: Phenobarbital has significant cognitive/behavioral side effects; risks far outweigh benefits • E: EEG not indicated for simple febrile seizures; findings don't change management and may cause unnecessary concern High-Yield Takeaway: Simple febrile seizures (even recurrent) do not require prophylaxis—reassure parents of benign prognosis. Daily AEDs and intermittent antipyretics do NOT prevent recurrence and carry risks exceeding benefits.

stem:
A 33-year-old G1P0 at 30 weeks with gestational diabetes has been on dietary modification for 2 weeks. Her fasting glucose logs show values of 98, 102, 95, 105, and 99 mg/dL over the past week. Two-hour postprandial values are consistently 115–125 mg/dL. She has gained 2 pounds since diagnosis. Fetal growth ultrasound is scheduled for 32 weeks.

What is the most appropriate next step in management?
options: [{"text":"Continue diet therapy; recheck in 2 weeks","label":"A"},{"text":"Add metformin for fasting hyperglycemia","label":"B"},{"text":"Initiate nighttime NPH insulin","label":"C"},{"text":"Initiate rapid-acting insulin with meals","label":"D"},{"text":"Increase dietary carbohydrate restriction","label":"E"}]
explanation: GDM glucose targets (Fifth International Workshop): • Fasting: <95 mg/dL (some use <90) • 1-hour postprandial: <140 mg/dL • 2-hour postprandial: <120 mg/dL This patient's values: • Fasting: 95–105 → Consistently elevated (4/5 values exceed 95) • Postprandial: 115–125 → At or slightly above 2-hour target When to escalate from diet to pharmacotherapy: • Fasting or postprandial targets not achieved after 1–2 weeks of diet/exercise • Majority of values out of range Choosing the agent: • Fasting hyperglycemia → Hepatic glucose production overnight → Nighttime NPH insulin (or long-acting insulin) • Postprandial hyperglycemia → Inadequate insulin response to meals → Rapid-acting insulin with meals or metformin • Both → Combination therapy This patient's primary issue is fasting glucose, so nighttime NPH addresses the pathophysiology (suppresses overnight hepatic gluconeogenesis). Why other options are wrong: • A: Two weeks is adequate diet trial; persistent fasting elevation requires escalation • B: Metformin primarily lowers fasting glucose by reducing hepatic glucose output; however, insulin is first- line in GDM due to more predictable pharmacokinetics and established safety profile • D: Postprandial values are borderline/at target; prandial insulin addresses postprandial, not fasting glucose • E: Further carbohydrate restriction unlikely to address fasting glucose; may be inadequate nutrition High-Yield Takeaway: GDM with elevated fasting glucose despite diet → start nighttime NPH insulin. Elevated postprandial glucose → add prandial rapid-acting insulin or consider metformin (second-line).

stem:
A 28-year-old G1P0 at 10 weeks presents with severe nausea and vomiting for 3 weeks. She has lost 8% of pre- pregnancy weight and has 3+ ketonuria. Vitals: HR 108, BP 138/88. Labs show TSH 0.1 mIU/L, free T4 1.8 ng/dL (slightly elevated). She has not yet had an ultrasound.

What is the most appropriate next step?
options: [{"text":"Start methimazole for gestational hyperthyroidism","label":"A"},{"text":"Obtain pelvic ultrasound before further management","label":"B"},{"text":"Initiate IV fluids and antiemetics; discharge when tolerating oral intake","label":"C"},{"text":"Check serum hCG level to guide imaging decision","label":"D"},{"text":"Obtain TSH receptor antibodies to differentiate Graves disease","label":"E"}]
explanation: Hyperemesis gravidarum with hyperthyroidism in the first trimester requires ruling out gestational trophoblastic disease (GTD), particularly complete molar pregnancy: Features suggesting molar pregnancy: • Hyperemesis — More severe than typical pregnancy (very high hCG) • Gestational hyperthyroidism — hCG cross-reacts with TSH receptor • Hypertension — Preeclampsia before 20 weeks (classic for molar pregnancy) • Uterine size > dates • Vaginal bleeding This patient has a concerning triad: 1. Severe hyperemesis (8% weight loss) 2. Hyperthyroidism (suppressed TSH, elevated T4) 3. Hypertension at 10 weeks — Should NOT occur in normal pregnancy this early Management priority: Pelvic ultrasound to evaluate for: • Viable intrauterine pregnancy • Molar pregnancy ("snowstorm" pattern, no fetal pole) • Size-dates discrepancy Gestational hyperthyroidism (from normal pregnancy) typically doesn't require treatment—it resolves as hCG declines. But molar pregnancy requires suction evacuation and surveillance. Why other options are wrong: • A: Gestational hyperthyroidism doesn't require antithyroid drugs; more importantly, must rule out molar pregnancy first • C: Supportive care is appropriate for hyperemesis but doesn't address the concerning hypertension/hyperthyroidism combination • D: While very high hCG suggests molar pregnancy, ultrasound is the definitive diagnostic test • E: TSH receptor antibodies distinguish Graves from gestational hyperthyroidism, but the immediate concern is ruling out GTD High-Yield Takeaway: Hyperemesis + hyperthyroidism + early hypertension (before 20 weeks) = suspect molar pregnancy → obtain pelvic ultrasound immediately.

stem:
A 32-year-old woman with BMI 38 and idiopathic intracranial hypertension has been on maximum-dose acetazolamide (2g/day) for 4 months with dietary counseling. She reports persistent daily headaches. Ophthalmology exam shows stable moderate papilledema with visual field testing demonstrating enlarged blind spots and early peripheral field constriction—worse than 2 months ago. LP shows opening pressure of 38 cmH2O.

What is the most appropriate next step in management?
options: [{"text":"Add topiramate for adjunctive ICP lowering","label":"A"},{"text":"Continue current management and recheck in 2 months","label":"B"},{"text":"Refer for optic nerve sheath fenestration or CSF shunting","label":"C"},{"text":"Refer for bariatric surgery evaluation","label":"D"},{"text":"Perform serial therapeutic lumbar punctures","label":"E"}]
explanation: IIH management follows a stepwise approach with vision preservation as the primary goal: Step 1 — Conservative: • Weight loss (5–10% body weight can resolve IIH) • Acetazolamide (first-line medical therapy, up to 4g/day) Step 2 — Escalation indications: • Progressive visual field loss despite maximum medical therapy • Severe or rapidly progressive papilledema • Intractable headache with visual deterioration Step 3 — Surgical options: • Optic nerve sheath fenestration (ONSF) — Primarily for visual symptoms; less effective for headache • CSF diversion (VP or LP shunt) — For both visual and headache symptoms • Venous sinus stenting — If venous sinus stenosis present This patient has: • Maximum-dose acetazolamide (4 months) • Progressive visual field loss (primary concern) • Persistent elevated ICP Progressive visual field deterioration on maximum medical therapy = surgical intervention required. Why other options are wrong: • A: Topiramate provides modest additional benefit but won't reverse progressive visual loss; delay risks permanent vision damage • B: Vision is worsening—cannot wait; permanent optic nerve damage is irreversible • D: Bariatric surgery is effective long-term but takes months for results; cannot wait with progressive visual loss • E: Serial LPs provide temporary relief but are not definitive; impractical for chronic management and don't prevent ongoing damage High-Yield Takeaway: IIH with progressive visual field loss despite maximum acetazolamide → surgical intervention (ONSF or shunt) is indicated to prevent permanent vision loss. Do not delay for weight loss or additional medical trials. OB/GYN

stem:
A 55-year-old man presents with a 6-cm reducible incisional hernia at his midline laparotomy scar from colectomy 2 years ago. The surgery was for perforated diverticulitis with gross fecal contamination. His BMI is 32. He is otherwise healthy with no current infection.

What is the most appropriate repair approach?
options: [{"text":"Primary suture repair without mesh","label":"A"},{"text":"Repair with synthetic mesh (polypropylene)","label":"B"},{"text":"Repair with biologic mesh","label":"C"},{"text":"Watchful waiting given contamination history","label":"D"},{"text":"Preoperative weight loss then synthetic mesh repair","label":"E"}]
explanation: Incisional hernia repair considerations: Primary suture vs mesh: • Primary suture: Recurrence rate 30–50% • Mesh repair: Recurrence rate 10–15% • Recommendation: Mesh repair for all incisional hernias >2 cm Mesh selection based on wound classification: Wound Class Contamination Mesh Type Clean (Class I) None Synthetic mesh (polypropylene) Clean-contaminated (Class II) GI opened without spillage Synthetic (caution) or biologic Contaminated (Class III) Gross spillage, fresh trauma Biologic preferred Dirty (Class IV) Purulence, fecal contamination Biologic or delayed repair Key point: The wound classification at the TIME OF HERNIA REPAIR determines mesh choice, not the classification at original surgery. This patient: • Current presentation: Clean (Class I) — no infection, no contamination • History of contaminated surgery is irrelevant to current repair • 6-cm hernia → requires mesh (too large for primary repair) • Clean field → synthetic mesh appropriate Synthetic mesh is preferred in clean fields due to: • Lower cost • Better long-term durability • Equivalent infection rates to biologic in clean fields Why other options are wrong: • A: Primary repair has unacceptable recurrence rate for 6-cm hernia • C: Biologic mesh reserved for contaminated/infected fields; more expensive, less durable • D: Watchful waiting risks incarceration, enlargement; repair recommended for symptomatic hernias • E: While weight loss may reduce recurrence, no absolute BMI cutoff for repair; surgery shouldn't be indefinitely delayed High-Yield Takeaway: Incisional hernia mesh selection depends on contamination at time of REPAIR, not original surgery. Clean field → synthetic mesh. Contaminated/infected → biologic mesh.

stem:
A 34-year-old G2P1 at 28 weeks has an ultrasound showing estimated fetal weight at the 5th percentile with normal amniotic fluid. Umbilical artery Doppler shows elevated S/D ratio but positive end-diastolic flow. Fetal anatomy and middle cerebral artery Doppler are normal. She has chronic hypertension on labetalol.

What is the most appropriate surveillance plan?
options: [{"text":"Weekly biophysical profile; deliver at 34 weeks","label":"A"},{"text":"Twice-weekly NST and weekly umbilical artery Doppler; deliver by 37 weeks","label":"B"},{"text":"Daily fetal kick counts; deliver at 39 weeks","label":"C"},{"text":"Continuous inpatient monitoring until delivery","label":"D"},{"text":"Repeat growth ultrasound in 4 weeks; routine prenatal care","label":"E"}]
explanation: IUGR (FGR) management depends on severity, Doppler findings, and gestational age: Classification by umbilical artery (UA) Doppler: UA Doppler Severity Surveillance Delivery Timing Normal Mild FGR Weekly NST; growth q3-4 weeks 38–39 weeks Elevated S/D, positive EDF Moderate Twice-weekly NST; weekly Dopplers 37 weeks Absent EDF (AEDF) Severe Daily NST or admission; steroids if <34wk 33–34 weeks Reversed EDF (REDF) Critical Inpatient; often deliver after steroids 30–32 weeks This fetus has: • EFW 5th percentile = FGR • Elevated S/D ratio but positive end-diastolic flow = moderate severity • 28 weeks = time to optimize with steroids before potential delivery Surveillance: Twice-weekly NST and weekly umbilical artery Doppler to detect progression to AEDF/REDF Delivery: By 37 weeks if stable; earlier if Dopplers worsen Why other options are wrong: • A: Weekly BPP alone is insufficient; UA Doppler progression guides management. Delivery at 34 weeks is premature for this stage • C: Too conservative; misses FGR severity. Kick counts alone inadequate for moderate FGR • D: Inpatient monitoring reserved for AEDF/REDF; not indicated for elevated S/D with positive EDF • E: Growth in 4 weeks is appropriate, but surveillance is insufficient given abnormal Doppler High-Yield Takeaway: FGR with elevated UA S/D ratio but positive EDF → twice-weekly NST + weekly Dopplers; deliver by 37 weeks. Absent or reversed EDF requires more intensive monitoring and earlier delivery.

stem:
A 7-year-old girl with oligoarticular juvenile idiopathic arthritis affecting her left knee has been treated with naproxen and intra-articular corticosteroid injection 8 weeks ago. Despite initial improvement, she now has recurrent swelling and stiffness in the same knee with limited range of motion. Ophthalmologic exam is normal.

What is the most appropriate next step in management?
options: [{"text":"Repeat intra-articular corticosteroid injection","label":"A"},{"text":"Switch to a different NSAID","label":"B"},{"text":"Initiate methotrexate","label":"C"},{"text":"Initiate etanercept (TNF inhibitor)","label":"D"},{"text":"Refer for synovectomy","label":"E"}]
explanation: JIA treatment follows a stepwise approach based on disease subtype and response: Oligoarticular JIA (≤4 joints): Step Therapy 1 NSAIDs + intra-articular corticosteroid (first-line) 2 DMARD (methotrexate) if inadequate response to above 3 Biologic (TNF inhibitor) if DMARD failure Indications to escalate to methotrexate: • Inadequate response to 2 months of NSAIDs • Recurrence after intra-articular injection • Functional limitation • High-risk features (uveitis risk, extended oligoarticular disease) This patient: • Failed NSAID + intra-articular steroid • Recurrent synovitis at 8 weeks (beyond typical 4–6 week response window) • Functional impairment (limited ROM) Methotrexate is the first DMARD used in JIA because: • Extensive efficacy and safety data in children • Weekly dosing (oral or subcutaneous) • Also protects against uveitis (important in oligoarticular JIA) Why other options are wrong: • A: Repeated injections into same joint without systemic therapy risks cartilage damage and is temporizing • B: NSAID switching rarely effective if first NSAID failed; doesn't address disease-modifying need • D: Biologics are reserved for DMARD failures; must trial methotrexate first per guidelines • E: Synovectomy is rarely indicated in modern era of effective medical therapy High-Yield Takeaway: JIA with inadequate response to NSAIDs + intra-articular steroids → initiate methotrexate. Biologics (TNF inhibitors) are second-line after DMARD failure.

stem:
A 58-year-old man with bipolar disorder on lithium for 15 years presents with 1 week of progressive tremor, unsteady gait, and confusion. His family reports he's been vomiting from a "stomach bug" for 5 days and has been taking extra ibuprofen for back pain. He appears lethargic with coarse tremor and ataxia. Labs: lithium level 2.8 mEq/L (therapeutic 0.6–1.2), creatinine 2.1 mg/dL (baseline 1.0), and potassium 5.1 mEq/L.

What is the most appropriate management?
options: [{"text":"IV normal saline hydration alone","label":"A"},{"text":"Hold lithium and observe; repeat level in 12 hours","label":"B"},{"text":"Hemodialysis","label":"C"},{"text":"Activated charcoal","label":"D"},{"text":"IV sodium bicarbonate for alkaline diuresis","label":"E"}]
explanation: Lithium toxicity classification and management: Types of lithium toxicity: Type Mechanism Level vs Symptoms Management Acute (overdose) Ingestion High level, mild symptoms initially GI decontamination; IVF; HD if severe Chronic Decreased clearance Moderate level, SEVERE symptoms HD often needed Acute-on-chronic Both Variable Based on symptoms This patient has CHRONIC lithium toxicity: • Gradual symptom onset (1 week) • Precipitants: Volume depletion (vomiting) + NSAIDs (ibuprofen inhibits renal lithium clearance) • Level 2.8 with severe CNS symptoms (confusion, ataxia) • AKI (Cr 2.1) Key principle: In chronic toxicity, lithium has equilibrated into tissues (especially brain). Even "moderate" levels (2– 2.5) can cause severe toxicity because CNS levels are high. Hemodialysis indications: • Level >4.0 (any toxicity type) • Level >2.5 with significant symptoms • Any level with severe neurologic symptoms (altered mental status, seizures, coma) • Renal impairment limiting clearance • Unable to tolerate fluids Why other options are wrong: • A: IVF helps in mild toxicity but insufficient for severe neurologic symptoms with AKI • B: Observation too conservative; CNS symptoms require intervention • D: Activated charcoal doesn't bind lithium; not helpful • E: Lithium is not amenable to alkaline diuresis (unlike salicylates) High-Yield Takeaway: Chronic lithium toxicity with neurologic symptoms (confusion, ataxia, tremor) → hemodialysis, even at moderate levels (2.5–3.5). Chronic toxicity causes severe symptoms at lower levels than acute toxicity due to CNS lithium accumulation.

stem:
A 42-year-old woman with migraines (8–10 headache days/month) and BMI 34 requests preventive therapy. She also has hypertension controlled on lisinopril and reports depressed mood for which she declines antidepressant medication. She is concerned about weight gain. Prior trial of topiramate was stopped due to significant word- finding difficulty.

Which prophylactic agent is most appropriate for this patient?
options: [{"text":"Propranolol","label":"A"},{"text":"Amitriptyline","label":"B"},{"text":"Valproate","label":"C"},{"text":"Venlafaxine","label":"D"},{"text":"Onabotulinumtoxin A","label":"E"}]
explanation: Migraine prophylaxis selection requires matching agent to comorbidities: Agent Benefits Avoid if Beta-blockers HTN, anxiety, tremor Asthma, depression (relative), bradycardia Topiramate Obesity (weight loss) Kidney stones, cognitive concerns Amitriptyline Insomnia, depression, tension-type overlap Obesity, cardiac conduction issues Valproate Bipolar, epilepsy Obesity, childbearing potential Venlafaxine Depression, anxiety HTN (can raise BP) CGRP inhibitors Failed ≥2 preventives Cost/access This patient: • Hypertension → beta-blocker provides dual benefit • Obesity → avoid valproate and amitriptyline (weight gain) • Topiramate intolerance → already failed • Declines antidepressants → rules out amitriptyline, venlafaxine • Does not meet criteria for onabotulinumtoxin A (requires ≥15 headache days/month for chronic migraine) Propranolol addresses HTN and provides first-line migraine prophylaxis without weight gain. Why other options are wrong: • B: Causes weight gain; patient declined antidepressants • C: Significant weight gain; teratogenic (relevant for reproductive-age woman) • D: Patient declined antidepressants; can worsen hypertension • E: Only FDA-approved for chronic migraine (≥15 days/month); she has 8–10 days High-Yield Takeaway: Match migraine prophylaxis to comorbidities: beta-blocker for HTN; topiramate for obesity; amitriptyline for insomnia/depression; valproate for epilepsy (avoid in women of childbearing age); CGRP inhibitors after failing 2+ preventives.

stem:
A 34-year-old woman with relapsing-remitting multiple sclerosis on natalizumab presents with worsening right leg weakness over 2 days. She reports low-grade fever and dysuria for the past 4 days. Her last relapse was 8 months ago. Examination shows 4/5 strength in the right lower extremity (baseline was 4+/5) and an MRI from 3 months ago showed stable lesion burden.

What is the most appropriate next step in management?
options: [{"text":"Administer IV methylprednisolone 1g daily for 3–5 days","label":"A"},{"text":"Obtain urinalysis and urine culture before initiating steroids","label":"B"},{"text":"Obtain MRI brain and spine with gadolinium","label":"C"},{"text":"Switch disease-modifying therapy due to breakthrough disease","label":"D"},{"text":"Reassure and observe with outpatient follow-up in 1 week","label":"E"}]
explanation: This presentation is classic for pseudo-relapse—worsening of pre-existing neurologic deficits triggered by physiological stressor (here, UTI). Key distinguishing features: • Pseudo-relapse: Occurs with infection, fever, heat, or stress; symptoms are recurrence/worsening of OLD deficits; resolves when trigger treated; no new MRI lesions • True relapse: New or substantially worsened symptoms lasting >24 hours; typically new lesions on MRI; no identifiable trigger The dysuria and fever strongly suggest UTI as the culprit. Treatment of the underlying infection typically resolves neurologic worsening within 24–48 hours. Administering steroids before ruling out infection is inappropriate— steroids can worsen infection and won't address the underlying cause. Why other options are wrong: • A: Premature—steroids should not be given until infection is excluded; treating UTI may resolve symptoms entirely • C: MRI is reasonable if infection workup is negative and symptoms persist, but not the immediate next step • D: No evidence of breakthrough disease—this appears triggered by infection, not DMT failure • E: Untreated UTI in MS patient risks worsening pseudo-relapse and systemic complications High-Yield Takeaway: Always rule out infection (especially UTI), fever, and metabolic derangements before diagnosing MS relapse— pseudo-relapse resolves with trigger treatment and does not require steroids.

stem:
A 62-year-old woman with myasthenia gravis on pyridostigmine 90mg every 4 hours presents with worsening dyspnea and generalized weakness over 2 days. She increased her pyridostigmine dose 3 days ago due to perceived symptom worsening. Vitals: HR 58, BP 110/70, RR 24, SpO2 91% on room air. Exam shows bilateral ptosis, proximal weakness, diffuse fasciculations, diaphoresis, and excessive salivation. Negative inspiratory force is -18 cmH2O.

What is the most appropriate immediate management?
options: [{"text":"Administer additional pyridostigmine","label":"A"},{"text":"Administer atropine and prepare for intubation","label":"B"},{"text":"Hold pyridostigmine and prepare for intubation","label":"C"},{"text":"Administer edrophonium as a diagnostic test","label":"D"},{"text":"Start IV immunoglobulin immediately","label":"E"}]
explanation: This patient has cholinergic crisis—excess acetylcholinesterase inhibitor causing both nicotinic and muscarinic toxicity: Feature Myasthenic Crisis Cholinergic Crisis Cause Undertreated MG Excess anticholinesterase Weakness Present Present Fasciculations Absent Present SLUDGE symptoms Absent Present (salivation, lacrimation, urination, diarrhea, GI upset, emesis) Bradycardia Absent Present Pupils Normal Miotic Response to edrophonium Improves Worsens Key findings indicating cholinergic crisis: • Recent pyridostigmine increase • Fasciculations (nicotinic excess) • SLUDGE: salivation, diaphoresis (muscarinic excess) • Bradycardia Management: 1. Stop anticholinesterase medications immediately 2. Airway protection — NIF < -20 to -25 indicates impending respiratory failure 3. Supportive care; atropine only if severe bradycardia or secretions compromising airway Why other options are wrong: • A: Would worsen cholinergic crisis catastrophically • B: Atropine addresses muscarinic symptoms but doesn't reverse nicotinic weakness; holding pyridostigmine is the priority • D: Edrophonium would worsen cholinergic crisis; contraindicated when cholinergic crisis suspected • E: IVIG treats myasthenic crisis, not cholinergic crisis; stopping the offending medication is first priority High-Yield Takeaway: Fasciculations + SLUDGE symptoms + bradycardia in MG patient on anticholinesterases = cholinergic crisis → stop pyridostigmine immediately and prepare for airway management.

stem:
A 58-year-old man presents with 6 months of progressive numbness and burning in both feet. He has no diabetes (HbA1c 5.4%), drinks 1–2 beers weekly, and takes no medications. Examination reveals decreased pinprick and vibration sense to the mid-shin bilaterally with absent ankle reflexes. Initial labs show normal glucose, B12, TSH, and CBC.

What is the most appropriate next step in evaluation?
options: [{"text":"Nerve conduction studies and electromyography","label":"A"},{"text":"Serum protein electrophoresis and immunofixation","label":"B"},{"text":"Lumbar puncture with CSF analysis","label":"C"},{"text":"Genetic testing for Charcot-Marie-Tooth disease","label":"D"},{"text":"Trial of gabapentin for symptomatic relief","label":"E"}]
explanation: When initial workup for peripheral neuropathy is unrevealing, systematic evaluation for treatable causes is essential. Tiered approach to cryptogenic neuropathy: Tier 1 (Initial): Glucose/HbA1c, B12, TSH, CBC, CMP — rules out the "big 3" (diabetes, B12 deficiency, hypothyroidism) — done and normal Tier 2 (Extended): • SPEP/immunofixation — screens for monoclonal gammopathy (MGUS, myeloma, amyloidosis, POEMS) • HIV, hepatitis B/C serologies • ANA, ESR (vasculitis, connective tissue disease) • Methylmalonic acid (functional B12 deficiency) Tier 3 (Specialized): NCS/EMG (characterizes neuropathy type), genetic testing, nerve biopsy, paraneoplastic antibodies Monoclonal gammopathy causes ~10% of initially idiopathic neuropathies and is treatable. SPEP with immunofixation (not just SPEP alone) is essential because immunofixation detects small monoclonal proteins missed by SPEP. Why other options are wrong: • A: NCS/EMG characterizes neuropathy pattern but doesn't identify cause; appropriate after serologic workup • C: LP indicated if inflammatory/infectious etiology suspected (AIDP, CIDP); not routine for distal sensory neuropathy • D: CMT typically presents younger with foot deformities and family history; genetic testing is tier 3 • E: Symptomatic treatment before diagnosis may mask progression and delay identifying treatable cause High-Yield Takeaway: Idiopathic neuropathy with negative initial labs → check SPEP with immunofixation (monoclonal gammopathy is common and treatable), HIV, hepatitis serologies, and ANA before proceeding to electrodiagnostics.

stem:
A 71-year-old man with Parkinson disease for 9 years on carbidopa-levodopa 25/100mg four times daily reports that his medications "wear off" about 1 hour before each dose. He also experiences involuntary writhing movements of his trunk and limbs during peak effect. His wife confirms the dyskinesias occur 1–2 hours after each dose.

Which adjustment best addresses both his wearing-off and peak-dose dyskinesia?
options: [{"text":"Increase each carbidopa-levodopa dose","label":"A"},{"text":"Add entacapone to each levodopa dose","label":"B"},{"text":"Give smaller, more frequent doses of carbidopa-levodopa","label":"C"},{"text":"Add amantadine","label":"D"},{"text":"Add pramipexole","label":"E"}]
explanation: This patient demonstrates two common motor complications: 1. Wearing-off — Motor benefit wanes before next dose (predictable end-of-dose deterioration) 2. Peak-dose dyskinesia — Involuntary choreiform movements at time of peak levodopa levels The management strategy depends on which fluctuation predominates: Problem Strategy Wearing-off alone Add COMT inhibitor (entacapone), increase dose, add dopamine agonist, or shorten dosing interval Peak-dose dyskinesia alone Reduce individual doses, add amantadine Both wearing-off AND dyskinesia Smaller, more frequent doses (smooths plasma levels); add amantadine for dyskinesia Smaller, more frequent dosing reduces peak levels (↓ dyskinesia) while maintaining more consistent coverage (↓ wearing-off). This addresses both issues simultaneously. Why other options are wrong: • A: Higher doses worsen peak-dose dyskinesia • B: Entacapone prolongs levodopa effect (helps wearing-off) but increases peak levels → worsens dyskinesia • D: Amantadine specifically treats dyskinesia but doesn't address wearing-off; reasonable add-on but not first adjustment • E: Dopamine agonists help wearing-off but can worsen dyskinesia; higher risk of impulse control disorders in elderly High-Yield Takeaway: Wearing-off + peak-dose dyskinesia → smaller, more frequent levodopa doses to smooth plasma levels. Amantadine is the specific add-on for refractory dyskinesia.

stem:
A 31-year-old woman with PCOS and BMI 27 presents with 14 months of infertility. She has 3–4 menses per year. Her partner's semen analysis is normal. HSG shows patent tubes. She has tried lifestyle modifications for 6 months without achieving spontaneous ovulation.

What is the first-line pharmacologic agent for ovulation induction?
options: [{"text":"Clomiphene citrate","label":"A"},{"text":"Letrozole","label":"B"},{"text":"Metformin","label":"C"},{"text":"Gonadotropins (FSH injections)","label":"D"},{"text":"Combined oral contraceptives to regulate cycles first","label":"E"}]
explanation: Ovulation induction in PCOS follows a stepwise approach: Line Agent Notes First Letrozole Superior live birth and ovulation rates vs clomiphene in PCOS (PPCOS II trial); lower multiple gestation risk Second Clomiphene Alternative first-line; anti-estrogen at hypothalamus → ↑ GnRH/FSH Third Gonadotropins For clomiphene/letrozole failures; higher multiple gestation and OHSS risk Third Laparoscopic ovarian drilling Alternative to gonadotropins Line Agent Notes Third IVF For failed ovulation induction or other factors Letrozole vs Clomiphene: • Letrozole: Aromatase inhibitor → ↓ estrogen → ↑ FSH; thinner endometrial lining is NOT an issue (unlike clomiphene); fewer multiples • Clomiphene: Anti-estrogen → blocks negative feedback → ↑ GnRH/FSH; can cause hostile cervical mucus and thin endometrium The landmark PPCOS II trial (2014) established letrozole as superior to clomiphene for PCOS ovulation induction: • Higher ovulation rate • Higher live birth rate (27.5% vs 19.1%) • Lower multiple gestation rate Why other options are wrong: • A: Clomiphene is an acceptable alternative but no longer first-line per current evidence • C: Metformin improves ovulation rates but is inferior to letrozole/clomiphene for conception; adjunctive role • D: Gonadotropins are second/third-line due to higher risk profile • E: OCPs regulate cycles but prevent pregnancy; not indicated when actively trying to conceive High-Yield Takeaway: First-line ovulation induction for PCOS = letrozole (PPCOS II trial). Clomiphene is second-line. Gonadotropins for refractory cases. Pediatrics

stem:
A 3-year-old girl presents with her first febrile UTI. Urine culture grows >100,000 CFU/mL of E. coli. She is treated with oral antibiotics with clinical improvement. Renal bladder ultrasound shows normal kidneys bilaterally with no hydronephrosis or bladder abnormalities.

What is the most appropriate next step regarding imaging?
options: [{"text":"Voiding cystourethrogram (VCUG) to evaluate for vesicoureteral reflux","label":"A"},{"text":"DMSA renal scan to assess for scarring","label":"B"},{"text":"No additional imaging indicated","label":"C"},{"text":"Repeat renal ultrasound in 6 months","label":"D"},{"text":"CT urogram for detailed anatomical evaluation","label":"E"}]
explanation: Pediatric UTI imaging strategy has evolved to reduce unnecessary invasive testing (AAP 2011, reaffirmed): After first febrile UTI (age 2–24 months): • Renal bladder ultrasound (RBUS): Recommended for ALL children with first febrile UTI • VCUG: NOT routine for first febrile UTI if RBUS is normal VCUG indications after first UTI: • Abnormal RBUS (hydronephrosis, scarring, other anomalies) • Recurrent febrile UTI • Atypical UTI course (poor response to appropriate antibiotics, unusual organism) • Family history of high-grade VUR • Clinical concern for posterior urethral valves (males with poor stream) This patient: • First febrile UTI • Normal RBUS • Good clinical response • No atypical features VUR is common (30–40% of children with UTI) but: • Most cases are low-grade and resolve spontaneously • Antibiotic prophylaxis for low-grade VUR has questionable benefit • VCUG is invasive (catheterization, radiation) The "top-down" approach: RBUS screens for significant anomalies; VCUG reserved for those with abnormalities or recurrence. Why other options are wrong: • A: VCUG not indicated with normal ultrasound after first UTI—exposes child to catheterization and radiation without clear benefit • B: DMSA indicated if concern for scarring (recurrent UTI, atypical course); not routine after first UTI with normal ultrasound • D: Repeat ultrasound not needed if initial study was normal and child responded well • E: CT exposes child to significant radiation; never first-line in pediatrics High-Yield Takeaway: First febrile UTI + normal renal ultrasound = no VCUG needed. VCUG indicated for abnormal ultrasound, recurrent UTI, or atypical course. Surgery

stem:
A 48-year-old woman is post-operative day 3 after laparoscopic cholecystectomy for acute cholecystitis. She develops worsening right upper quadrant pain, fever to 38.4°C, and nausea. Her drain (placed intraoperatively due to inflamed gallbladder bed) output has increased to 200 mL of bilious fluid over 24 hours. Labs show WBC 14,000 and total bilirubin 2.8 mg/dL.

What is the most appropriate next step in management?
options: [{"text":"Return to operating room for exploratory laparotomy","label":"A"},{"text":"ERCP with sphincterotomy and possible stent placement","label":"B"},{"text":"CT abdomen with IV contrast","label":"C"},{"text":"Remove drain and observe","label":"D"},{"text":"HIDA scan to confirm bile leak","label":"E"}]
explanation: Post-cholecystectomy bile leak is a recognized complication occurring in 0.3–0.5% of cases. Management depends on leak source and severity: Bile leak sources: • Cystic duct stump — Most common; usually low-grade • Duct of Luschka — Small duct from liver bed • Common bile duct injury — Most severe; requires surgical repair Management algorithm: Scenario Management Controlled leak with drain in place ERCP with sphincterotomy ± stent (first-line) Uncontrolled leak / biloma without drain CT-guided drainage + ERCP Major CBD injury (transection/ligation) Surgical repair (hepaticojejunostomy) Why ERCP is first-line for most bile leaks: 1. Sphincterotomy reduces sphincter of Oddi pressure, redirecting bile flow to duodenum 2. Stent placement further reduces pressure gradient across the leak 3. 90% of cystic duct/duct of Luschka leaks resolve with ERCP alone 4. Also diagnostic—cholangiogram identifies leak site and any CBD injury This patient: • Controlled leak (drain in place with bilious output) • Low-grade leak (200 mL/day) • No signs of peritonitis Why other options are wrong: • A: Surgery reserved for major CBD injury or failed ERCP; too aggressive for controlled low-grade leak • C: CT may be helpful if drain not in place (to identify biloma) but won't change management here—ERCP is both diagnostic and therapeutic • D: Removing drain would lead to biloma formation; drain is protective • E: HIDA confirms bile leak but doesn't treat it; ERCP is both diagnostic and therapeutic High-Yield Takeaway: Post-cholecystectomy bile leak (controlled) → ERCP with sphincterotomy ± stent (>90% success rate). Maintain drain in place. Surgery only for major CBD injury or ERCP failure.

stem:
A 67-year-old woman underwent open sigmoid colectomy for colon cancer 5 days ago. She had return of bowel function (flatus) on post-operative day 3 and was tolerating a regular diet until this morning when she developed nausea, vomiting, and abdominal distension. She reports intermittent crampy abdominal pain. Exam shows distended abdomen with high-pitched bowel sounds. She passed flatus this morning.

What is the most likely diagnosis?
options: [{"text":"Prolonged postoperative ileus","label":"A"},{"text":"Anastomotic leak","label":"B"},{"text":"Early postoperative small bowel obstruction","label":"C"},{"text":"Ogilvie syndrome (colonic pseudo-obstruction)","label":"D"},{"text":"Clostridium difficile colitis","label":"E"}]
explanation: Distinguishing ileus from early postoperative SBO is crucial: Feature Postoperative Ileus Early SBO Timing POD 0–3; no prior return of function After initial return of function Pain Mild, constant discomfort Crampy, intermittent Bowel sounds Absent or hypoactive High-pitched, hyperactive Passage of flatus Absent May be present (partial) Course Gradually improves Worsens without intervention This patient: • Initial return of function (flatus POD 3, tolerating diet) — ileus had resolved • New symptoms after resolution — concerning for mechanical obstruction • Crampy pain — suggests peristalsis against obstruction • High-pitched bowel sounds — classic for SBO • Continued flatus — partial obstruction Early postoperative SBO (within 30 days): • Occurs in ~1% of abdominal surgeries • Causes: adhesions (most common), internal hernia, kinking at anastomosis • Management: NGT decompression, CT to evaluate; most resolve non-operatively initially Why other options are wrong: • A: Ileus doesn't present with crampy pain and hyperactive bowel sounds; typically no return of function • B: Anastomotic leak presents with fever, peritonitis, tachycardia; not typically obstructive symptoms • D: Ogilvie syndrome affects colon (massive colonic dilation); presents with distension but not crampy pain or high-pitched sounds • E: C. diff presents with watery diarrhea, fever, leukocytosis; not obstruction pattern High-Yield Takeaway: Crampy pain + high-pitched bowel sounds + symptoms AFTER initial return of bowel function = early postoperative SBO, not prolonged ileus. Ileus has absent/hypoactive sounds and no prior return of function.

stem:
A 29-year-old G2P1 at 31 weeks gestation presents with rupture of membranes confirmed by pooling, ferning, and positive AmniSure. She is afebrile with reassuring fetal heart tracing and no contractions. GBS status is unknown. She received her first dose of betamethasone 6 hours ago.

What is the most appropriate management plan?
options: [{"text":"Proceed with delivery given confirmed rupture of membranes","label":"A"},{"text":"Expectant management with antibiotics until 34 weeks or complications develop","label":"B"},{"text":"Expectant management until 37 weeks","label":"C"},{"text":"Administer tocolytics for 48 hours, then induce at 32 weeks","label":"D"},{"text":"Perform amniocentesis to assess fetal lung maturity before deciding","label":"E"}]
explanation: PPROM (preterm prelabor rupture of membranes) management depends on gestational age: GA Management <23 weeks Counsel on options (expectant vs termination); high morbidity 23–34 weeks Expectant management with latency antibiotics until 34 weeks or complications 34–37 weeks Current evidence supports delivery at 34 weeks (some centers extend to 36-37) ≥37 weeks Deliver Components of expectant management at 31 weeks: 1. Corticosteroids — Complete course (2 doses, 24h apart) 2. Latency antibiotics — Ampicillin + azithromycin (7-day course) to prolong latency and reduce chorioamnionitis 3. GBS prophylaxis — If unknown status, treat as positive during labor 4. Magnesium sulfate — For neuroprotection if delivery anticipated <32 weeks 5. Monitoring — Serial maternal vitals, fetal heart rate monitoring, signs of infection/labor Indications to deliver despite prematurity: • Chorioamnionitis (fever, uterine tenderness, fetal tachycardia, maternal leukocytosis) • Non-reassuring fetal status • Placental abruption • Cord prolapse • Advanced labor Why other options are wrong: • A: At 31 weeks, prematurity risk exceeds infection risk in stable patients; expectant management improves outcomes • C: Most guidelines recommend delivery by 34 weeks (some 36–37); extending to 37 weeks increases infection risk without clear benefit • D: Tocolytics only indicated for 48 hours to complete steroids/magnesium; not for prolonged latency • E: Amniocentesis for FLM no longer recommended; gestational age guides decisions High-Yield Takeaway: PPROM 23–34 weeks + stable = expectant management with latency antibiotics and corticosteroids until 34 weeks or complications. Deliver immediately if signs of infection, non-reassuring fetal status, or abruption.

stem:
A 28-year-old man with well-controlled focal epilepsy on levetiracetam 1500mg twice daily presents after a witnessed seizure this morning—his first in 2 years. He denies missed doses and his pill count confirms adherence. He started a new job last week with irregular sleep and reports taking over-the-counter diphenhydramine for insomnia. Vitals and neurologic exam are normal. Levetiracetam level is 18 mcg/mL (therapeutic: 12–46 mcg/mL).

What is the most appropriate next step?
options: [{"text":"Increase levetiracetam to 2000mg twice daily","label":"A"},{"text":"Add a second antiepileptic drug","label":"B"},{"text":"Obtain EEG and MRI brain","label":"C"},{"text":"Counsel on sleep hygiene and discontinue diphenhydramine","label":"D"},{"text":"Check CBC and comprehensive metabolic panel","label":"E"}]
explanation: Breakthrough seizures in adherent patients with therapeutic drug levels require identification of modifiable triggers before escalating therapy. This patient has two clear precipitants: 1. Sleep deprivation — Most common seizure trigger; lowers seizure threshold significantly 2. Diphenhydramine — Antihistamines lower seizure threshold and should be avoided in epilepsy The approach to breakthrough seizure in compliant patient: 1. Verify adherence (done—pill count confirms) 2. Check drug level (done—therapeutic) 3. Identify triggers (sleep deprivation, new medications, alcohol, illness, stress) 4. Address triggers before adjusting AED regimen Why other options are wrong: • A: Level is therapeutic; increasing dose adds side effects without addressing the cause • B: Premature—trigger modification should be attempted first; adding AEDs increases polypharmacy burden • C: EEG/MRI indicated if concern for new lesion or change in semiology; routine imaging not needed for single breakthrough with clear trigger • E: Metabolic workup reasonable but less likely to yield actionable findings than addressing obvious triggers High-Yield Takeaway: Breakthrough seizure + therapeutic AED level + clear trigger = address the trigger first. Common culprits: sleep deprivation, alcohol, medication interactions (fluoroquinolones, tramadol, bupropion, antihistamines), and illness.

stem:
A 45-year-old woman is post-operative day 1 after total thyroidectomy for papillary thyroid carcinoma. She reports perioral tingling and finger numbness. Labs show calcium 7.6 mg/dL and intact PTH 8 pg/mL (normal 15–65). She has no prior calcium supplementation.

What is the most appropriate management?
options: [{"text":"Oral calcium carbonate 500mg three times daily","label":"A"},{"text":"Oral calcium carbonate plus calcitriol","label":"B"},{"text":"IV calcium gluconate bolus followed by oral calcium","label":"C"},{"text":"Observation with repeat calcium in 6 hours","label":"D"},{"text":"Magnesium replacement before calcium supplementation","label":"E"}]
explanation: Post-thyroidectomy hypocalcemia results from parathyroid injury (transient stunning or inadvertent removal): Severity assessment: • Mild: Asymptomatic or perioral paresthesias; Ca 7.5–8.0 mg/dL • Moderate: Symptomatic paresthesias; Ca 7.0–7.5 mg/dL • Severe: Carpopedal spasm, tetany, arrhythmia; Ca <7.0 mg/dL Management by severity: Severity Management Symptomatic (any level) Oral calcium + calcitriol Severe (Ca <7.0 or severe symptoms) IV calcium gluconate → oral calcium + calcitriol Asymptomatic Oral calcium alone may suffice Why calcitriol (1,25-OH vitamin D)? • PTH normally stimulates 1α-hydroxylase to convert 25-OH vitamin D → active 1,25-OH vitamin D • With low PTH, this conversion is impaired • Calcitriol provides the active form, allowing calcium absorption • Without calcitriol, oral calcium alone is poorly absorbed This patient: • Symptomatic (paresthesias) • Low PTH (8 pg/mL) — confirms hypoparathyroidism • Moderate hypocalcemia (7.6 mg/dL) Why other options are wrong: • A: Calcium alone insufficient when PTH is low—needs calcitriol for adequate absorption • C: IV calcium reserved for severe/life-threatening symptoms (tetany, seizure, arrhythmia); this patient has mild symptoms • D: Patient is symptomatic—requires treatment, not observation • E: Magnesium should be checked but hypomagnesemia is not the likely cause post-thyroidectomy; parathyroid injury is High-Yield Takeaway: Post-thyroidectomy hypocalcemia with low PTH = oral calcium PLUS calcitriol (active vitamin D). Calcitriol compensates for impaired 1α-hydroxylation due to PTH deficiency.

stem:
A 67-year-old man presented 3 days ago with transient left arm weakness lasting 30 minutes. MRI showed a small acute infarct in the right corona radiata. ABCD2 score was 5. He was started on aspirin 81mg plus clopidogrel 75mg. Carotid imaging shows <50% stenosis bilaterally. Echocardiogram and telemetry show no cardioembolic source. He now asks how long he needs to take both medications.

What is the appropriate duration of dual antiplatelet therapy for this patient?
options: [{"text":"21 days, then aspirin monotherapy","label":"A"},{"text":"90 days, then aspirin monotherapy","label":"B"},{"text":"12 months, then reassess","label":"C"},{"text":"Indefinitely, given high-risk features","label":"D"},{"text":"Discontinue clopidogrel now; aspirin alone is sufficient","label":"E"}]
explanation: The POINT and CHANCE trials established dual antiplatelet therapy (DAPT) for high-risk TIA/minor stroke: Indications for DAPT: • High-risk TIA (ABCD2 ≥4) OR minor ischemic stroke (NIHSS ≤3) • Non-cardioembolic mechanism • Initiated within 24 hours of symptom onset Duration: • 21 days of aspirin + clopidogrel (CHANCE protocol, preferred) • Alternative: 21–30 days (some guidelines extend to 30) • NOT 90 days — POINT trial showed increased bleeding without additional benefit beyond 21–30 days • After DAPT: Continue aspirin monotherapy indefinitely This patient has minor stroke (DWI+ TIA = minor stroke by definition), ABCD2 of 5 (high-risk), and non- cardioembolic etiology—perfect candidate for 21-day DAPT. Why other options are wrong: • B: 90 days showed excess bleeding in POINT trial without additional stroke reduction; 21 days is current standard • C: No indication for 12-month DAPT in stroke (unlike coronary stenting) • D: Indefinite DAPT increases bleeding; long-term management is aspirin monotherapy • E: Stopping clopidogrel at day 3 loses the early high-risk window benefit High-Yield Takeaway: High-risk TIA or minor stroke → 21 days of aspirin + clopidogrel (start within 24 hours) → then aspirin monotherapy lifelong. Do not extend DAPT beyond 21–30 days due to bleeding risk.

stem:
A 48-year-old woman with major depressive disorder has failed adequate trials of sertraline (200mg x 10 weeks) and venlafaxine (225mg x 8 weeks) with minimal improvement. She has no history of mania, psychosis, or substance use. She asks about options beyond switching to another antidepressant.

Which augmentation strategy has the strongest evidence for treatment-resistant depression?
options: [{"text":"Add lithium","label":"A"},{"text":"Add buspirone","label":"B"},{"text":"Add modafinil","label":"C"},{"text":"Add atypical antipsychotic (aripiprazole)","label":"D"},{"text":"Add thyroid hormone (T3)","label":"E"}]
explanation: Treatment-resistant depression (TRD) is defined as failure of ≥2 adequate antidepressant trials. Options include: Evidence-based augmentation strategies: Agent Evidence Level Notes Atypical antipsychotics Strongest (FDA-approved) Aripiprazole, quetiapine, olanzapine/fluoxetine Lithium Strong (older studies) Requires monitoring; smaller effect in modern trials Thyroid hormone (T3) Moderate 25–50 mcg; better for T3 than T4 Bupropion Moderate Combination rather than augmentation Buspirone Weak-moderate Less robust data Atypical antipsychotics are currently first-line for TRD augmentation because: • FDA-approved: Aripiprazole (Abilify), quetiapine XR (Seroquel XR), olanzapine/fluoxetine (Symbyax), brexpiprazole (Rexulti) • Consistent efficacy in large RCTs • Aripiprazole has favorable metabolic profile among atypicals Lithium augmentation: • Well-established in older literature • Modern meta-analyses show smaller effect sizes than initially reported • Requires level monitoring, renal/thyroid function checks • Reserved for patients who also need mood stabilization or have suicidality (lithium reduces suicide risk) Why other options are wrong: • A: Lithium has evidence but is no longer first-line given monitoring burden and smaller modern effect sizes • B: Buspirone augmentation has weaker evidence than atypicals • C: Modafinil may help fatigue/concentration but limited antidepressant augmentation data • E: T3 augmentation has moderate evidence but atypicals have stronger, more consistent data High-Yield Takeaway: Treatment-resistant depression augmentation: first-line = atypical antipsychotic (aripiprazole or quetiapine). Lithium and T3 are alternatives with moderate evidence.

stem:
A 41-year-old woman is admitted with acute pancreatitis secondary to gallstones. On hospital day 2, she has mild epigastric tenderness, lipase of 890 U/L (down from 2,400 U/L on admission), and no nausea or vomiting. She reports feeling hungry. She has been receiving IV fluids and IV morphine for pain control. CT performed on admission showed interstitial edematous pancreatitis without necrosis. She remains afebrile with stable vital signs.

What is the most appropriate nutritional management?
options: [{"text":"Continue NPO status until lipase normalizes","label":"A"},{"text":"Initiate nasojejunal tube feeding","label":"B"},{"text":"Start a clear liquid diet and advance as tolerated","label":"C"},{"text":"Delay oral intake until abdominal pain completely resolves","label":"D"},{"text":"Begin total parenteral nutrition","label":"E"}]
explanation: Current evidence supports early oral feeding (within 24-48 hours) in acute pancreatitis when patients can tolerate it, regardless of lipase levels or mild residual pain. The traditional teaching of prolonged NPO status ("pancreatic rest") until complete pain resolution and lipase normalization has been disproven. Early enteral feeding maintains gut barrier function, reduces infectious complications, decreases length of stay, and may reduce mortality. This patient is hungry, has no nausea/vomiting, has mild uncomplicated (interstitial) pancreatitis, and has improving clinical status—all favorable indicators for initiating oral intake. A low-fat solid diet is acceptable; routine use of clear liquid progression is not mandatory. Why Other Options Are Wrong: • A (NPO until lipase normalizes): Outdated practice; lipase normalization is not required before feeding. • B (Nasojejunal feeding): Reserved for patients who cannot tolerate oral intake; unnecessary here. • D (Wait for complete pain resolution): Unnecessary delay; mild pain is not a contraindication to oral feeding. • E (TPN): Only indicated when enteral feeding is not possible for prolonged periods; not appropriate here. High-Yield Takeaway: In acute pancreatitis, initiate oral feeding within 24-48 hours when tolerated; do not wait for complete pain resolution or lipase normalization. NEPHROLOGY

stem:
A 58-year-old woman undergoes CT abdomen for evaluation of kidney stones. Incidentally, a 0.9-cm homogeneous adrenal nodule is discovered with Hounsfield units of 8 (consistent with lipid-rich adenoma). She is normotensive, has no cushingoid features, and has no symptoms of hyperaldosteronism or catecholamine excess. She has no personal or family history of malignancy.

What is the most appropriate next step?
options: [{"text":"24-hour urine catecholamines and metanephrines","label":"A"},{"text":"1-mg overnight dexamethasone suppression test","label":"B"},{"text":"Plasma aldosterone-to-renin ratio","label":"C"},{"text":"Complete hormonal workup including all of the above","label":"D"},{"text":"No further workup indicated","label":"E"}]
explanation: Adrenal incidentalomas <1 cm with benign imaging characteristics (low Hounsfield units indicating lipid-rich content, homogeneous appearance, smooth borders) have extremely low malignant potential and low rates of hormonal hypersecretion. Current guidelines suggest that nodules <1 cm with imaging features consistent with adenoma do not require routine biochemical workup or follow-up imaging. The risk of clinically significant disease is negligible, and the cost and patient anxiety of testing outweigh potential benefits. This contrasts with lesions ≥1 cm, which typically warrant biochemical evaluation regardless of imaging appearance. Why Other Options Are Wrong: • A, B, C, D (Various hormonal tests): Not indicated for <1 cm lipid-rich adenomas; biochemical workup is reserved for larger lesions or those with concerning imaging features. High-Yield Takeaway: Adrenal incidentalomas <1 cm with benign imaging features (lipid-rich, homogeneous) require no further hormonal workup or surveillance. HEMATOLOGY/ONCOLOGY

stem:
A 58-year-old man with a 2-year history of persistent atrial fibrillation managed with metoprolol and apixaban presents with 6 weeks of progressive exertional dyspnea and orthopnea. He denies chest pain or palpitations. Echocardiogram reveals a new finding of left ventricular ejection fraction of 38% (previously 55% one year ago), moderate mitral regurgitation, and left atrial enlargement. His ventricular rate is well-controlled at 78 bpm. NT-proBNP is elevated at 2,400 pg/mL. He has no history of coronary artery disease, and recent coronary angiography was unremarkable.

What is the most appropriate change to his atrial fibrillation management?
options: [{"text":"Continue current rate control with metoprolol","label":"A"},{"text":"Add digoxin for enhanced rate control","label":"B"},{"text":"Refer for catheter ablation with goal of rhythm control","label":"C"},{"text":"Initiate amiodarone for pharmacologic cardioversion","label":"D"},{"text":"Increase metoprolol dose to achieve resting rate below 60 bpm","label":"E"}]
explanation: This patient has tachycardia-mediated cardiomyopathy (or AFib-related cardiomyopathy), where persistent atrial fibrillation has led to new-onset heart failure with reduced ejection fraction. Despite "adequate" rate control by traditional metrics, the loss of atrial kick and irregularity of AFib contributes to ventricular dysfunction. In this setting, the discovery of new HFrEF fundamentally changes the treatment paradigm from rate control to rhythm control. Catheter ablation for AFib in patients with HFrEF has been shown to improve ejection fraction, reduce hospitalizations, and decrease mortality compared to continued rate control. This represents a reversal of the initial strategy based on the new clinical context. Why Other Options Are Wrong: • A (Continue rate control): The development of HFrEF in the setting of AFib indicates rate control alone is insufficient and may be contributing to cardiomyopathy. • B (Add digoxin): Adding another rate-control agent does not address the underlying issue; rhythm control is now indicated. • D (Amiodarone): While amiodarone can achieve rhythm control, catheter ablation has superior outcomes in AFib with HFrEF and avoids long- term drug toxicity. • E (Stricter rate control): Aggressive rate control with goal HR <60 is not supported and does not restore atrial contribution to cardiac output. High-Yield Takeaway: New-onset heart failure with reduced EF in a patient with atrial fibrillation should prompt a shift from rate control to rhythm control, preferably via catheter ablation.

stem:
A 68-year-old man with CKD stage 3b (baseline creatinine 2.1 mg/dL), heart failure with reduced ejection fraction, and type 2 diabetes is hospitalized for acute kidney injury in the setting of volume depletion from gastroenteritis. His lisinopril was held on admission. Creatinine peaked at 3.8 mg/dL and has now recovered to 2.3 mg/dL after IV fluid resuscitation. His blood pressure is 128/78 mmHg. He is preparing for discharge. Prior to this hospitalization, his creatinine had been stable on lisinopril for 3 years with good BP control and no hyperkalemia.

What is the most appropriate management of his lisinopril at discharge?
options: [{"text":"Permanently discontinue lisinopril due to AKI","label":"A"},{"text":"Switch to an ARB which has better renal safety","label":"B"},{"text":"Restart lisinopril at the prior dose once creatinine returns to baseline","label":"C"},{"text":"Restart lisinopril at a reduced dose with creatinine monitoring in 1 week","label":"D"},{"text":"Delay lisinopril restart for 3 months to allow renal recovery","label":"E"}]
explanation: ACE inhibitors provide significant long-term cardiorenal protection in patients with HFrEF and diabetic nephropathy. Temporary discontinuation during AKI is appropriate, but permanent discontinuation based solely on a hemodynamic/pre-renal AKI episode is not indicated. The AKI in this case was clearly precipitated by volume depletion, not intrinsic ACE inhibitor nephrotoxicity. Once the reversible trigger has resolved and creatinine is trending toward baseline, the ACE inhibitor should be restarted—often at a reduced dose initially—with close monitoring. The mortality and heart failure hospitalization benefits of ACE inhibitors in HFrEF outweigh the risks in patients with stable CKD. Why Other Options Are Wrong: • A (Permanently discontinue): Removes a medication with proven mortality benefit; not indicated for hemodynamic AKI. • B (Switch to ARB): ARBs have similar hemodynamic effects on GFR; no safety advantage over ACE inhibitors in this scenario. • C (Restart at full dose): More cautious approach with reduced dose and monitoring is prudent post-AKI. • E (Delay 3 months): Unnecessarily prolongs the time without cardioprotective therapy. High-Yield Takeaway: ACE inhibitors held during pre-renal AKI should be restarted (often at reduced dose with monitoring) once the precipitant resolves; permanent discontinuation forfeits cardiorenal benefits.

stem:
A 35-year-old man was treated 8 weeks ago for uncomplicated acute appendicitis managed non-operatively with IV antibiotics due to his preference to avoid surgery. CT at that time showed a non-perforated appendix without abscess. He completed a 7-day antibiotic course with complete resolution of symptoms. Follow-up CT shows resolution of inflammation with a normal-appearing appendix. He remains asymptomatic.

What is the most appropriate management?
options: [{"text":"Proceed with interval appendectomy within the next 4 weeks","label":"A"},{"text":"Perform colonoscopy before deciding on surgery","label":"B"},{"text":"Interval appendectomy is not required; continue observation","label":"C"},{"text":"Obtain MRI of the abdomen before interval appendectomy","label":"D"},{"text":"Interval appendectomy only if symptoms recur","label":"E"}]
explanation: The management of uncomplicated appendicitis has evolved. Non-operative management with antibiotics is successful in 70-80% of patients, and of those, approximately 30-40% will have recurrence within 5 years. The traditional approach of interval appendectomy for all patients has been questioned. Current evidence suggests that routine interval appendectomy is not mandatory after successful non-operative treatment of uncomplicated appendicitis. A reasonable approach is to offer appendectomy for recurrence. For patients over 40, colonoscopy or imaging follow-up to exclude malignancy masquerading as appendicitis is recommended, but for this 35-year-old with resolved imaging, observation with surgery reserved for recurrence is appropriate. Why Other Options Are Wrong: • A (Interval appendectomy in 4 weeks): Not required for uncomplicated appendicitis treated non-operatively. • B (Colonoscopy first): Typically recommended for patients >40 years to exclude neoplasm; not mandatory for this 35-year-old. • C (Continue observation without offering surgery for recurrence): Subtly incorrect; observation is appropriate, but surgery should be offered if symptoms recur. • D (MRI): No indication; CT has already shown resolution. High-Yield Takeaway: After successful non-operative treatment of uncomplicated appendicitis, interval appendectomy is not mandatory; surgery is reserved for recurrence. BATCH 4 — QUESTION GENERATION COMPLETE Total questions generated: 33 Format: NBME-style clinical vignettes with single best answer Coverage: All 33 locked Batch 4 concepts

stem:
A 28-year-old woman with well-controlled asthma on medium-dose inhaled corticosteroid plus long-acting beta-agonist (ICS-LABA) had her therapy stepped down to low-dose ICS alone 6 weeks ago after 3 months of complete symptom control. She now presents with nighttime awakenings twice weekly and uses her rescue albuterol 4 times per week. She denies respiratory infection, new environmental exposures, or medication non-adherence. Peak flow is 75% of her personal best.

What is the most appropriate next step in management?
options: [{"text":"Restart medium-dose ICS-LABA and continue indefinitely","label":"A"},{"text":"Restart medium-dose ICS-LABA and reassess step-down eligibility in 3 months","label":"B"},{"text":"Increase to high-dose ICS monotherapy","label":"C"},{"text":"Add oral montelukast to current low-dose ICS","label":"D"},{"text":"Prescribe a short course of oral prednisone","label":"E"}]
explanation: This patient's symptoms represent failure of step-down therapy rather than a true exacerbation. The appropriate response is to return to the previously effective regimen (medium-dose ICS-LABA) and reassess step-down eligibility after re-establishing control for at least 3 months. Failed step-down does not mean permanent therapy escalation—it means the patient was not ready for de-escalation at that time. After regaining control, another step-down attempt may be successful, particularly if modifiable factors (allergen exposure, technique, adherence) are optimized. The goal remains the lowest effective therapy. Why Other Options Are Wrong: • A (Continue indefinitely): Premature; step-down should be re-attempted after control is re-established. • C (High-dose ICS monotherapy): Less effective than ICS-LABA and represents over-escalation for a step-down failure. • D (Add montelukast): Less effective add-on than LABA and does not address the demonstrated need for LABA. • E (Oral prednisone): Reserved for true exacerbations; this is loss of control, not acute exacerbation. High-Yield Takeaway: Failed asthma step-down requires returning to the prior effective regimen and re-attempting step-down after 3 months of regained control, not permanent escalation. GASTROENTEROLOGY

stem:
A 7-month-old infant presents with 3 days of rhinorrhea, cough, and wheezing. She has mild tachypnea and scattered wheezes with adequate oxygen saturation of 94% on room air. She is feeding well, taking about 70% of her usual intake. RSV rapid antigen test is positive. The parents ask about nebulized treatments they read about online that can "clear the mucus."

What is the most appropriate recommendation regarding nebulized hypertonic saline?
options: [{"text":"Prescribe nebulized 3% hypertonic saline for home use","label":"A"},{"text":"Administer nebulized hypertonic saline in the emergency department and discharge","label":"B"},{"text":"Admit for nebulized hypertonic saline therapy","label":"C"},{"text":"Nebulized hypertonic saline is not indicated for this patient","label":"D"},{"text":"Use nebulized normal saline as a safer alternative","label":"E"}]
explanation: This infant has mild bronchiolitis with adequate oxygen saturation and feeding. AAP guidelines recommend supportive care (hydration, nasal suctioning, oxygen if needed) as the mainstay of bronchiolitis management. Nebulized hypertonic saline is not recommended for infants treated in the emergency department or outpatient setting. While some evidence suggests modest benefit in reducing length of stay for hospitalized patients (likely through improved mucociliary clearance), this benefit does not apply to outpatients. In the ED or outpatient setting, hypertonic saline has not been shown to prevent hospitalization or improve outcomes and adds cost and bronchospasm risk. Why Other Options Are Wrong: • A (Prescribe for home): Not indicated; no outpatient benefit demonstrated. • B (Give in ED and discharge): ED administration has not shown benefit in preventing hospitalization. • C (Admit for therapy): This infant does not meet admission criteria; admitting solely for hypertonic saline is inappropriate. • E (Normal saline): Also not routinely recommended; no proven benefit over supportive care. High-Yield Takeaway: Nebulized hypertonic saline may have modest benefit in hospitalized bronchiolitis patients but is not indicated in the emergency department or outpatient settings.

stem:
A 71-year-old woman with a history of Clostridioides difficile infection (CDI) 4 months ago (treated with oral vancomycin with resolution) presents with 5 days of watery diarrhea, abdominal cramping, and low-grade fever. She completed a course of ciprofloxacin for a urinary tract infection 2 weeks ago. Stool PCR for C. difficile toxin is positive. She has 6-8 loose stools daily, WBC is 11,200/μL, and creatinine is 1.0 mg/dL. She is hemodynamically stable and tolerating oral intake.

What is the most appropriate treatment?
options: [{"text":"Oral vancomycin 125 mg four times daily for 10 days","label":"A"},{"text":"Oral fidaxomicin 200 mg twice daily for 10 days","label":"B"},{"text":"Oral vancomycin tapered and pulsed regimen over 6 weeks","label":"C"},{"text":"Fecal microbiota transplantation","label":"D"},{"text":"Oral metronidazole 500 mg three times daily for 10 days","label":"E"}]
explanation: This patient has a first recurrence of CDI, which fundamentally changes the treatment approach. For first recurrence, fidaxomicin is preferred over standard-course vancomycin because it has demonstrated lower rates of subsequent recurrence. Fidaxomicin has a narrower spectrum with minimal disruption of the gut microbiome and achieves high fecal concentrations with sustained post-antibiotic effect against C. difficile spores. The IDSA/SHEA guidelines recommend fidaxomicin as the preferred agent for first recurrence, with a vancomycin taper/pulse regimen as an alternative. Standard 10-day vancomycin is no longer recommended for recurrent disease. Why Other Options Are Wrong: • A (Standard vancomycin): Not recommended for first recurrence due to higher recurrence rates compared to fidaxomicin. • C (Vancomycin taper/pulse): Acceptable alternative but fidaxomicin is preferred due to simpler regimen and efficacy data. • D (FMT): Reserved for multiple recurrences (typically ≥2 recurrences or ≥3 total episodes); premature for first recurrence. • E (Metronidazole): Not recommended for any recurrence or non-initial episodes due to inferior efficacy. High-Yield Takeaway: For first recurrence of C. difficile infection, fidaxomicin is the preferred treatment over standard vancomycin due to lower subsequent recurrence rates.

stem:
A 48-year-old woman is hospitalized with mild acute gallstone pancreatitis (Ranson score 1, no organ failure, CT shows interstitial edematous pancreatitis). By hospital day 3, her abdominal pain has resolved, she is tolerating a regular diet, and labs show lipase 180 U/L (down from 1,800 U/L), WBC 7,500/μL, and normal liver enzymes. Right upper quadrant ultrasound shows multiple gallstones with a normal common bile duct.

What is the most appropriate timing for cholecystectomy?
options: [{"text":"After 6 weeks to allow inflammation to resolve","label":"A"},{"text":"During this hospitalization before discharge","label":"B"},{"text":"Schedule electively within 2-4 weeks after discharge","label":"C"},{"text":"Only if recurrent pancreatitis occurs","label":"D"},{"text":"Perform ERCP with sphincterotomy instead of cholecystectomy","label":"E"}]
explanation: For mild gallstone pancreatitis without necrosis or other complications, cholecystectomy should be performed during the index hospitalization (same- admission cholecystectomy) once the patient has clinically recovered. This approach reduces the risk of recurrent biliary events, including recurrent pancreatitis (which occurs in 25-30% of patients within 6 weeks if cholecystectomy is delayed). Waiting 6 weeks was previously standard but has been shown to result in preventable recurrent events. Same-admission cholecystectomy is safe once pain resolves, diet is tolerated, and inflammatory markers are improving. Why Other Options Are Wrong: • A (After 6 weeks): Outdated; significantly increases recurrent biliary event risk. • C (2-4 weeks after discharge): Still delays intervention with unnecessary risk of interval recurrence. • D (Only if recurrence): Reactive approach leads to preventable recurrent pancreatitis and its complications. • E (ERCP with sphincterotomy): Does not eliminate gallbladder as stone source; reserved for common bile duct stones or patients unfit for surgery. High-Yield Takeaway: Cholecystectomy for mild gallstone pancreatitis should be performed during the same hospitalization once the patient has clinically recovered, not delayed for weeks.

stem:
A 67-year-old man with GOLD stage III COPD presents with 4 days of increased dyspnea and cough. He reports his sputum volume has increased but remains white-gray in color, similar to his baseline. He denies fever, chills, or chest pain. Vital signs show temperature 37.1°C, RR 22/min, SpO2 89% on room air (baseline 92%). Lung exam reveals diffuse expiratory wheezes without focal consolidation. Chest X-ray shows hyperinflation without infiltrate. He uses tiotropium and a fluticasone/salmeterol inhaler daily.

What is the most appropriate antibiotic management?
options: [{"text":"Azithromycin 500 mg daily for 3 days","label":"A"},{"text":"Amoxicillin-clavulanate 875 mg twice daily for 5 days","label":"B"},{"text":"Levofloxacin 750 mg daily for 5 days","label":"C"},{"text":"Doxycycline 100 mg twice daily for 7 days","label":"D"},{"text":"No antibiotics indicated at this time","label":"E"}]
explanation: This patient has a COPD exacerbation with only one Anthonisen criterion (increased dyspnea) without purulent sputum or significantly increased sputum volume beyond baseline. According to the Anthonisen classification, antibiotics are indicated for Type I exacerbations (all three cardinal symptoms: increased dyspnea, increased sputum volume, and sputum purulence) or Type II exacerbations if purulence is one of the two symptoms present. Sputum purulence is the strongest predictor of bacterial infection and antibiotic benefit. This patient has non-purulent sputum, making antibiotic therapy unlikely to provide benefit and exposing him to unnecessary side effects and resistance development. Management should focus on bronchodilators and systemic corticosteroids. Why Other Options Are Wrong: • A, B, C, D (Various antibiotics): All represent antibiotic therapy, which is not indicated without sputum purulence as a key criterion for bacterial involvement. High-Yield Takeaway: In COPD exacerbations, sputum purulence is the critical Anthonisen criterion driving antibiotic use; increased dyspnea and non-purulent sputum alone do not warrant antibiotics.

stem:
A 45-year-old woman with major depressive disorder has been on sertraline 200 mg daily (maximum dose) for 10 weeks. She reports some improvement—her sleep is better, and she no longer has passive suicidal ideation—but continues to have low energy, anhedonia, and poor concentration that impair her work function. PHQ-9 score has decreased from 22 to 14. She tolerates the medication well with no significant side effects.

What is the most appropriate next step in management?
options: [{"text":"Continue sertraline monotherapy and reassess in 4 more weeks","label":"A"},{"text":"Switch to a different SSRI","label":"B"},{"text":"Augment with aripiprazole","label":"C"},{"text":"Switch to venlafaxine","label":"D"},{"text":"Discontinue sertraline and start psychotherapy alone","label":"E"}]
explanation: This patient has a partial response to adequate SSRI therapy (maximum dose, adequate duration of 10 weeks). A partial response is defined as some improvement but with persistent clinically significant symptoms. In this scenario, augmentation is preferred over switching because the patient has shown benefit from the current medication. Switching would abandon gains and restart the clock on response. Atypical antipsychotics (aripiprazole, quetiapine, brexpiprazole) and other augmenting agents (bupropion, lithium, thyroid hormone) can enhance response to SSRIs. Aripiprazole has strong evidence for augmentation in partial responders. Why Other Options Are Wrong: • A (Continue and reassess): Already at maximum dose for adequate duration with only partial response; augmentation is indicated. • B (Switch to different SSRI): Switching is appropriate for non-responders or intolerance, not partial responders who have shown benefit. • D (Switch to venlafaxine): Switching classes loses current gains; augmentation preserves partial response. • E (Discontinue and use psychotherapy alone): Would abandon pharmacologic gains; psychotherapy can be added but medication should continue. High-Yield Takeaway: For partial SSRI response (some improvement but residual symptoms), augment with a second agent rather than switching medications.

stem:
A 24-year-old man with type 1 diabetes presents with altered mental status, Kussmaul respirations, and severe abdominal pain. Labs reveal glucose 580 mg/dL, pH 6.92, bicarbonate 4 mEq/L, anion gap 32, and potassium 2.9 mEq/L. He is hypotensive with BP 78/50 mmHg and tachycardic at 128 bpm. IV fluid resuscitation is initiated. Initial potassium replacement is started, but his pH continues to drop, and he is becoming increasingly obtunded.

What is the most appropriate next step?
options: [{"text":"Continue aggressive potassium replacement before starting insulin","label":"A"},{"text":"Start insulin infusion at 0.1 units/kg/hour immediately","label":"B"},{"text":"Administer sodium bicarbonate bolus","label":"C"},{"text":"Wait until potassium reaches 3.3 mEq/L before starting insulin","label":"D"},{"text":"Intubate for airway protection before any other intervention","label":"E"}]
explanation: The traditional teaching is to withhold insulin until potassium is ≥3.3 mEq/L because insulin drives potassium intracellularly and can precipitate fatal arrhythmias. However, in severe life-threatening acidosis (pH <7.0) with hemodynamic instability and altered mental status, the immediate threat is the acidosis itself. In this scenario, insulin should be started without delay while aggressively replacing potassium simultaneously. The rationale is that untreated severe acidosis will lead to death before hypokalemia can be corrected. Continuous cardiac monitoring and very aggressive potassium replacement (often via central access with rates up to 40 mEq/hour in ICU settings) accompany insulin initiation. Why Other Options Are Wrong: • A (Continue K+ replacement before insulin): Delays insulin in life-threatening acidosis; both should occur simultaneously. • C (Sodium bicarbonate): Not routinely recommended even in severe DKA; insulin and fluids correct acidosis. • D (Wait for K+ 3.3): Standard approach but overridden by life-threatening acidosis where delay is more dangerous. • E (Intubate first): May be needed but is not the immediate next step; metabolic management takes priority unless imminent respiratory arrest. High-Yield Takeaway: In DKA with life-threatening acidosis (pH <7.0), start insulin immediately despite K+ <3.3 mEq/L while aggressively replacing potassium simultaneously.

stem:
A 26-year-old woman with a 6-week ectopic pregnancy (β-hCG 2,800 mIU/mL, adnexal mass 2.5 cm, no fetal cardiac activity, hemodynamically stable) received single-dose methotrexate (50 mg/m²) 7 days ago.
