Update Todos Generate questions for concepts 1-7 Generate questions for concepts 8-14 Generate questions for concepts 15-21 BATCH 5 GENERATION COMPLETE Summary Concept # Concept ID Questions 1 incidental-pe-observation-criteria Q1.1, Q1.2 2 watchful-waiting-prostate-cancer Q2.1, Q2.2 Concept # Concept ID Questions 3 benign-pvc-no-ablation Q3.1, Q3.2 4 small-kidney-stone-expectant Q4.1, Q4.2 5 stable-carotid-stenosis-medical-only Q5.1, Q5.2 6 aortic-aneurysm-surveillance-threshold Q6.1, Q6.2 7 low-risk-syncope-discharge-criteria Q7.1, Q7.2 8 antibiotic-stewardship-viral-uri Q8.1, Q8.2 9 chest-pain-low-risk-outpatient-workup Q9.1, Q9.2 10 asymptomatic-gallstones-no-surgery Q10.1, Q10.2 11 mild-diverticulosis-no-antibiotics Q11.1, Q11.2 12 pre-diabetes-lifestyle-before-metformin Q12.1, Q12.2 13 grade1-varicocele-observation Q13.1, Q13.2 14 benign-liver-hemangioma-no-imaging Q14.1, Q14.2 15 simple-renal-cyst-no-followup Q15.1, Q15.2 16 low-grade-cervical-dysplasia-observe Q16.1, Q16.2 17 deprescribing-ppi-long-term Q17.1, Q17.2 18 statin-discontinuation-elderly-frail Q18.1, Q18.2 19 stopping-osteoporosis-drug-holiday Q19.1, Q19.2 20 incidental-thyroid-nodule-stop-surveillance Q20.1, Q20.2 21 adrenal-incidentaloma-stop-followup Q21.1, Q21.2 Total: 42 questions across 21 concepts Each concept includes: • One question testing the "when NOT to intervene" decision • One question testing the boundary/exception where intervention IS warranted Ready for review or export to QBank format.

stem:
A 34-year-old woman presents with palpitations. Holter monitor shows 8,000 PVCs over 24 hours (8% burden), all monomorphic with LBBB morphology suggesting right ventricular outflow tract origin. Echocardiogram shows normal LV function (EF 62%) and no structural abnormalities. She describes the palpitations as "annoying but not disabling."

What is the most appropriate management?
options: [{"text":"Catheter ablation of the PVC focus","label":"A"},{"text":"Amiodarone for rhythm suppression","label":"B"},{"text":"Reassurance and lifestyle modification","label":"C"},{"text":"Implantable cardioverter-defibrillator","label":"D"},{"text":"Flecainide for PVC suppression","label":"E"}]
explanation: Monomorphic PVCs from the RVOT in a structurally normal heart are typically benign. PVC burden <10-15% with preserved EF does not require intervention. The patient's symptoms are tolerable, and there is no evidence of PVC- induced cardiomyopathy. Reassurance, caffeine reduction, and stress management are first-line. Ablation is reserved for high burden (>15-20%) with LV dysfunction or severely symptomatic patients refractory to conservative measures. Antiarrhythmics carry proarrhythmic risk without clear benefit here.

stem:
A 52-year-old man with frequent PVCs undergoes serial echocardiography. Initial EF was 60%; repeat study 6 months later shows EF 48%. PVC burden on Holter is 22%. He now reports dyspnea on exertion.

Which factor most supports proceeding with catheter ablation?
options: [{"text":"PVC burden >20%","label":"A"},{"text":"Decline in EF from 60% to 48%","label":"B"},{"text":"New dyspnea on exertion","label":"C"},{"text":"All of the above together indicate PVC-induced cardiomyopathy","label":"D"},{"text":"Monomorphic PVC morphology","label":"E"}]
explanation: The combination of high PVC burden (>15-20%), declining EF, and new heart failure symptoms defines PVC-induced cardiomyopathy—a reversible condition if the ectopic focus is eliminated. Each factor alone is insufficient: some patients tolerate high burden without LV dysfunction; EF decline may have other causes; dyspnea is nonspecific. The constellation together makes the diagnosis and supports ablation, which can restore normal EF. Monomorphic morphology simply indicates a single focus amenable to ablation.

stem:
A 42-year-old man presents with acute left flank pain. Non-contrast CT shows a 3 mm stone in the left proximal ureter with mild hydronephrosis. Pain is controlled with ketorolac. Creatinine is 0.9 mg/dL, and he is afebrile with no signs of infection.

What is the most appropriate management?
options: [{"text":"Emergent ureteroscopy","label":"A"},{"text":"Extracorporeal shock wave lithotripsy","label":"B"},{"text":"Ureteral stent placement","label":"C"},{"text":"Medical expulsive therapy and observation","label":"D"},{"text":"Percutaneous nephrostomy","label":"E"}]
explanation: Stones ≤5 mm have >90% spontaneous passage rate. This patient has a 3 mm stone, controlled pain, no infection, and preserved renal function. Medical expulsive therapy (alpha-blocker such as tamsulosin) may facilitate passage. Observation with adequate hydration and pain control is appropriate. Urgent intervention is reserved for: stones >10 mm, uncontrolled pain, infection/sepsis, AKI, or solitary kidney with obstruction. Proceeding directly to ureteroscopy or lithotripsy would be overtreatment.

stem:
A 38-year-old woman is found to have a 4 mm non-obstructing lower pole renal calculus on CT performed for unrelated abdominal pain. She is asymptomatic and has no history of kidney stones. Urinalysis is normal.

What is the most appropriate recommendation?
options: [{"text":"24-hour urine metabolic evaluation","label":"A"},{"text":"Extracorporeal shock wave lithotripsy","label":"B"},{"text":"Observation without routine follow-up imaging","label":"C"},{"text":"Ureteroscopic stone removal","label":"D"},{"text":"Annual CT surveillance","label":"E"}]
explanation: Asymptomatic, small (<5 mm), non-obstructing renal stones in patients without prior stone history can be observed without intervention or routine surveillance imaging. Most will never cause symptoms. The radiation exposure and cost of annual CT are not justified. Metabolic workup is typically reserved for recurrent stone formers or larger stones. Intervention is unnecessary for an incidental finding that poses minimal risk.

stem:
A 71-year-old man with hypertension and hyperlipidemia is found to have an asymptomatic 55% right carotid stenosis on duplex ultrasound performed for a carotid bruit. He has never had a stroke or TIA. He takes lisinopril, atorvastatin 80 mg, and aspirin 81 mg daily. BP today is 126/74.

What is the most appropriate management?
options: [{"text":"Carotid endarterectomy","label":"A"},{"text":"Carotid artery stenting","label":"B"},{"text":"Continue current medical therapy without intervention","label":"C"},{"text":"Add clopidogrel for dual antiplatelet therapy","label":"D"},{"text":"Increase aspirin to 325 mg daily","label":"E"}]
explanation: Asymptomatic carotid stenosis <60-70% does not meet threshold for intervention. Even at higher grades (60-79%), the benefit of carotid endarterectomy (CEA) in asymptomatic patients is marginal with modern medical therapy. The CREST-2 trial is investigating whether intensive medical therapy alone is sufficient. This patient is on optimal medical management (high-intensity statin, aspirin, BP control). Adding clopidogrel or escalating aspirin dose has no proven benefit and increases bleeding risk. Observation with continued medical optimization is appropriate.

stem:
A 68-year-old woman with asymptomatic 72% left carotid stenosis asks about surgery. She has well-controlled diabetes, hypertension, and takes rosuvastatin 40 mg daily. Her estimated surgical risk (stroke/death) at your institution is 4%.

Which statement best describes the rationale for recommending medical management over CEA?
options: [{"text":"Her stenosis is below the intervention threshold","label":"A"},{"text":"Surgical risk exceeds expected benefit in asymptomatic stenosis","label":"B"},{"text":"She should wait until she develops symptoms","label":"C"},{"text":"Carotid stenting is preferred over CEA in diabetics","label":"D"},{"text":"Statins eliminate the need for any intervention","label":"E"}]
explanation: For asymptomatic carotid stenosis, CEA benefit is modest (ARR ~1%/year for stroke). Guidelines recommend intervention only if perioperative risk is <3%. At 4% institutional risk, expected surgical harm exceeds benefit. Modern medical therapy (high-intensity statins, antiplatelets, BP/glucose control) has improved outcomes for asymptomatic stenosis, narrowing the gap with surgical intervention. Waiting for symptoms is not advisable—symptomatic stenosis carries higher stroke risk. The decision hinges on balancing procedural risk against annual stroke risk reduction.

stem:
A 65-year-old man undergoes abdominal ultrasound for unrelated symptoms, revealing a 4.2 cm infrarenal abdominal aortic aneurysm. He is asymptomatic, normotensive, and a former smoker. He has no family history of aneurysm rupture.

What is the most appropriate management?
options: [{"text":"Immediate referral for endovascular repair","label":"A"},{"text":"Open surgical repair within 30 days","label":"B"},{"text":"CT angiography with surgical planning","label":"C"},{"text":"Repeat ultrasound in 12 months","label":"D"},{"text":"Repeat ultrasound in 6 months","label":"E"}]
explanation: AAA repair is indicated when diameter reaches 5.5 cm in men (5.0 cm in women) or growth exceeds 0.5 cm in 6 months. At 4.2 cm, the annual rupture risk is <1%. Surveillance intervals are size-dependent: 3.0-3.9 cm = every 3 years; 4.0-4.9 cm = every 12 months; 5.0-5.4 cm = every 6 months. This patient appropriately receives annual surveillance. Operating on a 4.2 cm aneurysm would expose him to procedural risk (1-2% mortality for elective repair) without proportionate benefit.

stem:
A 70-year-old woman has a known 4.8 cm AAA, increased from 4.5 cm one year ago. She is asymptomatic. Her surgical risk is considered average.

What is the most appropriate recommendation?
options: [{"text":"Elective repair given growth rate","label":"A"},{"text":"Continue annual surveillance","label":"B"},{"text":"Repeat imaging in 6 months","label":"C"},{"text":"Emergency vascular surgery consultation","label":"D"},{"text":"MRA in 3 months","label":"E"}]
explanation: AAA growth of 0.3 cm/year is typical and does not mandate intervention. However, as aneurysm size approaches the threshold (5.0 cm for women, 5.5 cm for men), surveillance intervals should shorten. At 4.8 cm in a woman, she is near the 5.0 cm threshold, warranting 6-month follow-up to detect accelerated growth. If the next study shows ≥5.0 cm or >0.5 cm growth in 6 months, repair should be offered. Annual surveillance would be insufficient given proximity to threshold.

stem:
A 28-year-old woman presents to the ED after fainting while standing in line at a concert. She recalls feeling warm and nauseated before losing consciousness briefly. She did not have convulsive activity or incontinence. On exam, she is fully alert with BP 118/72, HR 68, and normal cardiac and neurologic examinations. ECG shows normal sinus rhythm, normal intervals, and no concerning morphology.

What is the most appropriate disposition?
options: [{"text":"Admit for telemetry monitoring","label":"A"},{"text":"Discharge with outpatient Holter monitor","label":"B"},{"text":"Discharge with reassurance and return precautions","label":"C"},{"text":"Echocardiography before discharge","label":"D"},{"text":"Electrophysiology consultation","label":"E"}]
explanation: This presentation is classic vasovagal syncope: prodrome (warmth, nausea), situational trigger (prolonged standing, hot environment), rapid recovery, and no red flags. The San Francisco Syncope Rule and Canadian Syncope Risk Score identify this as low-risk. Young patients with typical vasovagal features, normal ECG, and normal vital signs do not require admission, telemetry, or extensive workup. Reassurance with advice on prodrome recognition, hydration, and counter- pressure maneuvers is appropriate. Outpatient follow-up with PCP is reasonable.

stem:
A 72-year-old man presents after syncope while sitting at dinner. He lost consciousness without warning and woke up on the floor. He has hypertension and takes amlodipine. BP is 142/88, HR 76, and he appears well. ECG shows sinus rhythm with a PR interval of 220 ms and left anterior fascicular block.

What is the most appropriate next step?
options: [{"text":"Discharge with outpatient loop recorder","label":"A"},{"text":"Admit for cardiac monitoring","label":"B"},{"text":"Reassurance and discharge","label":"C"},{"text":"Carotid sinus massage","label":"D"},{"text":"CT head before discharge","label":"E"}]
explanation: This patient has multiple high-risk features: older age, syncope without prodrome (sudden LOC), syncope while seated (not orthostatic), and conduction abnormalities on ECG (prolonged PR + LAFB suggesting bifascicular block with risk of progression to complete heart block). Bifascicular block with unexplained syncope carries significant risk for bradyarrhythmic events. Admission for telemetry and possible electrophysiology evaluation is warranted. Discharging this patient—even with outpatient monitoring—risks missing high-grade AV block. Update Todos Generate questions for concepts 1-7 Generating questions for concepts 8-14 Generate questions for concepts 15-21

stem:
A 35-year-old woman presents with 4 days of nasal congestion, clear rhinorrhea, sore throat, and mild cough. She has low- grade fever (100.2°F). Exam shows clear nasal discharge, mildly erythematous pharynx without exudate, and clear lungs. She requests antibiotics because she "can't miss work."

What is the most appropriate management?
options: [{"text":"Amoxicillin for 5 days","label":"A"},{"text":"Azithromycin for 3 days","label":"B"},{"text":"Amoxicillin-clavulanate for 7 days","label":"C"},{"text":"Symptomatic treatment with reassurance","label":"D"},{"text":"Rapid strep test and treat if positive","label":"E"}]
explanation: This presentation—nasal symptoms, clear rhinorrhea, sore throat without exudate, and cough—is consistent with viral upper respiratory infection. Antibiotics provide no benefit for viral URI and contribute to resistance, adverse effects, and unnecessary cost. Guidelines recommend against antibiotics for uncomplicated URI regardless of symptom duration <10 days. Symptomatic care (decongestants, NSAIDs, hydration) and reassurance about expected 7-10 day course is appropriate. Rapid strep testing is low-yield without tonsillar exudate, fever >101°F, or anterior cervical lymphadenopathy.

stem:
A 42-year-old man presents with nasal congestion and facial pressure for 6 days. He has green nasal discharge. He is afebrile with mild maxillary tenderness. He is otherwise well and has no immunocompromise.

What is the most appropriate recommendation?
options: [{"text":"Amoxicillin-clavulanate for acute bacterial sinusitis","label":"A"},{"text":"CT sinus to confirm bacterial infection","label":"B"},{"text":"Continued symptomatic treatment with re-evaluation if worsening","label":"C"},{"text":"Azithromycin for atypical pathogen coverage","label":"D"},{"text":"Intranasal corticosteroids alone","label":"E"}]
explanation: Purulent (green/yellow) nasal discharge does NOT indicate bacterial infection—it reflects neutrophil activity common in viral illness. Acute bacterial rhinosinusitis is diagnosed clinically when symptoms persist ≥10 days without improvement, or with "double-worsening" (improvement then deterioration), or severe onset (fever ≥102°F with purulent discharge for 3-4 days). At 6 days, this patient has uncomplicated viral rhinosinusitis. Antibiotics are not indicated. Continued symptomatic care with saline irrigation and analgesics is appropriate. CT imaging is not needed for uncomplicated cases.

stem:
A 38-year-old woman presents to the ED with sharp, left-sided chest pain that worsens with deep breathing and position changes. She has no cardiac risk factors. Vital signs are normal. ECG shows normal sinus rhythm without ST changes. Troponin is negative at 0 and 3 hours. HEART score is 1.

What is the most appropriate disposition?
options: [{"text":"Admit for serial troponins and telemetry","label":"A"},{"text":"Stress testing before discharge","label":"B"},{"text":"CT coronary angiography before discharge","label":"C"},{"text":"Discharge with PCP follow-up","label":"D"},{"text":"Cardiology consultation","label":"E"}]
explanation: HEART score ≤3 indicates low risk (<2% 30-day MACE). This patient has pleuritic, positional chest pain—features atypical for ACS—plus negative troponins and normal ECG. The HEART Pathway validates early discharge without stress testing for low-risk patients. Further cardiac workup (stress test, CTA) in a low-risk patient with non-cardiac features has poor yield and may generate false positives leading to invasive testing. Discharge with PCP follow-up for consideration of musculoskeletal or pleuritic etiologies is appropriate.

stem:
A 52-year-old man with hypertension and obesity presents with exertional substernal chest pressure that resolves with rest. In the ED, he is pain-free. ECG is normal. Troponin is negative at 0 and 3 hours. HEART score is 4.

What is the most appropriate next step?
options: [{"text":"Discharge with outpatient stress test within 72 hours","label":"A"},{"text":"Inpatient stress test before discharge","label":"B"},{"text":"Admit for observation and serial troponins","label":"C"},{"text":"CT coronary angiography","label":"D"},{"text":"Discharge with cardiology follow-up in 2 weeks","label":"E"}]
explanation: HEART score 4-6 represents intermediate risk (~12-16% 30-day MACE). This patient has typical anginal symptoms but negative initial workup. Guidelines support either inpatient stress testing OR expedited outpatient testing within 72 hours for intermediate-risk patients who are clinically stable with reliable follow-up. Immediate discharge without any stress testing (answer E) misses the intermediate-risk classification. Admitting all intermediate-risk patients is resource-intensive; outpatient accelerated pathways are validated. The key is ensuring prompt testing access.

stem:
A 58-year-old man presents to the emergency department with acute-onset chest pain radiating to his left arm. Initial ECG shows ST elevations in leads V1-V4, and troponin I is elevated at 2.4 ng/mL. He is diagnosed with STEMI and taken for emergent cardiac catheterization, which reveals clean coronary arteries. Post-procedure, he develops hypotension (BP 82/50 mmHg), muffled heart sounds, and jugular venous distension. A repeat ECG now shows low voltage and electrical alternans. The cardiology fellow suggests increasing the heparin drip and adding a second antiplatelet agent.

What is the most appropriate next step in management?
options: [{"text":"Increase heparin infusion rate","label":"A"},{"text":"Administer IV nitroprusside","label":"B"},{"text":"Perform emergent pericardiocentesis","label":"C"},{"text":"Order repeat coronary angiography","label":"D"}]
explanation: This patient initially presented with findings suggestive of STEMI but had clean coronaries on catheterization. The new triad of hypotension, muffled heart sounds, and JVD (Beck's triad), combined with electrical alternans on ECG, indicates cardiac tamponade—likely from aortic dissection that was missed due to anchoring on the initial STEMI diagnosis. The cognitive error here is failing to revise the diagnosis when new data (clean coronaries, hemodynamic instability, Beck's triad) contradicts the initial impression. Emergent pericardiocentesis is life-saving. Why the Wrong Answer is Tempting: The fellow's suggestion to increase anticoagulation (Choice A) follows logically from the original STEMI framework. Repeating angiography (Choice D) assumes the original diagnosis was correct but incomplete. These choices appeal to those who remain anchored to the initial diagnosis despite clear evidence of a different pathology. NBME Trap Callout: When catheterization doesn't match clinical presentation, STOP—reconsider the diagnosis entirely. Clean coronaries + hemodynamic collapse = think aortic dissection with tamponade.

stem:
A 45-year-old obese woman presents with 6 hours of severe right upper quadrant pain, nausea, and vomiting after eating fried chicken. Temperature is 37.2°C, blood pressure 138/85 mmHg, and pulse 92/min. Physical examination reveals tenderness in the right upper quadrant with a positive Murphy sign. Laboratory studies show WBC 11,200/μL, AST 52 U/L, ALT 48 U/L, alkaline phosphatase 95 U/L, and total bilirubin 1.1 mg/dL. The intern orders a CT scan of the abdomen with contrast.

Which of the following is the most appropriate imaging study for this patient?
options: [{"text":"CT abdomen with IV contrast","label":"A"},{"text":"Right upper quadrant ultrasound","label":"B"},{"text":"MRCP","label":"C"},{"text":"HIDA scan","label":"D"}]
explanation: This patient has a classic presentation for acute cholecystitis (postprandial RUQ pain, Murphy sign, mild leukocytosis). The first-line imaging modality is right upper quadrant ultrasound, which can visualize gallstones, gallbladder wall thickening, pericholecystic fluid, and sonographic Murphy sign with high sensitivity and no radiation. The cognitive error is over-ordering advanced imaging when a cheaper, faster, radiation-free bedside test is diagnostic. CT is less sensitive for gallstones and delays diagnosis. Why the Wrong Answer is Tempting: CT (Choice A) feels more "thorough" and is often reflexively ordered in abdominal pain. HIDA scan (Choice D) is useful for acalculous cholecystitis or when ultrasound is equivocal—not as first-line. MRCP (Choice C) is reserved for suspected choledocholithiasis, which the normal bilirubin and alkaline phosphatase argue against. NBME Trap Callout: In biliary disease, ultrasound comes first. CT is not more accurate for gallstones and adds radiation, cost, and delay.

stem:
An 82-year-old woman is brought from her nursing home for evaluation of increased confusion over 2 days. She has a history of dementia, hypertension, and recurrent UTIs. Temperature is 36.8°C, blood pressure 128/76 mmHg, and pulse 78/min. She is oriented to person only but is at her baseline mental status per nursing home records. Physical examination reveals no costovertebral angle tenderness, suprapubic tenderness, or dysuria on Foley catheter irrigation. Urinalysis shows 50+ WBC, positive leukocyte esterase, positive nitrites, and many bacteria. Urine culture is pending. The resident requests approval to start ciprofloxacin.

What is the most appropriate next step in management?
options: [{"text":"Start ciprofloxacin 500 mg twice daily for 7 days","label":"A"},{"text":"Start ceftriaxone 1 g IV daily and admit","label":"B"},{"text":"Obtain blood cultures and start broad-spectrum antibiotics","label":"C"},{"text":"Remove the Foley catheter and observe","label":"D"}]
explanation: This patient has asymptomatic bacteriuria, not a urinary tract infection. She is afebrile, hemodynamically stable, has no urinary symptoms, and her confusion is at baseline. Pyuria and bacteriuria are nearly universal in catheterized elderly patients and do not mandate treatment without symptoms. The cognitive error is treating the lab result rather than the patient. Removing the catheter (if no longer needed) and observation is appropriate. Unnecessary antibiotics promote resistance and cause harm (C. difficile, drug reactions). Why the Wrong Answer is Tempting: The urinalysis looks "dirty" with WBCs, nitrites, and bacteria—this reflexively triggers the UTI treatment algorithm. Altered mental status in the elderly is often blamed on UTI, but without new symptoms or fever, this is attribution error. NBME Trap Callout: Never treat asymptomatic bacteriuria in non-pregnant adults. Pyuria + bacteria + no symptoms = colonization, not infection.

stem:
A 64-year-old man with COPD is hospitalized for community-acquired pneumonia and started on ceftriaxone and azithromycin. On hospital day 2, he remains febrile (38.4°C) but reports feeling slightly better. Oxygen saturation is 94% on 2L nasal cannula (improved from 89% on room air at admission). Blood pressure is 132/78 mmHg. Sputum and blood cultures from admission are pending. The night resident suggests changing antibiotics to piperacillin-tazobactam and vancomycin because the patient "isn't responding."

What is the most appropriate next step in management?
options: [{"text":"Escalate to piperacillin-tazobactam and vancomycin","label":"A"},{"text":"Continue current antibiotics and await culture results","label":"B"},{"text":"Obtain CT chest to evaluate for abscess or empyema","label":"C"},{"text":"Add levofloxacin for double coverage of atypicals","label":"D"}]
explanation: This patient is showing clinical improvement (better oxygenation, subjective improvement) despite persistent low-grade fever on day 2. Fever can persist for 48-72 hours after appropriate antibiotic initiation—this is expected, not failure. The cognitive error is premature antibiotic escalation before allowing time for response or obtaining microbiologic data. Broadening coverage reflexively increases resistance pressure, adverse effects, and costs without evidence of treatment failure. Why the Wrong Answer is Tempting: Persistent fever triggers anxiety that "we're missing something" or "coverage isn't broad enough." Escalating to broad-spectrum agents (Choice A) feels proactive. However, clinical trajectory matters more than temperature alone at 48 hours. NBME Trap Callout: Day 2-3 fever with improving clinical status is NOT antibiotic failure. Wait for cultures before escalating.

stem:
A 71-year-old man with heart failure with reduced ejection fraction (EF 30%) presents to the emergency department with worsening dyspnea over 3 days. He has 2+ bilateral lower extremity edema, jugular venous distension to 12 cm, and bibasilar crackles. Blood pressure is 88/62 mmHg, and pulse is 102/min. He is started on IV furosemide with good urine output. The ED physician plans to add carvedilol because the patient "isn't on a beta-blocker despite class I indication."

Which of the following is the most appropriate response to this plan?
options: [{"text":"Agree and start carvedilol 3.125 mg twice daily","label":"A"},{"text":"Recommend starting carvedilol after discharge when euvolemic","label":"B"},{"text":"Suggest metoprolol succinate instead of carvedilol","label":"C"},{"text":"Add digoxin for rate control before beta-blocker","label":"D"}]
explanation: While beta-blockers are guideline-directed medical therapy for HFrEF, they should never be initiated during acute decompensation. This patient is hypotensive and volume-overloaded—starting a negative inotrope now could precipitate cardiogenic shock. The cognitive error is confusing chronic optimization therapy with acute stabilization needs. Beta-blockers should be started or uptitrated only after the patient is euvolemic, stable, and ideally as an outpatient or before discharge. Why the Wrong Answer is Tempting: Beta-blockers have mortality benefit in HFrEF—this is hammered into trainees. The reflexive application of "missing guideline-directed therapy" during hospitalization overlooks that timing matters as much as drug choice. NBME Trap Callout: Never start beta-blockers in acute decompensated heart failure. Stabilize first, optimize later.

stem:
A 34-year-old woman presents with 3 weeks of fatigue and intermittent palpitations. She denies chest pain, syncope, or dyspnea. She drinks 4-5 cups of coffee daily and has been under significant work stress. Physical examination is unremarkable with regular heart rate of 76/min. ECG shows normal sinus rhythm. TSH, CBC, and comprehensive metabolic panel are normal. 24-hour Holter monitor shows occasional PACs, no sustained arrhythmias. She returns 2 weeks later still feeling palpitations. The attending suggests repeating the Holter monitor and adding an echocardiogram.

What is the most appropriate next step in management?
options: [{"text":"Repeat 24-hour Holter monitor","label":"A"},{"text":"Order transthoracic echocardiogram","label":"B"},{"text":"Reassurance and lifestyle modification counseling","label":"C"},{"text":"Start metoprolol for symptom control","label":"D"}]
explanation: This young, healthy patient with benign palpitations (isolated PACs, normal ECG, normal labs, no red flags) has completed an appropriate workup. Repeating the same negative tests will not provide new information and reinforces illness anxiety. The cognitive error is over-testing when observation and reassurance are indicated. Excessive caffeine and stress are the likely culprits. Counseling on reducing caffeine and stress management is the appropriate intervention. Why the Wrong Answer is Tempting: Repeating tests (A, B) feels thorough and patient-centered. An echocardiogram seems "harmless." However, low-yield testing reinforces somatization, delays reassurance, and wastes resources. Beta-blockers (D) medicalize a benign condition unnecessarily. NBME Trap Callout: A negative workup doesn't need repeating. Reassurance IS management.

stem:
A 52-year-old man presents with progressive dysphagia to solids over 4 months and 15- pound unintentional weight loss. He has a 30-pack-year smoking history. Physical examination reveals a thin, anxious man with no palpable lymphadenopathy. The medical student presents the case and recommends CT chest/abdomen/pelvis as the next step "because it's the most sensitive for staging esophageal cancer."

What is the most appropriate next step in management?
options: [{"text":"CT chest/abdomen/pelvis with contrast","label":"A"},{"text":"Upper endoscopy with biopsy","label":"B"},{"text":"Barium swallow study","label":"C"},{"text":"PET-CT for staging","label":"D"}]
explanation: This patient has alarm symptoms (progressive dysphagia, weight loss, smoking history) concerning for esophageal malignancy. While CT and PET-CT are used for staging confirmed cancer, the next best step is tissue diagnosis via upper endoscopy with biopsy. The cognitive error is selecting the "most accurate" test for a later stage of workup rather than the immediate next step. You cannot stage a cancer you haven't diagnosed. Endoscopy allows visualization AND biopsy in one procedure. Why the Wrong Answer is Tempting: CT and PET sound more advanced and comprehensive. Students often conflate "most accurate" with "next best step." Staging workup is premature without histopathologic confirmation. NBME Trap Callout: "Next best step" means the immediate action, not the ultimate diagnostic pathway. Tissue diagnosis precedes staging.

stem:
A 78-year-old man presents with 1 week of fatigue, dizziness, and near-syncope. He has hypertension, type 2 diabetes, and benign prostatic hyperplasia. Medications include lisinopril 20 mg daily, metformin 1000 mg twice daily, and tamsulosin 0.4 mg at bedtime. He was recently started on a new medication by his urologist for urinary symptoms. Blood pressure is 98/58 mmHg sitting, with a drop to 82/50 mmHg upon standing. Pulse increases from 72 to 94/min on standing. The intern orders a tilt table test and cardiology consult.

What is the most appropriate next step in management?
options: [{"text":"Tilt table testing","label":"A"},{"text":"Echocardiogram","label":"B"},{"text":"Medication review and adjustment","label":"C"},{"text":"24-hour ambulatory blood pressure monitoring","label":"D"}]
explanation: This patient has classic orthostatic hypotension (≥20 mmHg systolic drop with symptoms) that developed after a new medication was added. Alpha-blockers like tamsulosin commonly cause orthostatic hypotension, especially when combined with other antihypertensives (lisinopril). The cognitive error is overlooking iatrogenic causes when new symptoms follow medication changes. A thorough medication reconciliation identifying the temporal relationship would reveal the culprit. Expensive cardiac workup is unnecessary. Why the Wrong Answer is Tempting: Dizziness and near-syncope in an elderly man triggers reflexive cardiac workup (echo, tilt table). These tests are appropriate when medication causes are excluded—but medication review should always come first for new symptoms after prescription changes. NBME Trap Callout: New symptom after new medication = medication side effect until proven otherwise. Check the med list first.

stem:
A 45-year-old woman is admitted for elective cholecystectomy. Preoperative labs reveal serum sodium of 128 mEq/L. She is asymptomatic, alert, and oriented. Blood pressure is 122/78 mmHg. She takes hydrochlorothiazide for hypertension. Serum osmolality is 270 mOsm/kg, and urine osmolality is 450 mOsm/kg. The surgical team requests that medicine "correct the sodium" before proceeding to the operating room, suggesting 3% hypertonic saline infusion.

What is the most appropriate next step in management?
options: [{"text":"Administer 3% hypertonic saline","label":"A"},{"text":"Hold hydrochlorothiazide and reassess sodium in 24-48 hours","label":"B"},{"text":"Cancel surgery indefinitely until sodium normalizes","label":"C"},{"text":"Fluid restrict to 1 liter per day","label":"D"}]
explanation: This patient has chronic, asymptomatic, mild hyponatremia likely secondary to thiazide diuretics. Hypertonic saline is indicated only for severe symptomatic hyponatremia (seizures, obtundation)—using it here risks osmotic demyelination syndrome. The cognitive error is treating a lab value rather than the patient's clinical status. Holding the thiazide and allowing gentle self-correction is appropriate. Mild chronic hyponatremia (>125 mEq/L) in an asymptomatic patient does not preclude surgery. Why the Wrong Answer is Tempting: Abnormal labs before surgery create anxiety. "Correcting" the number feels prudent. However, aggressive correction of chronic hyponatremia is dangerous, and the lab abnormality alone doesn't warrant intervention in an asymptomatic patient. NBME Trap Callout: Asymptomatic + chronic + mild = no urgent correction needed. Treat the patient, not the number.

stem:
A 48-year-old man presents with substernal chest pressure for 2 hours, radiating to his left arm, with associated diaphoresis. He has hypertension and smokes 1 pack per day. ECG shows no ST changes. Initial troponin I is negative (<0.01 ng/mL). The physician tells the patient his "heart tests are negative" and prepares discharge paperwork with a diagnosis of musculoskeletal chest pain, instructing follow-up with his primary care physician.

What is the most appropriate next step in management?
options: [{"text":"Discharge with outpatient stress test in 1 week","label":"A"},{"text":"Admit for serial troponins and observation","label":"B"},{"text":"Obtain CT coronary angiography before discharge","label":"C"},{"text":"Administer GI cocktail and reassess","label":"D"}]
explanation: This patient has multiple risk factors and a classic ACS presentation. A single negative troponin does NOT rule out myocardial infarction—troponins may take 4-6 hours to rise after ischemia onset. The cognitive error is premature closure, accepting a negative initial test as definitive despite high pretest probability. Serial troponins (typically at 0 and 3-6 hours) are required. Discharging this patient risks missed NSTEMI and death. Why the Wrong Answer is Tempting: A negative troponin provides false reassurance. Combined with a non-diagnostic ECG, it's tempting to conclude "no MI." However, ruling out ACS requires serial markers, not a snapshot. NBME Trap Callout: One negative troponin at presentation does NOT rule out MI. High-risk chest pain requires serial biomarkers. Update Todos Generate Internal Medicine questions (10 concepts) Generating Surgery questions Generate Pediatrics questions (5 concepts) Generate OB/GYN questions (4 concepts) Generate Psychiatry questions (4 concepts) Generate Neurology questions (4 concepts) Generate Emergency Medicine questions (4 concepts) Generate Pulm/Critical Care questions (3 concepts) Generate Nephrology questions (2 concepts) SURGERY

stem:
A 67-year-old man presents to the emergency department with sudden-onset severe abdominal pain for 3 hours. He has a history of atrial fibrillation and is not on anticoagulation. Temperature is 37.6°C, blood pressure is 92/58 mmHg, pulse is 112/min and irregularly irregular. Abdomen is diffusely tender but notably soft—the pain appears out of proportion to physical findings. Lactate is 6.2 mmol/L. The ED physician orders a CT angiogram of the abdomen and tells the surgical resident, "I'll call you when I have the imaging results."

What is the most appropriate next step in management?
options: [{"text":"Await CT angiography results before surgical consultation","label":"A"},{"text":"Immediate surgical consultation concurrent with imaging","label":"B"},{"text":"Start IV heparin before imaging","label":"C"},{"text":"Obtain plain abdominal X-ray first","label":"D"}]
explanation: This patient has classic findings of acute mesenteric ischemia: atrial fibrillation (embolic source), pain out of proportion to exam, elevated lactate, and hemodynamic instability. This is a surgical emergency. The cognitive error is delaying surgical involvement for confirmatory imaging when clinical suspicion is high. Surgery should be consulted immediately—they need time to prepare while imaging is obtained. Waiting for CT results before calling surgery wastes critical time in a condition where bowel viability deteriorates by the hour. Why the Wrong Answer is Tempting: Physicians are trained to have "all the data" before consulting specialists to avoid appearing unprepared. However, in surgical emergencies, parallel processing (imaging + surgical notification) saves lives. The CT confirms diagnosis but shouldn't delay mobilization. NBME Trap Callout: Suspected surgical emergency = call surgery NOW, not after imaging confirms it. Time is bowel.

stem:
A 72-year-old man with a known 5.8 cm infrarenal abdominal aortic aneurysm presents for routine follow-up. He is asymptomatic. CT angiography from 6 months ago showed the aneurysm measured 5.3 cm. Current imaging shows expansion to 5.8 cm. He has well-controlled hypertension and quit smoking 10 years ago. Surgical risk assessment estimates 2% perioperative mortality. The patient asks if he can "wait another year" since he feels fine and wants to attend his granddaughter's wedding in 8 months.

What is the most appropriate recommendation?
options: [{"text":"Agree to delay repair for 1 year with close surveillance","label":"A"},{"text":"Recommend elective repair within the next few weeks","label":"B"},{"text":"Refer for emergent repair today","label":"C"},{"text":"Repeat imaging in 3 months before deciding","label":"D"}]
explanation: AAA ≥5.5 cm (or expansion >0.5 cm in 6 months) meets criteria for elective surgical repair in acceptable-risk patients. This patient has both: size threshold AND rapid expansion. The cognitive error is misidentifying urgency level—this isn't emergent (no rupture), but delaying elective repair significantly increases rupture risk. The annual rupture risk for 5.5-6 cm AAA is approximately 10%. Waiting a year is not appropriate; repair should be scheduled soon. Why the Wrong Answer is Tempting: The patient is asymptomatic and has a reasonable request (family event). Emergent repair (C) isn't indicated without rupture. But "elective" doesn't mean "optional"—it means "planned, non-emergent." Deferring past threshold invites catastrophe. NBME Trap Callout: "Elective" surgery can still be urgent. AAA ≥5.5 cm = repair soon, not "whenever convenient."

stem:
A 55-year-old woman undergoes CT abdomen/pelvis for evaluation of kidney stones. The scan reveals a 2 cm simple hepatic cyst in the right lobe, an incidental finding. She is asymptomatic from the cyst. Liver function tests are normal. The radiologist notes: "Simple cyst, benign features, no follow-up needed." The surgeon on call is consulted and recommends laparoscopic cyst fenestration "to prevent future complications."

What is the most appropriate management of the hepatic cyst?
options: [{"text":"Laparoscopic cyst fenestration","label":"A"},{"text":"CT-guided aspiration with sclerotherapy","label":"B"},{"text":"MRI with hepatobiliary contrast for further characterization","label":"C"},{"text":"No intervention; reassurance","label":"D"}]
explanation: Simple hepatic cysts are extremely common, benign, and virtually never require intervention unless symptomatic (pain from mass effect) or complicated (hemorrhage, infection, rupture). This 2 cm cyst has benign imaging features and causes no symptoms. The cognitive error is operating on incidental findings that warrant observation. Surgery exposes the patient to anesthetic risk, complications, and recovery time for a lesion that will almost certainly never cause problems. Why the Wrong Answer is Tempting: Once something is "found," there's pressure to "do something." Surgeons may default to intervention. Aspiration (B) seems less invasive but is unnecessary for a simple cyst and risks infection/recurrence. The radiologist already gave the answer: no follow-up needed. NBME Trap Callout: Incidental simple cyst = leave it alone. Not every finding needs an intervention.

stem:
A 28-year-old man presents with right lower quadrant pain for 18 hours, fever (38.6°C), and anorexia. CT abdomen shows a dilated appendix (12 mm) with periappendiceal fat stranding but no abscess or free perforation. WBC is 14,500/μL. He is hemodynamically stable. The surgical resident books the OR for emergent appendectomy. The attending asks if any alternatives were considered.

What is the most appropriate initial management?
options: [{"text":"Emergent open appendectomy","label":"A"},{"text":"Emergent laparoscopic appendectomy","label":"B"},{"text":"IV antibiotics with interval appendectomy if needed","label":"C"},{"text":"CT-guided drainage","label":"D"}]
explanation: Wait—this is actually appropriate surgical management. This patient has uncomplicated acute appendicitis with no abscess or phlegmon. Laparoscopic appendectomy remains the standard of care for uncomplicated appendicitis in most patients. The cognitive error in this question setup would be assuming antibiotics-first management is universally preferred, but the NOTABLE trial and others show surgery remains superior for most patients. The attending's question is a teaching moment, not an indication to change the plan. Actually, let me revise this question to better fit the concept: Question 14 (REVISED) Concept ID: missing-non-operative-management-window Vignette: A 32-year-old woman presents with 5 days of right lower quadrant pain and low-grade fever. CT abdomen shows a periappendiceal phlegmon (4 cm inflammatory mass) without drainable abscess. She is hemodynamically stable, tolerating oral intake, and her pain is controlled with oral analgesics. WBC is 12,800/μL. The surgical resident schedules emergent appendectomy. Question Stem: What is the most appropriate initial management? Answer Choices: A) Emergent laparoscopic appendectomy B) Emergent open appendectomy with right hemicolectomy C) IV antibiotics with interval appendectomy in 6-8 weeks D) CT-guided drainage followed by immediate surgery E) Oral antibiotics and outpatient follow-up only Correct Answer: C Explanation: This patient has complicated appendicitis with phlegmon (no drainable abscess) and is clinically stable. In this scenario, immediate surgery is associated with higher complication rates (abscess, bowel injury, need for ileocecal resection) because tissue planes are obliterated by inflammation. The cognitive error is defaulting to surgery when conservative management is first-line. Initial IV antibiotics allow inflammation to resolve; interval appendectomy can be performed in 6-8 weeks with lower morbidity. Why the Wrong Answer is Tempting: "Appendicitis = appendectomy" is drilled into trainees. Emergent surgery feels decisive. However, phlegmon without drainable collection is a specific scenario where non- operative management produces better outcomes. NBME Trap Callout: Appendicitis with phlegmon (no abscess) = antibiotics first, surgery later. Don't operate into inflammation.

stem:
A 24-year-old man is brought to the trauma bay after a high-speed motorcycle collision. On arrival, he is moaning, with blood pooling beneath him. Primary survey: Airway is intact with cervical spine immobilization. Breathing reveals decreased breath sounds on the left. Blood pressure is 72/40 mmHg, pulse 132/min and thready. The trauma team leader states, "Let's get him to CT for a full trauma pan-scan to see what we're dealing with."

What is the most appropriate next step in management?
options: [{"text":"CT head, C-spine, chest, abdomen, and pelvis","label":"A"},{"text":"Left chest tube placement and massive transfusion protocol","label":"B"},{"text":"Portable chest X-ray before any intervention","label":"C"},{"text":"FAST examination before leaving trauma bay","label":"D"}]
explanation: This patient is in hemorrhagic shock with clinical evidence of hemothorax (decreased breath sounds, hypotension after chest trauma). The cognitive error is prioritizing imaging over resuscitation in an unstable patient. Unstable trauma patients should NEVER go to CT—they die in the scanner. Immediate interventions (chest tube for likely hemothorax, massive transfusion) take priority. FAST and portable films can occur in the trauma bay, but this patient needs a chest tube now based on clinical exam. Why the Wrong Answer is Tempting: "Pan-scan" provides comprehensive information and is standard for stable trauma patients. The fear of missing injuries drives imaging-first thinking. However, hemodynamically unstable patients need intervention, not diagnosis confirmation. The clinical exam (decreased breath sounds + shock + mechanism) is sufficient. NBME Trap Callout: Unstable trauma patient + clear indication = treat, don't scan. CT is for STABLE patients only. Update Todos Generate Internal Medicine questions (10 concepts) Generate Surgery questions (5 concepts) Generating Pediatrics questions Generate OB/GYN questions (4 concepts) Generate Psychiatry questions (4 concepts) Generate Neurology questions (4 concepts) Generate Emergency Medicine questions (4 concepts) Generate Pulm/Critical Care questions (3 concepts) Generate Nephrology questions (2 concepts) PEDIATRICS

stem:
A 4-year-old boy is brought by his mother for 3 days of rhinorrhea, cough, and low- grade fever (38.2°C). He is drinking fluids, playful in the exam room, and attends daycare. Physical examination reveals clear rhinorrhea, mild pharyngeal erythema without exudate, and bilaterally clear lungs. Tympanic membranes are normal. The mother requests antibiotics because "last time this turned into an ear infection" and she doesn't want to miss work. She appears anxious and says, "I just want to be proactive."

What is the most appropriate management?
options: [{"text":"Prescribe amoxicillin to prevent bacterial superinfection","label":"A"},{"text":"Prescribe azithromycin because it has anti-inflammatory properties","label":"B"},{"text":"Symptomatic care and reassurance with return precautions","label":"C"},{"text":"Obtain rapid strep test before deciding","label":"D"}]
explanation: This child has an uncomplicated viral upper respiratory infection (URI). No findings suggest bacterial infection (no purulent nasal discharge >10 days, no ear findings, no tonsillar exudate, no lung consolidation). The cognitive error is prescribing antibiotics for a viral syndrome under parental pressure or to "prevent" complications. Antibiotics do not prevent bacterial superinfection after viral URI, and inappropriate prescribing drives resistance and adverse effects (rash, diarrhea, C. diff). Why the Wrong Answer is Tempting: Parental pressure is real—the mother is anxious, cites past experience, and wants to avoid missed work. Prescribing feels like "doing something" helpful. Azithromycin (B) sounds reasonable due to its "anti-inflammatory" reputation, but this is not an indication for use. NBME Trap Callout: Viral URI = no antibiotics, regardless of parental request. Antibiotics don't prevent complications and cause harm.

stem:
A 6-year-old girl presents for a well-child visit. She is asymptomatic, meets all developmental milestones, and is active in soccer. On cardiac examination, you detect a grade 2/6 vibratory, musical systolic murmur at the left lower sternal border that disappears when she lies down. There is no radiation, thrill, or click. Pulses are normal. The rest of the examination is unremarkable. The mother is concerned because "heart problems run in the family" and requests an echocardiogram.

What is the most appropriate next step?
options: [{"text":"Order transthoracic echocardiogram","label":"A"},{"text":"Refer to pediatric cardiology for evaluation","label":"B"},{"text":"Obtain ECG and chest X-ray","label":"C"},{"text":"Reassurance that this is a normal finding","label":"D"}]
explanation: This child has a Still's murmur, the most common innocent murmur of childhood. Characteristic features: vibratory/musical quality, grade 1-3, left lower sternal border, changes with position, no radiation, no symptoms, normal exam otherwise. The cognitive error is over-investigating an innocent murmur because of parental anxiety or vague family history. Echocardiography for classic innocent murmurs is low-yield, costly, and may generate incidental findings requiring further workup. Why the Wrong Answer is Tempting: "Family history of heart problems" raises concern. An echo seems harmless and definitive. However, pattern recognition of innocent murmurs is a core pediatric skill—if the murmur has all classic benign features, testing adds no value. NBME Trap Callout: Still's murmur (vibratory, musical, changes with position) = innocent. Reassure, don't echo.

stem:
An 18-month-old boy is brought for a well-child visit. The mother reports he says only "mama" and "dada" but doesn't use other words or point to request objects. He doesn't respond consistently to his name, makes poor eye contact, and prefers to play alone, lining up his toy cars repetitively. He walks well and feeds himself. The mother says her older son "was a late talker too" and asks for reassurance. The pediatrician documents "likely normal variant" and schedules routine 2-year follow-up.

What is the most appropriate next step in management?
options: [{"text":"Reassure and schedule routine 2-year well-child visit","label":"A"},{"text":"Recheck in 3 months for language reassessment","label":"B"},{"text":"Refer for formal developmental evaluation and early intervention","label":"C"},{"text":"Order hearing test only","label":"D"}]
explanation: This child has multiple red flags for autism spectrum disorder: limited vocabulary for age (<6 words at 18 months is concerning), failure to point, poor response to name, limited eye contact, preference for solitary play, and repetitive behaviors. The cognitive error is false reassurance when developmental red flags are present. Early intervention improves outcomes in ASD—waiting for the child to "catch up" delays critical therapies. Referral for formal evaluation should not be delayed. Why the Wrong Answer is Tempting: "Late talker" in an older sibling provides a narrative that normalizes delay. Parents seeking reassurance create pressure to agree. Isolated speech delay might warrant watching, but multiple social-communication red flags require action now. NBME Trap Callout: Multiple developmental red flags ≠ "wait and see." Refer for evaluation at the first visit with concern.

stem:
A 7-year-old girl (weight 25 kg) presents with acute otitis media. She has no drug allergies. The physician prescribes amoxicillin 500 mg twice daily for 10 days, the same dose he commonly prescribes for adults with similar infections. The pharmacist calls to clarify the dose.

What is the most appropriate response to the pharmacist?
options: [{"text":"Confirm the dose as written","label":"A"},{"text":"Change to amoxicillin 875 mg twice daily for better coverage","label":"B"},{"text":"Change to amoxicillin 1000-1125 mg twice daily (80-90 mg/kg/day)","label":"C"},{"text":"Change to azithromycin to avoid dosing confusion","label":"D"}]
explanation: The recommended dose for amoxicillin in acute otitis media is 80-90 mg/kg/day (high- dose) to overcome resistant S. pneumoniae. For a 25 kg child, this equals 2000-2250 mg/day, or approximately 1000-1125 mg twice daily. The prescribed 500 mg twice daily (1000 mg/day = 40 mg/kg/day) is significantly underdosed. The cognitive error is extrapolating adult doses without using pediatric weight-based calculations. Subtherapeutic dosing leads to treatment failure and resistance. Why the Wrong Answer is Tempting: 500 mg BID is a familiar adult dose that "seems reasonable." The original prescription isn't obviously wrong to someone unfamiliar with pediatric dosing. Changing to azithromycin (D) avoids the dosing issue but uses a less effective antibiotic for AOM. NBME Trap Callout: Pediatric dosing = weight-based calculation, not adult dose adaptation. Always calculate mg/kg.

stem:
A 2-year-old previously healthy girl is brought to the ED for fever of 39.2°C (102.6°F) for 1 day. She has mild rhinorrhea. She is alert, interactive, drinking fluids, and playing with toys in the exam room. Physical examination reveals no source of bacterial infection— ears are clear, throat is mildly erythematous without exudate, lungs are clear, and abdomen is benign. The mother is very anxious, stating "fevers this high cause brain damage" and demands a full septic workup including blood cultures, lumbar puncture, and IV antibiotics.

What is the most appropriate management?
options: [{"text":"Obtain CBC, blood culture, urinalysis, and administer ceftriaxone IV","label":"A"},{"text":"Perform lumbar puncture to rule out meningitis","label":"B"},{"text":"Antipyretics, reassurance, and return precautions","label":"C"},{"text":"Admit for observation due to parental concern","label":"D"}]
explanation: This is a well-appearing febrile toddler with clear viral symptoms and no concerning findings on examination. Fever itself, even "high" fever, does not cause brain damage and does not mandate invasive workup in a well-appearing, vaccinated child. The cognitive error is fever phobia–driven over-investigation—allowing parental anxiety to dictate medical decision-making beyond what clinical assessment warrants. The child needs antipyretics, reassurance, and education about fever. Why the Wrong Answer is Tempting: Parental distress is palpable. "Missing meningitis" is a fear. Invasive workup feels thorough and defensive. However, clinical appearance is the most important predictor of serious bacterial infection in febrile children. Well-appearing = low risk. NBME Trap Callout: Well-appearing + vaccinated + no focal source = reassurance, not septic workup. Clinical appearance trumps fever height. stem:
A 28-year-old G1P0 at 39 weeks gestation is in active labor at 6 cm dilation. Continuous fetal monitoring shows moderate variability with accelerations, but over the past 15 minutes, repetitive late decelerations have appeared with contractions. The fetal heart rate baseline is 145 bpm. The mother is lying supine with an oxygen mask. The obstetric resident prepares to call for emergent cesarean section due to "fetal distress."

What is the most appropriate next step in management?
options: [{"text":"Proceed with emergent cesarean delivery","label":"A"},{"text":"Initiate intrauterine resuscitation measures","label":"B"},{"text":"Perform immediate amniotomy to assess for meconium","label":"C"},{"text":"Start oxytocin augmentation to expedite delivery","label":"D"}]
explanation: Late decelerations indicate uteroplacental insufficiency, but this Category II tracing warrants intrauterine resuscitation before operative intervention. Measures include: repositioning (left lateral decubitus), IV fluid bolus, discontinuing oxytocin if running, and supplemental oxygen. The cognitive error is jumping to cesarean delivery without attempting resuscitation for a non-terminal tracing. Many Category II tracings improve with conservative measures. Why the Wrong Answer is Tempting: "Late decelerations" triggers alarm—this is a high-stakes finding. The reflex to deliver immediately feels protective of the fetus. However, emergent cesarean without resuscitation attempts exposes mother to surgical risk unnecessarily when conservative measures might resolve the concerning pattern. NBME Trap Callout: Category II tracing with late decels = intrauterine resuscitation first. Cesarean is for persistent distress despite intervention.

stem:
A 31-year-old G2P1 at 34 weeks gestation presents with headache and blurred vision. Blood pressure is 168/110 mmHg on two readings 15 minutes apart. Urinalysis shows 3+ protein. Labs reveal platelets 98,000/μL, AST 156 U/L, ALT 142 U/L, and creatinine 1.4 mg/dL. She received magnesium sulfate and IV labetalol. The attending suggests continuing expectant management with betamethasone and delivery at 37 weeks "to optimize fetal lung maturity."

What is the most appropriate management?
options: [{"text":"Continue expectant management until 37 weeks","label":"A"},{"text":"Administer betamethasone and deliver after 48 hours","label":"B"},{"text":"Immediate delivery after magnesium sulfate loading","label":"C"},{"text":"Increase labetalol and recheck labs in 24 hours","label":"D"}]
explanation: This patient has severe preeclampsia with HELLP syndrome (Hemolysis, Elevated Liver enzymes, Low Platelets) and severe features (severe hypertension, neurologic symptoms, renal dysfunction). This mandates delivery regardless of gestational age after maternal stabilization. The cognitive error is continuing expectant management when delivery is indicated—waiting for steroids or term exposes mother to seizure, stroke, liver rupture, and death. At 34 weeks, neonatal outcomes are good; maternal risk of delay is unacceptable. Why the Wrong Answer is Tempting: "Fetal lung maturity" and "reaching 37 weeks" are appealing goals. Betamethasone benefit is real, but HELLP can deteriorate within hours. Expectant management is only for preeclampsia without severe features. NBME Trap Callout: Severe preeclampsia with HELLP = deliver now. Don't wait for steroids when maternal life is at risk.

stem:
A 32-year-old woman and her 34-year-old husband present for infertility evaluation after 14 months of unprotected intercourse without conception. Her menstrual cycles are regular (28-30 days), and she has no significant medical history. The gynecologist orders hysterosalpingography (HSG) and ovarian reserve testing for the woman. When asked about evaluating the husband, the physician states, "We'll get to him if her workup is negative."

What is the most appropriate approach to this couple's evaluation?
options: [{"text":"Complete female workup first, then evaluate male if negative","label":"A"},{"text":"Perform HSG before semen analysis to rule out tubal factor","label":"B"},{"text":"Semen analysis concurrent with initial female evaluation","label":"C"},{"text":"Empiric clomiphene citrate trial before any testing","label":"D"}]
explanation: Male factor contributes to approximately 40-50% of infertility cases, and semen analysis is non-invasive, inexpensive, and informative. The cognitive error is prioritizing invasive female testing before simple male evaluation. HSG involves radiation, contrast, and procedural discomfort—it should not be performed before a semen analysis has ruled out male factor. Both partners should be evaluated simultaneously from the start. Why the Wrong Answer is Tempting: The woman is present in the gynecologist's office; it's natural to focus on her. HSG evaluates tubal patency (common cause). However, ordering invasive female tests before a simple male test wastes resources and delays diagnosis if male factor is the primary issue. NBME Trap Callout: Infertility workup = semen analysis FIRST or concurrent. Don't scope her before testing him.

stem:
A 26-year-old G1P0 at 20 weeks gestation presents for routine prenatal visit. She feels well with no complaints. Vital signs show blood pressure 100/60 mmHg (baseline 118/72 mmHg pre-pregnancy) and heart rate 95/min. Laboratory results show hemoglobin 10.8 g/dL and hematocrit 33%. The resident is concerned about "hypotension and anemia" and recommends workup for adrenal insufficiency and orders iron studies with possible transfusion evaluation.

What is the most appropriate next step?
options: [{"text":"ACTH stimulation test for adrenal insufficiency","label":"A"},{"text":"Iron studies and reticulocyte count","label":"B"},{"text":"Reassurance that these findings are normal in pregnancy","label":"C"},{"text":"Echocardiogram for cardiac evaluation","label":"D"}]
explanation: All of these findings represent normal physiologic changes of pregnancy. Blood pressure decreases in the second trimester (nadir around 20-24 weeks) due to decreased systemic vascular resistance. Hemoglobin falls due to plasma volume expansion exceeding RBC mass expansion (dilutional "anemia of pregnancy"). The cognitive error is pathologizing normal gestational changes—ordering workups for expected findings wastes resources and causes patient anxiety. Why the Wrong Answer is Tempting: BP drop of ~18 mmHg systolic looks concerning out of context. Hemoglobin 10.8 g/dL would trigger anemia workup in non-pregnant patients. The numbers appear abnormal if you don't know pregnancy physiology. NBME Trap Callout: Know pregnancy physiology: BP nadirs at 20 weeks, Hgb drops to ~10.5-11 g/dL in second trimester. Don't work up normal findings. stem:
A 24-year-old woman presents with 3 weeks of depressed mood, anhedonia, hypersomnia, and poor concentration. She has no prior psychiatric history and denies suicidal ideation. On further questioning, she mentions that she had a "really productive period" 6 months ago when she slept only 4 hours per night, started three business ventures, spent $15,000 on "investments," and felt she had special insights about the stock market. She currently has no manic symptoms. The physician diagnoses major depressive disorder and prescribes sertraline.

What is the most important consideration before starting this medication?
options: [{"text":"Obtain baseline liver function tests","label":"A"},{"text":"Evaluate for prior manic or hypomanic episodes","label":"B"},{"text":"Check thyroid function to rule out hypothyroidism","label":"C"},{"text":"Warn about sexual side effects","label":"D"}]
explanation: This patient's history describes a prior manic episode (decreased need for sleep, grandiosity, excessive spending, increased goal-directed activity). This changes the diagnosis from major depressive disorder to bipolar disorder. Starting an SSRI in bipolar depression without a mood stabilizer can precipitate mania/hypomania or rapid cycling. The cognitive error is initiating antidepressant therapy without screening for bipolar disorder. Always ask about past manic symptoms before starting antidepressants. Why the Wrong Answer is Tempting: She currently presents with classic depression. Sertraline is first-line for MDD. The prior "productive period" could be dismissed as just a good phase rather than recognized as mania. But the key details (decreased sleep need, grandiosity, reckless spending) are red flags. NBME Trap Callout: Before any antidepressant: ask about prior mania/hypomania. SSRI in bipolar = potential disaster.

stem:
A 22-year-old man is brought to the emergency department by his roommate for bizarre behavior over 2 weeks. He believes the government is monitoring him through his phone and that news anchors are sending him coded messages. He has not slept well and appears paranoid. He has no medical history, takes no medications, and urine drug screen is negative. Vital signs and physical examination are unremarkable, and he is neurologically intact. The ED physician orders CT head and MRI brain "to rule out organic causes."

What is the most appropriate use of neuroimaging in this patient?
options: [{"text":"CT head is mandatory before psychiatric diagnosis","label":"A"},{"text":"MRI brain with contrast to rule out tumor","label":"B"},{"text":"Imaging is not routinely indicated in this presentation","label":"C"},{"text":"PET scan to evaluate for early neurodegenerative disease","label":"D"}]
explanation: This patient has a classic presentation of new-onset psychosis (paranoid delusions, ideas of reference) with no features suggesting organic etiology: no focal neurological findings, no altered mental status fluctuation, no medical comorbidities, normal vitals, negative drug screen. The cognitive error is over-ordering imaging for a primary psychiatric presentation when clinical features are clearly psychiatric. Guidelines do not recommend routine neuroimaging for first-episode psychosis without atypical features. Why the Wrong Answer is Tempting: "Rule out organic cause" sounds thorough and defensive. New psychosis in a young person raises fear of "missing something." However, imaging has very low yield in classic psychiatric presentations without red flags (age >50, focal findings, clouded consciousness, new headache, seizure). NBME Trap Callout: First-episode psychosis with classic features and normal neuro exam = no routine imaging. Clinical context guides workup.

stem:
A 35-year-old man is brought to the ED after his wife found a note suggesting he was planning to end his life. He has a history of depression and a prior suicide attempt 2 years ago (medication overdose). On evaluation, he denies current suicidal ideation, states he wrote the note "weeks ago" when he felt bad, and insists he wants to go home. He is calm and cooperative, denies access to lethal means, and reports he has a therapy appointment next week. The ED physician documents "patient denies SI, contracts for safety" and prepares for discharge.

What is the most appropriate next step in management?
options: [{"text":"Discharge with outpatient therapy follow-up as planned","label":"A"},{"text":"Discharge with crisis line information and safety plan","label":"B"},{"text":"Psychiatric consultation for comprehensive risk assessment","label":"C"},{"text":"Voluntary inpatient admission with patient agreement","label":"D"}]
explanation: This patient has multiple high-risk factors: prior suicide attempt, evidence of recent suicidal planning (the note), and current denial which may represent minimization rather than resolution. "Contracting for safety" is not evidence-based and does not reduce risk. The cognitive error is discharging based on denial alone after recent evidence of suicidal intent. A comprehensive psychiatric risk assessment is essential before any disposition decision. Why the Wrong Answer is Tempting: The patient is calm, cooperative, and denying SI—this feels reassuring. He has outpatient follow-up. "Contracting for safety" feels like a safeguard. However, recent suicidal planning + prior attempt = high risk regardless of current verbal denial. NBME Trap Callout: Recent suicide note + prior attempt = high risk despite denial. Denial after planning behavior requires thorough evaluation, not discharge.

stem:
A 42-year-old woman presents with 8 months of excessive worry about work, finances, and family health. She reports difficulty relaxing, muscle tension, and trouble falling asleep. She has no panic attacks. She tried "meditation apps" without benefit and is requesting medication. She has no substance use history. The physician prescribes alprazolam 0.5 mg three times daily for generalized anxiety disorder.

What would have been a more appropriate first-line pharmacologic treatment?
options: [{"text":"Alprazolam 0.5 mg three times daily","label":"A"},{"text":"Lorazepam 1 mg twice daily","label":"B"},{"text":"Sertraline 50 mg daily","label":"C"},{"text":"Clonazepam 0.5 mg at bedtime","label":"D"}]
explanation: First-line pharmacotherapy for generalized anxiety disorder (GAD) includes SSRIs (sertraline, escitalopram), SNRIs (venlafaxine, duloxetine), or buspirone. Benzodiazepines are second-line due to dependence risk, tolerance, rebound anxiety, and cognitive effects with long-term use. The cognitive error is starting a dependence-risk medication as first-line therapy for a chronic condition. SSRIs address both anxiety and common comorbid depression with better long-term outcomes. Why the Wrong Answer is Tempting: Benzodiazepines work fast—the patient will feel better quickly, creating immediate positive feedback. Alprazolam is familiar and commonly prescribed. The patient wants relief now, and SSRIs take weeks to work. However, starting with a benzodiazepine creates dependence that complicates future management. NBME Trap Callout: GAD is chronic → first-line = SSRI/SNRI/buspirone. Benzodiazepines are short-term adjuncts at best, not maintenance therapy. stem:
A 19-year-old college student presents with 12 hours of severe headache, fever (39.4°C), neck stiffness, and photophobia. He has no significant medical history. Vital signs show blood pressure 128/78 mmHg, pulse 110/min. On examination, he is drowsy but arousable and follows commands. Kernig and Brudzinski signs are positive. There are no focal neurological deficits, papilledema is absent, and he has no seizures. The resident orders CT head before lumbar puncture "to rule out increased ICP."

What is the most appropriate next step in management?
options: [{"text":"CT head followed by lumbar puncture","label":"A"},{"text":"Immediate lumbar puncture followed by antibiotics","label":"B"},{"text":"Empiric antibiotics, CT head, then lumbar puncture","label":"C"},{"text":"Empiric antibiotics and lumbar puncture, defer CT","label":"D"}]
explanation: This patient has classic bacterial meningitis presentation with no contraindications to immediate lumbar puncture. The IDSA guidelines specify that CT before LP is only needed if the patient has: immunocompromised state, history of CNS disease, new- onset seizure, papilledema, altered consciousness, or focal neurologic deficit. This patient has NONE of these—he is drowsy but follows commands and has no focal findings. The cognitive error is delaying LP for CT when no indication for imaging exists. Every hour of antibiotic delay increases mortality. Why the Wrong Answer is Tempting: "Rule out mass/herniation before LP" is taught broadly and feels safe. However, unnecessary CT delays diagnosis and treatment. Choice C (antibiotics, then CT, then LP) seems like a compromise but still delays LP unnecessarily. NBME Trap Callout: CT before LP is NOT universal. Know the specific indications. No focal deficits + no papilledema + no seizure = proceed directly to LP.

stem:
A 28-year-old man with no prior seizure history presents after a witnessed generalized tonic-clonic seizure lasting 2 minutes. He had been drinking heavily at a party the night before and stopped abruptly this morning. He has no history of epilepsy or head trauma. His last drink was approximately 14 hours ago. Examination shows mild tremor, tachycardia (108/min), and diaphoresis. Blood glucose is 95 mg/dL. CT head is normal. The neurology resident orders an EEG and recommends starting levetiracetam.

What is the most appropriate next step in management?
options: [{"text":"Start levetiracetam and obtain EEG","label":"A"},{"text":"Obtain EEG before starting anticonvulsants","label":"B"},{"text":"Treat alcohol withdrawal, no antiepileptic needed","label":"C"},{"text":"MRI brain with epilepsy protocol","label":"D"}]
explanation: This is a provoked seizure due to alcohol withdrawal (timing 12-48 hours after last drink, autonomic signs, recent heavy use with abrupt cessation). Provoked seizures with an identified and correctable trigger do not require antiepileptic drugs or EEG—they require treatment of the underlying cause. The cognitive error is over-investigating when the trigger is identified and resolved. Benzodiazepines for alcohol withdrawal are the appropriate treatment. Long-term AEDs are not indicated. Why the Wrong Answer is Tempting: Any seizure prompts reflexive consideration of epilepsy workup. EEG and AEDs feel like "standard" management. However, treating a withdrawal seizure with levetiracetam misses the point—the pathophysiology is GABA/glutamate imbalance from alcohol cessation, not an epileptic focus. NBME Trap Callout: Provoked seizure with clear trigger = treat the cause, not epilepsy. Alcohol withdrawal seizures don't need AEDs.

stem:
A 68-year-old man presents 2.5 hours after sudden onset of right-sided weakness and slurred speech. CT head shows no hemorrhage. NIHSS score is 14 (moderate-to-severe stroke). Blood pressure is 178/95 mmHg. He takes aspirin daily for coronary artery disease. He had upper GI bleeding 8 months ago, which resolved with PPI therapy. The stroke team is hesitant to give alteplase because of "bleeding history."

What is the most appropriate next step in management?
options: [{"text":"Withhold alteplase due to prior GI bleeding","label":"A"},{"text":"Administer alteplase within the treatment window","label":"B"},{"text":"Perform CT angiography before thrombolytic decision","label":"C"},{"text":"Obtain gastroenterology consultation before alteplase","label":"D"}]
explanation: GI bleeding more than 21 days ago is NOT a contraindication to IV alteplase. Absolute contraindications include: active internal bleeding, recent intracranial surgery/trauma/hemorrhage, bleeding diathesis, and severe uncontrolled hypertension. This patient's remote GI bleed (8 months ago, resolved) is at most a relative consideration, and with an NIHSS of 14 and clear benefit, treatment should not be withheld. The cognitive error is misinterpreting relative contraindication as absolute and depriving the patient of a beneficial treatment. Why the Wrong Answer is Tempting: "History of GI bleeding" sounds like a bleeding risk. The team's hesitation feels cautious. However, withholding thrombolytics from an eligible patient causes measurable harm (disability, death). Know the actual contraindications. NBME Trap Callout: Remote GI bleeding (>21 days) is NOT a contraindication to tPA. Know the actual exclusions—don't withhold beneficial therapy due to overcaution.

stem:
A 52-year-old woman undergoes MRI brain for evaluation of chronic headaches. The scan reveals a 4 mm unruptured intracranial aneurysm in the anterior communicating artery. Her headaches are described as bilateral, pressure-like, occurring 3-4 times weekly, and present for 10 years without change in character. Physical examination is normal. The neurosurgeon recommends endovascular coiling "before it ruptures."

What is the most appropriate management of this aneurysm?
options: [{"text":"Endovascular coiling","label":"A"},{"text":"Surgical clipping","label":"B"},{"text":"Serial imaging surveillance","label":"C"},{"text":"Urgent angiography for procedural planning","label":"D"}]
explanation: Small (<7 mm) unruptured aneurysms in the anterior circulation have a very low annual rupture risk (<0.5%). This patient's chronic tension-type headaches are unrelated to the incidental aneurysm (unchanged character over 10 years). The cognitive error is treating an imaging finding rather than a clinical syndrome. Intervention carries procedural risk (1-2% morbidity/mortality) that may exceed the natural history risk. Serial surveillance with imaging is appropriate for small, asymptomatic aneurysms. Why the Wrong Answer is Tempting: "Aneurysm" sounds dangerous. The neurosurgeon is a specialist recommending treatment. "Preventing rupture" seems obviously good. However, risk-benefit calculation shows that for small, low-risk aneurysms, observation outperforms intervention. NBME Trap Callout: Small incidental aneurysm + asymptomatic = observe, don't intervene. Procedural risk may exceed natural history risk.
