stem:
A 72-year-old man with diabetes presents with fever, confusion, and hypotension. Blood pressure is 74/42 mmHg, pulse 118/min, temperature 39.2°C, and lactate is 6.8 mmol/L. Urine is cloudy, and WBC is 24,000/μL. He is diagnosed with septic shock secondary to urosepsis. The ED physician starts a 30 mL/kg crystalloid bolus (approximately 2.1 L for his 70 kg weight) and plans to reassess "after fluids are complete" before considering vasopressors.

What modification to this resuscitation strategy is most appropriate?
options: [{"text":"Complete the full 30 mL/kg before adding vasopressors","label":"A"},{"text":"Start vasopressors early, concurrent with fluid resuscitation","label":"B"},{"text":"Limit fluids to 20 mL/kg due to age and diabetes","label":"C"},{"text":"Use albumin instead of crystalloid for better hemodynamic response","label":"D"}]
explanation: While the Surviving Sepsis Campaign recommends 30 mL/kg crystalloid as initial resuscitation, current evidence supports early vasopressor initiation in severe shock rather than sequential fluid-then-pressors approach. Waiting to complete all fluids before starting vasopressors in a patient with MAP ~53 mmHg delays restoration of perfusion pressure. The cognitive error is rigid adherence to "fluids first" dogma when profound hypotension warrants earlier pressor support. Why the Wrong Answer is Tempting: "30 mL/kg first, then reassess" is protocol-driven and widely taught. The fear of "pressors on an empty tank" suggests fluids must be complete first. However, excessive fluid without vasopressors in refractory hypotension leads to fluid overload and delayed perfusion. NBME Trap Callout: Septic shock with severe hypotension = early vasopressors. Don't wait until fluids are "complete" to start norepinephrine.

stem:
A 61-year-old man with hypertension and diabetes presents with 45 minutes of crushing chest pain radiating to his jaw and left arm. He is diaphoretic and nauseated. ECG shows 3 mm ST elevations in leads II, III, and aVF. Blood pressure is 142/88 mmHg, and pulse is 62/min. Initial troponin I returns negative (<0.01 ng/mL). The emergency physician orders serial troponins at 0 and 3 hours "to confirm MI before activating the cath lab."

What is the most appropriate next step in management?
options: [{"text":"Wait for 3-hour troponin before cath lab activation","label":"A"},{"text":"Obtain echocardiogram to assess wall motion abnormalities","label":"B"},{"text":"Activate cath lab for emergent PCI","label":"C"},{"text":"Administer thrombolytics if cath lab delay exceeds 120 minutes","label":"D"}]
explanation: This patient has STEMI based on characteristic symptoms plus diagnostic ST elevations in a coronary distribution (inferior leads). The diagnosis of STEMI is clinical + ECG—it does NOT require troponin elevation. Troponins may be negative early (<4-6 hours) because they take time to rise. The cognitive error is waiting for biomarker confirmation when the clinical picture demands immediate action. Door-to-balloon time targets require immediate cath lab activation. Why the Wrong Answer is Tempting: Negative troponin is reassuring. "Confirming" with serial biomarkers seems thorough. However, in STEMI, every minute of delay increases myocardial death and worsens outcomes. The ECG is the diagnostic standard. NBME Trap Callout: STEMI diagnosis = symptoms + ECG. Negative initial troponin does NOT change management. Activate the cath lab immediately.

stem:
A 58-year-old woman presents with 2 hours of substernal chest pressure that resolved spontaneously. She has hypertension and family history of MI in her father at age 52. ECG shows nonspecific T-wave flattening. Initial troponin I is 0.02 ng/mL (normal <0.04 ng/mL). Chest X-ray is normal. The physician tells her the "initial workup is negative" and prepares discharge paperwork with outpatient stress test next week.

What is the most appropriate next step in management?
options: [{"text":"Discharge with outpatient stress test in 5-7 days","label":"A"},{"text":"Discharge with next-day cardiology follow-up","label":"B"},{"text":"Admit for serial troponins and observation","label":"C"},{"text":"Administer GI cocktail and discharge if pain-free","label":"D"}]
explanation: This patient has intermediate pretest probability for ACS: cardiac risk factors, concerning symptoms, and a troponin that, while below the threshold, is at the upper range of normal (0.02, with cutoff 0.04). A single "normal" troponin does not exclude ACS—serial markers are required. The cognitive error is premature discharge based on a negative initial snapshot when clinical suspicion warrants further observation. Ruling out ACS requires time-based troponin assessment. Why the Wrong Answer is Tempting: "ECG non-diagnostic, troponin normal, chest X-ray normal" sounds like a complete negative workup. The symptoms resolved. Outpatient follow-up seems reasonable. However, ACS rule-out requires serial biomarkers (typically 0 and 3-6 hours minimum). NBME Trap Callout: One negative troponin ≠ ruled out. Intermediate-risk chest pain requires serial biomarkers before safe discharge.

stem:
A 32-year-old man presents with 6 hours of severe right lower quadrant abdominal pain, rated 9/10. He is writhing on the stretcher, tachycardic (pulse 112/min), and diaphoretic. Examination reveals focal RLQ tenderness with voluntary guarding. CT abdomen is ordered. The patient begs for pain medication. The physician states, "I can't give you anything until surgery evaluates you—pain medication will mask your exam."

What is the most appropriate next step in management?
options: [{"text":"Withhold analgesia until surgical consultation","label":"A"},{"text":"Administer IV morphine for pain control","label":"B"},{"text":"Administer oral acetaminophen as a non-masking alternative","label":"C"},{"text":"Offer distraction techniques and reassurance","label":"D"}]
explanation: The outdated dogma of withholding analgesia to avoid "masking" physical exam findings has been definitively refuted by multiple studies. Appropriate analgesia does NOT increase diagnostic errors, delay surgery, or obscure peritoneal signs. The cognitive error is causing unnecessary suffering based on a disproven concern. Pain control is ethical, improves patient cooperation with exam, and does not compromise surgical decision-making. Why the Wrong Answer is Tempting: "Don't give pain meds until surgery sees them" is still taught in some settings. The fear of masking appendicitis or missing peritonitis persists. However, evidence shows that untreated pain is harmful and that treated patients can still be properly assessed. NBME Trap Callout: Pain medication does NOT mask peritoneal signs. Treat pain—it's ethical and evidence- based. stem:
A 68-year-old man with COPD presents with severe respiratory distress after 3 days of worsening dyspnea during an exacerbation. He is using accessory muscles, has tripod positioning, and can speak only 1-2 words between breaths. Respiratory rate is 36/min, SpO2 84% on 6L nasal cannula. He appears exhausted. The resident orders an arterial blood gas "to confirm respiratory failure before intubating."

What is the most appropriate next step in management?
options: [{"text":"Obtain ABG and await results before intubation","label":"A"},{"text":"Increase supplemental oxygen to 15L non-rebreather","label":"B"},{"text":"Trial of BiPAP before considering intubation","label":"C"},{"text":"Proceed with endotracheal intubation","label":"D"}]
explanation: This patient has clinical respiratory failure: severe accessory muscle use, inability to speak, exhaustion, hypoxemia despite supplemental oxygen, and impending respiratory arrest. The diagnosis of respiratory failure is CLINICAL—waiting for ABG confirmation wastes precious time when the patient is decompensating. The cognitive error is waiting for laboratory confirmation when clinical picture is unambiguous. Intubate based on clinical assessment, not numbers. Why the Wrong Answer is Tempting: ABG "confirms" respiratory failure with pH and CO2 values. It feels objective and documented. BiPAP (C) is appropriate for earlier-stage COPD exacerbation, but this patient is beyond that—exhaustion and minimal speech suggest imminent arrest. Waiting for data delays life-saving intervention. NBME Trap Callout: Clinical respiratory failure = intubate. Don't wait for ABG when the patient is crashing in front of you.

stem:
A 55-year-old woman was intubated 3 days ago for severe pneumonia. She has improved significantly: afebrile, WBC normalizing, FiO2 weaned to 0.30, PEEP 5 cm H2O. She passes a spontaneous breathing trial (SBT): respiratory rate 18/min, tidal volume 450 mL, SpO2 97%, no distress for 30 minutes. She follows commands and has adequate cough. The RASS score is 0, and she has minimal secretions. The attending physician says, "She just looks weak to me—let's give her another day on the vent to get stronger."

What is the most appropriate next step in management?
options: [{"text":"Continue mechanical ventilation for another 24-48 hours","label":"A"},{"text":"Increase pressure support and retry SBT tomorrow","label":"B"},{"text":"Extubate the patient","label":"C"},{"text":"Obtain NIF and RSBI before extubation decision","label":"D"}]
explanation: This patient meets ALL criteria for extubation: resolution of underlying condition, adequate oxygenation on minimal settings, passed SBT, follows commands, good cough, minimal secretions. Subjective impressions like "she looks weak" are not evidence-based criteria for continued ventilation. The cognitive error is prolonging mechanical ventilation based on subjective concern despite objective readiness. Each additional day of ventilation increases VAP risk, delirium, and ICU length of stay. Why the Wrong Answer is Tempting: The attending is experienced; "clinical gestalt" carries weight. "One more day to get stronger" seems cautious. However, prolonged ventilation causes harm. Protocol-based weaning outperforms subjective assessment. NBME Trap Callout: Passed SBT + meets extubation criteria = extubate. Don't override protocols with gut feelings.

stem:
A 71-year-old man with severe COPD (FEV1 28% predicted) presents with acute exacerbation. He is dyspneic and confused. Respiratory rate is 28/min, SpO2 82% on room air. ABG shows pH 7.28, PaCO2 72 mmHg, PaO2 48 mmHg. The ED nurse places him on 15L non-rebreather mask to "get his oxygen up." Thirty minutes later, he becomes more somnolent. Repeat ABG shows pH 7.22, PaCO2 92 mmHg, PaO2 112 mmHg.

What error occurred in this patient's oxygen management?
options: [{"text":"Oxygen should have been withheld due to COPD","label":"A"},{"text":"High-flow oxygen suppressed hypoxic respiratory drive","label":"B"},{"text":"Non-rebreather caused CO2 rebreathing","label":"C"},{"text":"COPD patients require higher oxygen targets","label":"D"}]
explanation: This patient has chronic CO2 retention (COPD with baseline hypercapnia). In these patients, the respiratory drive is predominantly driven by hypoxemia, not CO2. Administering high-flow oxygen eliminated the hypoxic drive, causing hypoventilation, worsening hypercapnia, and CO2 narcosis. The cognitive error is oxygen titration error in a COPD patient—targeting normal SpO2 (>95%) instead of appropriate target (88-92%). Controlled oxygen delivery (Venturi mask or titrated nasal cannula) is required. Why the Wrong Answer is Tempting: "Hypoxemia is dangerous—get the oxygen up" is instinctual. High-flow oxygen seems safe. However, in CO2 retainers, the hyperoxia-induced hypoventilation can be fatal. Target SpO2 88-92% in COPD. NBME Trap Callout: COPD + CO2 retention = target SpO2 88-92%. High-flow oxygen can kill by suppressing respiratory drive. stem:
A 62-year-old man with type 2 diabetes and hypertension is started on lisinopril 10 mg daily for new diagnosis of diabetic nephropathy (creatinine 1.4 mg/dL, urine albumin-to- creatinine ratio 350 mg/g). One week later, repeat labs show creatinine increased to 1.7 mg/dL. Potassium is 5.1 mEq/L. Blood pressure is well controlled at 128/76 mmHg. The physician discontinues lisinopril due to "worsening kidney function."

What would have been the most appropriate response to this laboratory finding?
options: [{"text":"Discontinue lisinopril immediately","label":"A"},{"text":"Continue lisinopril; this creatinine rise is expected and acceptable","label":"B"},{"text":"Switch to amlodipine for blood pressure control","label":"C"},{"text":"Reduce lisinopril dose by 50%","label":"D"}]
explanation: ACE inhibitors cause an expected, hemodynamically-mediated rise in creatinine due to efferent arteriolar dilation—this is NOT nephrotoxicity. A rise of up to 30% from baseline is acceptable and should be tolerated because ACE inhibitors provide long- term renoprotection in diabetic nephropathy. This patient's creatinine rose ~21% (1.4 to 1.7), which is within acceptable range. The cognitive error is discontinuing a renoprotective agent for an expected physiologic effect. Why the Wrong Answer is Tempting: Rising creatinine looks like kidney injury. "First, do no harm" suggests stopping the apparent offender. However, stopping ACE inhibitors in this situation deprives the patient of a drug with proven benefit for slowing diabetic nephropathy progression. NBME Trap Callout: Creatinine rise up to 30% on ACE/ARB = expected and acceptable. Don't stop renoprotective therapy for this.

stem:
A 78-year-old woman with heart failure presents after 3 days of diarrhea and poor oral intake. She is lethargic and has dry mucous membranes, decreased skin turgor, and flat neck veins. Blood pressure is 92/58 mmHg, and pulse is 108/min. Serum sodium is 126 mEq/L, BUN 42 mg/dL, and creatinine 1.8 mg/dL (baseline 1.0). Urine sodium is <10 mEq/L. The resident orders fluid restriction to 1 liter per day "for hyponatremia."

What is the most appropriate next step in management?
options: [{"text":"Fluid restriction to 1 L/day","label":"A"},{"text":"3% hypertonic saline infusion","label":"B"},{"text":"Isotonic saline infusion","label":"C"},{"text":"Tolvaptan administration","label":"D"}]
explanation: This patient has hypovolemic hyponatremia (diarrhea, poor intake, hypotension, tachycardia, dry membranes, low urine sodium indicating renal sodium conservation). Fluid RESTRICTION is for euvolemic (SIADH) or hypervolemic hyponatremia—not hypovolemia. The cognitive error is applying the wrong treatment protocol based on sodium value alone without assessing volume status. Treatment for hypovolemic hyponatremia is volume resuscitation with isotonic saline, which will suppress ADH and allow free water excretion. Why the Wrong Answer is Tempting: "Hyponatremia = fluid restrict" is a commonly memorized reflex. However, volume status determines treatment. In hypovolemia, restriction worsens hypotension and perpetuates ADH release. Giving saline corrects both volume AND sodium. NBME Trap Callout: Hyponatremia treatment depends on VOLUME STATUS. Hypovolemic = give saline. Euvolemic (SIADH) = restrict fluids. Anchoring on initial diagnosis despite new data 2. Over-ordering advanced imaging when first-line test is indicated 3. Treating asymptomatic bacteriuria 4. Premature antibiotic escalation 5. Confusing acute vs chronic management 6. Repeating negative workup instead of observation 7. Mistaking "next best step" for "most accurate test" 8. Missing medication as cause of new symptoms 9. Treating lab value, not patient 10. Premature closure in workup 11. Delaying surgical consultation for imaging 12. Misidentifying surgical urgency 13. Intervening on stable incidental findings 14. Missing developmental red flags 19. Adult dosing extrapolation to pediatrics 20. Fever phobia–driven intervention 21. Cesarean without intrauterine resuscitation 22. Delaying delivery in severe preeclampsia 23. Invasive female workup before semen analysis 24. Pathologizing physiologic pregnancy changes 25. SSRI in undiagnosed bipolar 26. Excessive imaging for primary psychiatric presentation 27. Discharge after suicide denial despite planning 28. Benzodiazepine first-line for chronic anxiety 29. CT before LP without indication 30. EEG/AED for provoked seizure 31. tPA hesitation for relative contraindication 32. Treating incidental imaging finding 33. Rigid fluids-before-pressors adherence 34. Waiting for troponin in STEMI 35. Discharging after one negative test 36. Withholding analgesia pending diagnosis 37. ABG before clinical intubation 38. Override of weaning protocol by subjective concern 39.
